In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. div.note: Prologue
div.l: WHan that Aprylle / wyth hys showres soote
The drowhte of Marche / hath ꝑpercede to the rote
And bathed euery veyne / in suche licour
Of whiche vertu / gendred is the flour
Whan zepherus eek / wtith his swete breth
Inspired hath / euꝰery holt and heth
The tendre croppys / and the yong sonne
Hath in the Ram / half cours y ronne
And smale fowles / maketh melodye
That slepyn all the nyght / wtith opyn eye
So prykketh hem nature / in here corages
Than longen folke / to gon̄ n in pylgrimages
And palmers for to seken / stran̄nge strondes
To fern halwes couthe in many londys
And specially / fro euery sheris ende
Of englonde / to Cantirbury they wynde
The holy blisfull martir / for to seke
That hem hath holpen / whan they were sieke
Be fell in that seson̄ n/ on a day
In southwerke at the tabbarde / as I lay
Redy to wende in my pilgrymage
To Cantirbury wtith ful devout corage
That nyght were com / in to that hostelery
Wel . ix and xx.tiri / in on company
Of sondry folke / by aventure fall
In felawshepe / and pylgrymes were they all
That towarde Cantirbury / wolde they ryde
The Chambres / and the stables were wyde
And wel we werne esed at the beste
And shortly / whanne the son was gon to Reste
So hadde I spokyn / wtith hem euerychon
That I was / of her felashepe a noon
And made forwarde / erly forto a ryse
To take our way / ther as y you devyse
But natheles / whil I haue tyme and space
Er that ferther / in this tale pace
Me thynkyth / it accordith on to reasou
To telle yow / of alle here condicioun .
Of eche of hem / as it xxxx semed me .
And whiche they were / and of what degre .
And eke what array / they were Inne .
And at a knyght / than wol I first begynne .
A knyght ther was / and that a worthy man .
That fro the tyme / that he first began .
To rydyn out / he loved cheualrye .
Trewthe and honorur / fredom and curtesye .
Well worthy was he / in his lordis werre .
And ther hadde ryden / no man so ferre .
As wel in cristyndom / as in hethnesse .
And euyr honowred / for his worthynesse .
At Alisaundir he was / whan it was wonne .
Ful oft he hadde / the boorde begonne .
A bouen al nacions / in pruce .
In lettowe hadde he rersed / and in Ruce .
No cristen man / so oft of his degre .
In gernade at the sege / eek hadde he be .
Off algizir / and riden in belmarie .
At lyeyes was he / and at Satalye .
Whan they were wonne / and in the grete se .
At many a noble / arme hadde he be .
At mortel batayles / hadde he befyftene .
And fowhten / for our feythe at Tramissene .
In lyhstys thries / and ay slayn his foo .
This ilke worthi knyght / hadde ben also .
Somtyme wtith the lorde / of palatye .
A yen a nothir hethene / in Turkye .
And evirmore / he hadde a souereyn prys .
And therto eek / he worthy was and wys .
And of his port / as meke as any maide .
He nevir yit no vylanye ne saide .
In al his lyve / vnto no maner wyght .
He was a verray ꝑperfyht gentyl knyht
div.note: Prologue
div.l: But for to telle you / of his array
His hors was good / but he ne was nat gay
Of fustian / he werid a gypoun ̄n
All besmotered / wtith his haberioun
For he was late / come fro his viage
And went for to don / his pilgrymage
Wyth hym ther was / his son a yong Sqwyer Sqyer
A loueer / and a lusty bacheler
Wyth lockes crul. / as they wer leyd in presse
He twenty yer of age / was as I gesse
Off his stature / he was of evene lenghe
And wondirly delyuyr / and grete of strengthe
And he hadde be / somtyme in chyvalrye
In Flaundres . artois . and in Pykardye
And borne him well / as of so lytel space.
In hope to stondyn / in his lady grace
Embroyded was he / as it were a mede
Al ful of freysh flowres / white and reede
Syngyng he was / and floytyng al the day .
He was as freysh / as the moneth of may
Short was his gowne / wtith slevys long and wyde
Wel coude he sitt on hors / and faire ryde
He coude songis make / and wel endyte
Iuste and daunce / and wel portrey and wryte
So hoot he louede / that be nyhterdale
He slepe no more / than doth de nyhtyngale
Curteys he was / lovely and seruysable
And craf be forne his Fader / at the table
A yoman he hadde / and ꝸseruauntꝭes no moo
At that tyme / for hym lyst ryde so : yoman̄n
And he was clad / in cote and hood grene
A sheff of pokok arwes / bryght and shene
Vndir his belte he bare well thryftely
Well cowde he dresse / his takyl yomanly
His arwes drouped nowht / wtith fetheres lowe
And in his hond . he bar / a myhty bowe
A not hed he d hadde / wtith a browne visage
Of wode craft / wel coude he all the vsa
Vp on his arme / he bare a gay bracer
And be his side / a swerde and a bokeler
And on that othir side / a gay daggere
Harneysed wel / and sharp as poynt of spere
A crystofir on his brest / of seluyr shene
An horne he bare / the bawdryk was of grene
A Foster was he / sothly as I gesse .
THer was also / a nonne a pryoresse
div.note: Nonne
div.l: That of here smylyng / was wol symple and coy
Hir grettest oth . / was but by seynt loy
And she was clepid / madame Eglentyne
Full wel she song / the ꝸseruice diuine
Entewned in her nose / ful swetely .
And frenshe she spake / wol fair and fetisly
After the scole / of Stratforde at bowe
For frenshe of paris / was to here vnknowe
At mete wel I tawht / was she wtith all
She let / no mussell / from hir lyppes fall
Ne wete here fyngres / in hir sauce depe
Wel coude she carye / a morsel and wel kepe
That no drope / falle on here brest
In curtesye was set / wel moche here list
Her ovyr lyppe / wyped she so clene /
That in her cuppe / ther was no ferthyng sene
Of grece / whan she hadde dronke her drawht
Wol semely / aftir her mete she rawht
And sikerly / she was of grete disport
And wel pleasaunt / and amyable of port
And peyned here / to conterfete chere
Off coort / and to be estatlych of manere .
div.note: A6
Prologue
div.l: And to be holden / digne of xxx reuerence
But for to speke / of her conscience
She was so charitable / and pytous
She wolde wepe / and she sey a movs
Cawht in a trappe / if it were deed or bledde
Off smale houndes / hadde she that she fedde
Wyth Rosted flesh / or mylke or wastylbred .
But sore wept she / yf any of hem were ded
Or if men smyte it / wtith a yerde smert
And all was conscience / and tendre hert
Wol semely / here wymple pynched was
Here nose streyht / her eyen grey as glas
Here mouth small / and therto soft and reed
But sekerly / she hadde a fayr forhed
It was all most a spanne brod I trowe
For hardely / she was not vndir growe
Wel fetys was here cloke / as I was warre
Of smal coral / a boute her arme she barre
A peyre of bedis / gavded al wtith grene
And theron heng / a broche of golde ful shene
On whiche therwas / first writen a crowned . A .
And aftir / Amor vincit omnia /
A nother nonne also / wtith her hadde she
That was her chapeleyn / and prestis . thre
A Monke ther was / a fair for the Maistre
An out ridere / that loved venerye
div.note: Monke
div.l: A manly man / to ben an Abbot able
Ful many a deynte hors / hadde he in his stable
And whan he roode / men myht his bridell her
Gynglyng in a whistlyng wynde as clere
And eek as lowde / as doth the chapell belle
Ther as this lorde / was keper of the selle
The rewle of seynt Mavr / othir of seynt benyt
Be causet it was olde / and somdel streyht
This ilk monke / let old thynges pace
And held / aftir the newe worlde the trace
He yaf not of the tixt / a pulled henne
That seyth that hunters / beth nat holy menne
Not that a monk / whanne he is recheles
Ne likned to a fyssh / that is waterles
This is to seyne . a monke out of his cloistre
But thilk tyxt / held he nat worth an oistre
And I saide / his opynyon was good
What shulde he studye / and make him self wood
Vp on a bok in cloistre / al day to povre
And swynke / wtith his handes and labour
As Austyn bit / how shulde the worlde be ꝸserued
Lat Austyn haue his swynk / to him reꝸserued
Therfor he was / a pirikasowre a ryht
Grehoundes he hadde / / as swyft as foul in flyht
Of prykyng and of hontyng for the hare
Was all his lust / for no cost wolde he spare
I saw his slevis / purfilid at the hond
Wyth grys / and that the fynest of a lond
And for to fastyn / his hood vnder the chyn
He hadde of golde / wrowht a wol coryows pyn
A love knotte in the grettere ther was
His hed was balled / that shon as any glas
And eek his face / as he hadde ben anoynt
He was a lorde / wel fat / and in good poynt
His eyen stepe / and rollyng in his hed
That stremed / as a forneys of a leed
His botys souple / his hors in gret astat
Nowe certenly / he was a faire prelat
He was nat pale / as a for pyned gost
A fat swanne loved he best / of any rost .
His palfrey was as brown / as any bery .
A Frere ther was / a wanton an amery
div.note: Frere
div.l: A lymytour / a wol solempne man
In all the ordres foure / is noon that kan
div.note: Prologue
div.l: So mechel of dalyance / and faire language
He hadde made / wol mony a maryage
Of yong women / at his owne cost
Vnto his ordre / he was a noble post
And wel I loved / and famylyarye was he
Wyth frankeleyns / over al in his contre
And worthy women / of the townne
For he hadde power / of confession
As seide him self / more thanne a curat
For of his ordre / he was lycencyat
Wel swetely was herd he confession
And plesaunt was / his absolucion
He was an esy man / to yeve penaunce
Ther he wyst / to haue a good pytaunce
For vnto a pore ordre for to yeue
Is signe that a man / is wel I shreve
For yf he yeue / he durst make avaunt
He wyst that a man / was repentaunt
For many a man / so hard is of his herte
He may nat wepe / thawe he sore smert
And therfore in stede / of wepyng and parayeris
Men mote yeue silver / to the pore freres
His typet was ay farsed ful of knyves
And pynnes for to yeve faire wyves
And certaynely / he hadde a mery noote
Wel cowde he synge / and pley at the roote
Off yeddynges / he bare vttirly the pris
His necke whit was / as the floure delys
Therto he strong was / as a champion
He knewe the tavernys / wel in euꝰery toun
And euꝰery hosteler / and tapstre
Bet than a laȝeer / or a begstre
For vnto suche / a worthy man as he
Accordyth nat / as be his faculte
To haue wtith syke / laȝeris acqueyntaunce
It is nat honest / it may not avaunce .
For to delyn / wyth no such Porayle
But al wtith ryche / and seleres of vytayle
And ovirall ther / as profit shulde a ryse
Curteys he was / and lovelyche of seruyse
Ther was no man / nowher so vertuous
He was the best / begger of his hows
For thow a wydwe / hadde but a sho
So plesaunt / was his Inprincipio
Yeet wolde he haue a ferthyng er than he wente
His purchas was wel better than his rente
And rage he cowde / ryght as it were a whelp
In love dayes there / kovde he mechel help
For ther he was / nat lyk a cloisterer
Wyth thredbare coope / as is a pore skoler
But he was a maister or a pope
Off dowble worstede / was his semy cope
That was rownded as a belle / out of the presse
Somwhat he lypsed / for his wantounesse
To maken his englysh swete / vpon his tong.
And in his harpyng / whan he hadde song
His eyen twynkelid / in his hed a ryht
As doth the sterres / in the frosty nyht
This worthi lymytour / was cleped hoberd
A Marchaunt was ther / wtith a forked berd .
div.note: Marchaunt
div.l: In motle / and hie on hors he sat
Vp on his hedde / a flaundersh beuer hat
His botys clapsed / faire and fetysly
His resoūns he spake / ful solempnely
Sownyng al wey / thencrees of his wynnyng
He wold the se / were kept for any thyng
Bi twix middel borwhe / and orewelle
Wel coude he in eschawyng sheedys selle
This worthy man / ful wel his wyt beset
Ther woste no wyht / that he was in Det .
div.note: Prologue
div.l: So estatlych was he / of his gouernaunce
Wyth his bargayns / and wtith his chevesaunce
Forsothe he was / a worthi man wtith. all
But soth for to telle / I not howe men him call
A Clerk ther was / of Oxynforde also
div.note: Clerk
div.l: That vnto logyk / hadde long I go
As leene as was his hors / as is a rake
And he was nat ryht fat / I vndirtake
But loked holowe / and therto sobirly.
Wol thredbare was / his ovirmest courtepye
For he ne hadde get him / yet no benefys
Ne was so wordlych / for to haue offys
For hym was levir to haue / at his beddis hedde
Twenty bokes / clad in blak and reed
Off Aristotele / and his philosophir
Than robys ryche / other fethele other Sawterye
But all by that / he was a philisophre
Yet hadde he / but lytell golde in cofre
But all that he myht / of his frendys hente
On bokes and on lernyng / he it spente
And besili gan / for the sowles preye
Of hem that yaf / wherwyth to scoleye
Off studye tok he / most cure and heed
Nowt on word spake he / more than was nede
And that was seid / in foorme and reuerence
And short and quyk / and ful of hye sentence
Sownyng in mortall / vꝰertu was his speche
And gladly wold he lerne / and gladly teche
A Seriaunt of the lawe / war and wys
div.note: Seriaunt of lawe
div.l: That oft hadde I be / at the parvys
He was also / wol ryche of excellense
Discret he was / and of grete reuerenee
He semed suche / his wordys were so wyse
Iustice he was often / in assice
By patēmt / and by pleyn commission
For his science / and his hyh renoun
Off feeis and roobis / hadde he many oon
So grete a purchasur / was nowher noon
Al was fee symple / to him in effect
His purchasyng / myht nat be infect
Nowher so besy a man as he / ther nas
And yit he seemed besiere / that he was
In termis hadde he cas / and domys alle
That fro the tyme of kyng william wer falle
Therto he cowde endyte / and make a thyng
Ther cowde no wyht / pynche at his wrytyng
And euꝰery statute / cowde he pleyn be roote
He rood but homly / in a medly coote
But wtith a seynt of silke wtith. barres smale
Off his array / telle I no lenger tale
A Frankelyn / was in his companye
div.note: Frankelyn
div.l: Whit was his berd / as is the dayeseye
Off his complexion / he was sangweyn
Weel loved he bi the morowe / a soppe in wyn
To levyn in delit / was euer his wone
For he was Epicurus / owne sone
That helde opynyon / that pleyn delit
Was verray felycyte / ꝑperfyt
An housholdere and that a grete was he
Seynt Iulian / he was clepid in his contre
His breed his Ale / was alwey aftir oon
A bettir envyned man / was nowher noon
Wyth out bake mete / was neuyr his house
Of fysh of flessh / and that so plentevous
It sewed in his hous / of mete and drynke
Of all deyntee / that men cowde thynke
Aftir the sondry sesons / of the yeer
So chaunged he his mete / and his sopeer
div.note: Prolog
div.l: Wel many a fat ꝑpertryche / had he in mewe
And many a breme / and many a luce in stewe
Woo was his cook / but if his sauce were
Poynaunt and reedy / al his other gere
His table dormant / in his halle alway
Stood reedy keveryd / al the longe day
At sessioūns / ther was he lorde and sire
Weel oftyn tyme / he was knyght of the shire
An anlas and a gipser / al of sylke
Heng at his girdell / whit as morowe mylke
A shereve had he be / and a comptour
Was nowher such / a worthy vavasour
AN habirdassher / and a Carpynteer
A Webber a dyere / and a tapyster
div.note: habirdassher
div.l: And they were clothed / all in oon lyvere
div.note: carpynteer
div.l: Of a solempne / and a grete fraternyte
div.note: webber . dyere
div.l: Ful freyssh and newe / here geer pyked was
div.note: tapyster
div.l: Her knyves were nat / chaped wtith bras
But all wtith siluer / wrowht ful clene and wel
Here girdelys / and here powches everydell
Wel seemed ech of hem / a fayr burgeys
To sitten in a yelde halle / or at the deys
Eueryche of the wysdam that he can
Was shaply for to be / a aldirman
For catell hadde they I nowe / and rente
And eek her wyves / wolde it wel assente
Or ellys certayn / they were moche to blame
It is wel fair / to be clepid madame
And for to gon to vigiliis / al before
And haue a mantyl / ryally I bore
A Cook they hadde wtith hem / for the nonys
To boile the chekenys / wtith the mary bonys
div.note: cook
div.l: And poudre marchaunt / tart and galyngale
Wel coude he knowe / a drauht of london ale
He coude rost and seth / boyle and frye
Make mortrows / and wel bake a pye.
But grete harme was it / as thouht me
That on his shene / a mormale had he
For blanmager / maad he wtith the beste
A Shipman was ther / wonnyng ferre bi weste
div.note: Shipman
div.l: For out I wot he was / of dertemouthe
He rood vppon a rontyn / as he couthe
In a gowne of faldyng to the kne
A daggere hangyng / by a lace had he
A bowten̄n his necke / vndir his arm don
The hote somer / had mad his hew ful bron
And certenly / he was a good felawe
Wol many drawht of wyn / hadde he drawe
Fro Burdeus warde / whill A the shipman sleep
If that he fauht and hadde the heyere hond
Be water he sent hem hom / bi every lond
But of his craftes / to relnen wel his tydes
His stremes and his daūngeres / ther besides
His heborh and his mone / and his loodmanage
Thes was noon such / fro hull to Cartage
Hardy he was / and wys to vndirtake
Wyth many a tempest hath his berd be shake
He knew all the havenys / as they were
Fro scottlonde / to the cape of fynestre
And euꝰery creek / in bretayne and in spayne
His barge was clepid / the Magdaleyne
Wyth vs ther was also / a doctour of phisik
div.note: doctoᵘur of physik
div.l: In all this world / was ther noon him lyk
To speke of phisik / and of surgerye
For he was grownded / in astronomye
He kept his pacyent / a wel gret del
In houris bi his magik / naturel
Wel coude he / the fortune accident
Of his ymages / for his pacient
He knewe the cause / of every maladye
Were it of hoot cold / moyst or drye
And were engendred / of what humour
He was a verray / Parfit practisour
For eche of hem / maketh other for to wynne
Here frendshepe / was nat newe to bigynne
Weel knew he tholde / Esculapius
And diascorides / and eke Rufus
Olde ypocras / haly / and Galien
Serapion / Razis / and Auyzen
Auerois / Damascien / and Constantyn
Bernard / and Gatisden / and Gelbertyn
Of his dyet / meserable was he
For it was / of noon suꝑperfluite
But of grete norshyng / and digestible
His study was but litell / on the bybill
In sangvyne and in perce / he clad was al
Lyved wtith taffata / and wtith sendal
And yet he was but esye / of dispense
He kept that he wan / in the pestelense
For gold in phisik / is a cordyal
Ther he loved gold in special .
A Good wyf was ther / of besyde Bathe
But she was somdel def / and that was skathe
Of cloth makyng / she hadde such an haunt
She passed hem of ypris and of gamt
In all the paryssh / ne was ther wyf noon
That to thoffryng / before here shuld goon
And if ther dede / certeyn so worth was she
That she was out / of all charyte

This froissh beaute / sleth me sodenly
Of hir that rometh / in the yondir place
And but I haue hir mercy / and hir grace
That I may sen̄ hire / at the lest wey
I am but ded / ther is no moor to sey
This palamon / whan he this wordys herd
Dispitously he loked / and Answerde
Whethir seyth thou this / in ernest or in pley
Nay ꝙquod Arcite in ernest / by my fey
God help me so / me list wol evyl pleye
This palamon gan knytte / his browes tweye
It were ꝙquod he / to the no grete honour
For to be fals / ne for to be traitour
To me that am thi cosyn / and thi brother
I swoor wol depe and ecħ of vs to othe
That nevyr for to deyen / in the peyne
Til that deeth deꝑparte shall / vs tweyne
Neythir of vs in love / to hynder othir
Be in noon othir caas / my swete brothir
But thou truly / shuldest forther me
In every caas / and I shall forther the
This was thyn oth and myn also certeyn
I wot it wel / thou darst it not wᵗithseyn
Thus art thou of my conseyl / out of doute
And nowe woldest / falsly ben aboute
To love my lady / whom I love and serve
And ever shalle / till that myn hert sterve
Now certys false Arcite thou shalt not so
I loved her first / and told the of my woo
As to my conseyl / and to my brothir sworn
To forther me / as I haue told bi forn
For whiche / thou art boundyn as a knyht
To helpyn me / if it lay in thi myht
Or ellys than art fals / I dar wel seyn
This Arcite wol proudly spak a geyn
Thou shalt ꝙquod he / be rather fals than I
But than art false / I telle the vituly
For paramour / I loved her first er thou
What wilt thou say / thou wyst it nat vyht novoe
Wher she were a woman or a goddesse
Thyn is affeccion / of w holynesse
And myn is love / as to a creature
For whiche / I told the myn aventure
As to my cosyn / and my brothir sworn
I suppose that thou lovedist hir biforn
Wost thou nat wel / tholde clerkes sawe
That who shall y yeve a lovere any lawe
Love is a grettere lawe / by my pan
Than may be yeve / to any erthlych̉e ma
And therfor positif lawe and suche decre
Is broke alday / for love in eche degre
A man must nedis love / mavgre his hed
He ne may forbere / thou he shuldle ded
As be she mayd wydowe / or ellis wyf
And eek it is nat lykly / all thy lyf
To stondyn in hir grace / no more than I
For wel thou wost / thy self verraily
That thou and I / be dampned to prisoun
Perpetually vs gayneth / no ranson
We striven / as dede the houndys for the bon
They fouhte all day / and yet here ꝑpart was noon Exᵐ
Ther kam a kyte / whil they were so wrothe
That bare awey the boon by twyxe hem bothe
And therfor at kynges coort / my brother
Eche man for hym self / ther is noon othir
Love if theu lust / for I love and ay shal
And sothly leeve brothir / this is al
Here in this prisoun / we mote endure
And eueryche of vs take / his aventure
Gret was the stryf / and long betwyxe them twey
If that I hadde leyser / for to seye
But to thaffect / it happed on a day
To tell it yow / as shortly as I may
A worthi Duke / that hihte ꝐPertheus Perithous
That felawe was / to Duke Theseus
Syth thilke day / that thei were children lyte
Was come to Athenys / his felawe to visite
And for to pleye / as he was wont to doo
For in this worlde / he loved no man so
And he him loved / as tendirly ageyn
So wel they loved / as oolde bookys seyn̄
That whanne that oon was deed shortly for to telle
His felawe went / and sowhte him down in helle
But of that story / list me nat to wryte
Duke protheus / loved wel Arcyt
And hadde him knowe / a Thebes yer bi yer
And fynally at request / and prayer
Off protheus wythoute / any raunson
Duke Theseus / him let out of prisoun
Freely to go wher that him list overall
In suche a guyse / as I you tell shall
This was the Forward / pleynly tendyte
Bi twyxe Theseus / and him arcite
That yf so were / that arcite wer Ifownde
Evir in his lyf / by day or nyħt other stownde
In any contre / of duke Theseus
And he were cauht / it was aicorded thus
That wᵗith a swerde / he shuld leese his heed
Ther was noon othir remedye nor reed
But taketh his leve / and homward he him spedde
Lat him be war / his nekke lyth towedde
How gret a sorwe suffreth nowe Arcite
The deth he felyth / thorwħ his herte smyte
He weepyth weyleth / cryeth pitouslye
To she him self he wayteth pryvelye
He seid allas / the day that I was borne
Now is my prisoun / wers than bi forne
Now is me shape eternally to dwelle
Nowht in purgatory / but in helle
Alas / that evir I knewe ꝑpartheus
For ellys hadde I dwellyd wyth Theseus
Feterid in prisoun / evir moo
Than hadde I ben / in blysse and nat in woo
Only the syht of hire / whom that I serve
Thouh I here grace / nevir may disserve
Wolde haue suffisid / I nouh to me
O dere cosyn palamon / ꝙquod he
Thyn is the victorie / of this aventure
Wel blisfuly in prisoun maist thou endure
In prison nay / but in parady

div.l: (base) Wel hath Fortune / yturned thee / the dys
(base) That hast the sighte of hire / and I thabsence
(base) For possible is / syn thow hast hire presence
(base) And art a knyght a worthy and an able
(base) That by som caas / syn Fortune is chaungeable
(base) Thow mayst to thy desir / som tyme atteyne
(base) But I / that am exiled and bareyne
(base) Of alle grace / and in so greet despeyr
(base) That ther nys Erthe / water / fyr / ne Eyr
(base) Ne creature / that of hem maked is
(base) That may me helpe / or do confort in this
(base) Wel oghte I sterue / in wanhope / and distresse
(base) Farwel my lyf / my lust and my gladnesse
(base) ¶ Allas / why pleynen folk so / in cōmmune
(base) On purueiance of god / or of Fortune
(base) That yeueth hem ful ofte / in many a gyse
(base) Wel bettre / than they kan hem self deuyse
(base) ¶ Som man desireth / for to haue richesse
(base) That cause is ofte / of his moerdre / or gret siknesse
(base) And som man wolde / out of his prison fayn
(base) That in his hous / is of his meynee slayn
(base) Infinite harmes / been in this matere
(base) We woot nat what thyng that we prayen heere
(base) We fare as he / that dronke is as a Mous
(base) A dronke man woot wel / he hath an hous

(base) And to a dronke man / . the wey is slider
(base) And certes / in this world / so faren we
(base) We seken faste / after felicitee
(base) But we goon wrong ful ofte trewely
(base) Thus may we seyn alle / and nameliche I
(base) That wende / and hadde a greet opinioun
(base) That if I myghte / scapen fro prisoun
(base) Thanne hadde I been in ioye / and parfit heele
(base) Ther now / I am exiled fro my wele
(base) Syn that / I may nat seen yow Emelie

div.l: (base) I nam but deed / ther nys no remedie
(base) ¶ Vpon that oother syde Palamon
(base) Whan that he wiste / Arcite was agon
(base) Swich sorwe he maketh / that the grete tour
(base) Resowneth / of his yowlyng and clamour
(base) The pure fettres / of his shynes grete
(base) Were / of his bittre salte teeris wete
(base) Allas quod he / Arcita cosyn myn
(base) Of al oure stryf / god woot the fruyt is thyn
(base) Thow walkest now / in Thebes at thy large
(base) And of my wo / thow yeuest litel charge
(base) Thow mayst syn thou hast wisdom / and manhede
(base) Assemblen / al the folk of oure kynrede
(base) And make a werre / so sharp / on this Citee
(base) That by som auenture / or som tretee
(base) Thow mayst haue hire / to lady and to wyf
(base) For whom / that I moste nedes lese my lyf
(base) For as by wey / of possibilitee
(base) Sith thow art at thy large / of prisoun free
(base) And art a lord / greet is thyn auantage
(base) Moore than is myn / that sterue here in a cage
(base) For I moot wepe / and waille whil I lyue
(base) With al the wo / that prison may me yeue
(base) And eek wtith peyne / that loue me yeueth also
(base) That doubleth / al my torment and my wo
(base) Ther with / the fyr of Ialousie vp sterte
(base) With Inne his brest and hente hym by the herte
(base) So woodly / that he lyk was to byholde
(base) The Boxtree / or the Asshen dede / and colde
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he / o crewel goddes / that gouerne
(base) This world / with byndyng of youre word eterne
(base) And writen / in the table of Atthamaūnt
(base) Youre parlement . and youre eterne graūnt

div.l: (base) For slayn is man / right as another beest
(base) And dwelleth eek in prison and arrest
(base) And hath siknesse / and greet aduersitee
(base) And ofte tymes / giltlees pardee
(base) ¶ What gouernance / is in this prescience
(base) That giltlees / tormenteth Innocence
(base) And yet encreeceth this / al my penance
(base) That man is bounden / to his obseruance
(base) For goddes sake / to letten of his wille
(base) Ther as a beest may al his lust fulfille
(base) And whan a beest is deed / it hath no peyne
(base) But man after his deeth / moot wepe and pleyne
(base) Thogh in this world / he haue care and wo
(base) Withouten doute / it moot stonden so
(base) The answere of this / lete I to diuynys
(base) But wel I woot that in this world / greet pyne is
(base) ¶ Allas / I se a serpent or a theef /
(base) That many a trewe man / hath doon mescheef
(base) Goon at his large / and where hym lust may turne

(base) ¶ Now wol I stynte / of Palamon alite

(base) ¶ The Somer / and the nyghtes longe
(base) Encreecen / double wise / the peynes stronge
(base) Bothe of the louere / and the prisoner

(base) ¶ What sholde I al day / of his wo endite

div.l: (base) ¶ Now wol I turne / to Arcite ageyn

(base) Woltow werreyen / Thebes the Citee

(base) The blood roial / of Cadme and Amphioun

div.l: (base) ¶ Thanne is it wisdom / as it thynketh me

(base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame

(base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour

(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel

(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye

(base) And er we / departen from this place

WHan that the knyht / had thus the tale tolde
In al the route / nas ther yong ne olde
That he ne seide / it was a noble storye
And worthy to be drawe / in memorye
And namely / the gentyls euerychone
Our oost tho louh / and swor so mot I gone
This goth ryht well / vnbokeled is the male
Let se nowe / who shall tellyn a nothir tale
For truly the game / is wel bigonne
Nowe tellyth ye sir Monke / if that ye konne
Somwhat to qwyt wyth / the knyhtys tale
The myller / that for dronkyn was all pale
So that vnethe / vp on his hors he sat
He nolde avale / nothir hood ne hat
Ne abide no man / for his curtesye
But in pilatis vois / he gan to cry
And swor by armys / and bi blood and bonys
I can a noble tale / for the nonys
Wyth whiche / I wil now quyte the knyhtys tale
Our ost sawe / that he dronken was at ale
And seyde abide Robyn / my dere brothir
Som betir man / shal tellyn vs first a nothir
A bid / ⁊ let vs werkyn thryftely
Bi godis soule ꝙquod he / that wol nat I
For I wol speke or els / go my wey
Our oost answerd / telle on a devylwey
Thou art a fool / thi wit is ovir come
Nowe herkenyth / ꝙquod the Miller al and some
But first I make / a protestacou
That I am dronke / I knowe wel be my soun
And therfor / if y myspeke or seye
Wyte it thale of Southwerk / I you prey
For I wol telle / a legende and a lyf
Both of a Carpenter / and his wyf
Howe that a Clerk / hath set the wrytes cappe
The Reeve answerd / and seid stynt thi clappe
Lat be thi lewde / dronkyn harlotrye
It is a synne / and eek a gret folye
To appeyryn any man / or him diffame
And eek to bryng wyvys / in ille name
Thou maist I now / of othir thyngꝭes seyn
This dronkyn Myller spak ful sone ageyn
And seyde / leeve brothir Oswolde
Who hath no wyf / is no Cokewolde
But I sey nat therfor / that thou ar oon
Ther ben ful good wyvys / many oon
And evir a thousand a yens oon badde
That knowyst thou wel thy self / but if thou be madde
But art thou angry / wyth my tale nowe
I haue a wyf ꝑperde / as wel as thou
Yit nolde I nat / for thoxen in my plowh
Take vp on me / more than I nouh
As demyng of my self / that I wer oon
I wolde beleve wel / that I am noon
An husbande / shal nat ben Inquesytyf
Of goddis pryuyte / ne of his wyf
So that he fynde / goddis foisou ther
Of the remnant / nedith nat enquer
What shulde I sey / but this proud Myller
He nolde his wordys / for no man forbere
But tolde his cherlys tale in his maner
Me thynkyth I shal rehersyn it her
And therfor / euery gentil wyht I preye
For goddis love / deeme nat that I seye
Of ille entent / for I mote reherse
Here ta / al be they bettꝰer or werse
Of ell falsen / som of my mateer
And therfor / who so list it nat to her
Turne ovir the lef / and chese a nothir tale
For he shal fynde I nouhe / both grete and smale
Of storial thynk that toucheth gentilnesse
And eek moralite / and holynesse
Blameth nat me / if that ye chese a mys
The myller is a Cherl / ye knowe wel this
So was the Reve / and othir many moo
And harlotrye / they tolden both two
Avyseth you / and puttith me out of blame
And eek men shul nat make ernest of game
WHilom ther was dwellyng / at Oxynforde
A ryche gnof / that gestis heeld to borde
And of his craft / he was a a Carpenter
And wtith him ther was dwellyng / a pore scoler
Had lerned art / but al his fantasye
Was turned / for to lernyn / astrologie
And cowde a certeyn of conclusions
To deeme / bi interrogaciouns
If that men axid him / in certeyn hourys
Whanne that men shulde haue drouht / or ellys shourys
Or if men axedyn him / what shold bifalle
Of euꝰery thyng / y may nat rekyn alle
This Clerk / was clepid / hende Nicholas
Of derne love he covde / and of salas
And therto he was ful slyh and ful piriue
And lyke a Mayde / meke for to se
A Chambre had he in that hostelrye
A lone wtith out / any companye
Ful feetysly / Dyht wtith herbys soote
As he him self / as swete as is the roote
Of lycorys / or any Setewale
His almagest / and bookis greete and smale
His astrelabre / longyng for his art
His Augrym stonys / lyeng fair apart
On shelvis cowched / at his bedis hede
His presse coverid / wtith a foldyng rede
And al above / ther lay a gay satrye
On whiche he made / on nyhtys melodye
So sweetly / that al the Chambir rong
And Angelus ad viirgine / he song
And aftir that / he song the kynge note
Ful oftyn blissed was / his mery throt
And thus this swete clerke his tyme he spente
Aftir his frendis fyndyng / and his rent
This Carpenter / hadde weddid / a newe wyf
Whiche that he loved / mor than his lyf
Of ayhtene yer / this wōmman was of age
Gelous he was / and helde hir narowe in cage
For she was wylde / and yong and he was olde
And deemyd hym self / be lyk a Cokwolde
He knew nat Catou / for his wyt was rewde
That bad men sholde wedde her similitude
Men shuldyn wedden aftir her astat
For youth and olde / ben often at bate
But sythen he was brouht / in to the snare
He must endure / as othir folk his care
Fair was this yong wyf / and therwythal
As any wesyl hir body gentyl and smal
A seynt she weryd / barrid al of sylk
A barmecloth eek / as whit as any mylk
Vppon his leendys / ful of many a goore
Whit was hir smok / and browdid al by fore
And eeke be hynde / on hir coler abowte
Of cole blak sylke wtiththynne / and eke wtithoute
The tapis / of hir whit voluper
Were of the same / sevt of hir coler
Hir filet brode / of silke I set ful hye
And sikyrly she hadde / a lycorous eye
Ful smale plukked / wer hir browis two
And tho wer bent / and blak as is a slo
She was more blisful / vn to se
Then is the new per Ienote tre
And softer / than the wol is of a wedir
And bi hir girdyl / heng a purs of lethir
Tasseled wyth sylke / and perled wyth latoūn
In al this worlde / to sekyn vp and doun
Ther nys noon so wyse / that covde thenche
So gay a popelote / ne so gay a wenche
For bryhter is the shynyng of her hewe
Thanne in the tour / the noble forged newe
But of hir song / it was as lowde and erne
As any swalowe / sittyng on a berne
Therto she covde skyppe / and game
As any kyde or calf / folwyng his dame
Hir mouth was swete / as braket or the methe
Or hoorde of appelys / layde in hey or hethe
Wynsyng she was / as is a Ioly colt
Long as a mast / and vpryht as a bolt
A brooche she bar / vp on hir love coleer
And brood as is the boos / of a bokeler
Hir shois wer lacid / on hir leggys hie
She was a prymeros a pyggys nye
For any lorde / haue liggyng in hir bed
Or yet for any good yoman / for to wed
Now sire / and eft sire / so fel the caas
That on a day this heende Nicholas
Fyl wtith this yong wyf / rage and pleye
Whil that hir husbonde / was at Oseneye
As clerkys ben ful sotyl / and ful queynte
And pryvely he cauht hir / by the queynte
And seid y wys / but I haue my wylle
For derne love of the / lemman I spille
And heelde hir fast / by the haunche bonys
And seide lemman / love me al attonys
Or I wol deye / also god me save
And she sprang out / as doth a colt in trave
And wyth hir hed / she wrythed faste a wey
And seid y wol nat kysse the bi my fey
Whi lat be ꝙquod she / lat be Nycolas
Or I wol crye out herow / and allas
Dowey your handys / for your curtesye
This Nicholas / mercy gan to crye
And spak so faire / and profred him so fast
That she / hir love him graunted at the laste
And swor hir oth / bi seynt Thomas of kent
That she wolde be / at his cōmmaundement
Whanne that she may / hir leyser wel aspye
Myn husbond / is so ful of Ielousye
That but if ye wayten wel / and be piriue
I wot ryhtwel / I nam but ded ꝙquod she
Ye must be ryht derne in this cas
Therof ne care ye nat ꝙquod Nicholas
A Clerk hadde lethirly beset his while
But if he covde / a carpenter bigile
And thus they been / accordid and I sworne
To wayte a tyme as I haue tolde biforne
Whanne Nicholas haddon thus euꝰerydel
And thakkid hir / abowten / the leendys wel
He kyste hir swete / and takyth hir sawtrye
And pleyth faste / and maad melodye
Than fel it thus / that to the paryh Chirche
Crystis owne werkys / for to werche
This good wyf went / on an halyday
Hir forhed shon / as bryht as any day
So was it waisshe / whan she leet hir werk
Now ther was of that Cherche / a paryssh Clerk
The whiche was I Clepid Absolon
Crul was his heer / and as the golde it shoon
And / strowded as a fanne / large and brod
Ful streht and evene lay his Ioly shod
His rode was reede / his eyen grey as goos
Wyth powl wyndowe / corven / on his shoos
In hoosis reed / he went fetysly

But soth play / quade spel / the flemmyng saith
And therfor / bailif bi thi fayth
Be thou nat wroth / er we departen heer
Thouh that my tale / be of an hosteler
But natheles / y wol nat telle it yit
But yer we part / y wys thou shalt be quyt
And therwythall / he louh and maad good chere
And seid his tale / as ye shall aftir heer
Explicit prologus coqui ·
⁊et Incipit Fabula euisdem.
A Preȳntes whilom / dwelt in our Cyte
And of a craft / of vitelers was he
Gailard he was / as goldfynche in the shawe
Browne as a bery / a propre short felawe
Wyth lokkes blake / kempt ful fetysly
Daunce he cowd / so wel and Iolyly
That he was cleped perkyn̄ / the revelour
He was as ful of love / and paramour
As is the hyve / ful of hony swete
Wel was the wenche / wyth him myht meete
At euery bridale / wolde he syng and hoppe
He loved bettir the taverne / than the shoppe
For whanne ther any revel / was in chepe
Out of the shoppe / thedir wolde he lepe
Tyl that he hadde / al the syht y seyn̄
And daunced wel / he wold nat com̄ a geyn̄
And gadred him a meny / of hir sort
To hoppe and syng / and make such disport
And ther the settyn / stevene / for to mete
To pleyn̄ at the dys / in suche a streete
For in towne / nas ther no preyntis
That fairer cowd cast a peyre of dys
Than̄ perkyn̄ covde / and ther to he was fre
Of his dispence / in place of pryuiyte
That fond his mast̉er / wel in his chaffar͗e
Ful oftyn tyme / he fond his box ful bar͗e
For sykirly / a prentys and a reuelour
That haunteth dys / ryot or paramour
His maister / shal it in his shoppe abeye
Al haue he no part / of the menstralsye
For theft and ryot / the ben cōnuertible
Al konne he pley / on gyterne or ribible
Revel and trewth / as yn a low degre
Thei ben ful roth alday / as men may se
This Ioly prentys / wyth his maist̉er bood
Tyl he wer nyh / out of his prentys hood
Al wer he snybbed / both erly / and late
And somtyme / lad wyth revel to newgate
But at the last / his maist̉er / hym bithouht
Vppon̄ a day / whanne he his papir souht
Of a prouerble / that seyth the same word
Wel bettir is a rotyn̄ apill out of hord
Thanne it rote / al the remenaunt
So faryth it / a ryetous servaunt
It is wel lasse harme / to late hin pace
Than̄ he shende al ʆseruᵃauntꝭes / in the place
Therfor his maist̉er / yaf him acquytaunce
And bad hym go wyth sorowe and myschaunce
And thus this Ioly prentys / hadde his leve
Now late him ryot / al nyht or bileve
And ther is no theef / wythouten a lowke
What helpyth him / to wasten / and to soupe
Of that he bribe can / or borwe may
A noon he sente his bed / and his array
Vn to a comper / of his owne sort
That loved dys / revel and disport
And hadde a wyf / that helde for contynaunce
A shoppe and swyvyng / for her sustinaunce

Owr hoost saw wel / that the bryht sonne
The ark / of his artificiall day hath ronne
The foorte part / of half an howr and more
And thouh he were nat deepe / expert in lore
He wyst it was / the eyht and twenty day
Of averyll / that is messyngeer to may
And sawe wel the shadowe / of eủery tree
Was as in lengthe / the same quantyt

(base) As wel as Euclyde or Protholomee
(base) Touchynge the cherl they seyde subtiltee
(base) And hy wit made hym speke as he spak
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) He nys no fool ne no demonyak
(base) And Iankyn hath ywonne a newe gowne
(base) My tale is doon we been almoost at towne
(base) Hic finita fabula Summonitoris

Explicit fabula Apparitoris
⁊ Incipit prologus clerici Oxon
Sire clerk of Oxenforde / our host saide
Ye ryde as styll / and coy as doth a maide
Wer new spoused / sittyng at boorde
This day ne harde y / of your tong a Woorde
I trowe ye studye / about som saphyme
But Salamon seith all thing hath tyme
Ffor goddis sake / as beth of bettir cheer
It is no tyme / for to studie her
Telle vs som mery tale bi your fay
Ffor what man is entred / in to play
He nedis must / vnto play assent
But prechith nat as ffreris / doon in lent
To make vs for our olde synnes weepe
Ne that your tale / make vs nat to slepeslpeslepe
Telle vs som mery thing / of aventures
Your tꝰermes your colours / and your figures
Keepe hem in stoor / til so be ye endyte
Hyh still / as whanne that men to kynges wryte
Speketh so playn at this tyme we you pray
That we may vndirstonde / what ye say
This worthi clerk / benygnely answerde
Hoost qd he / y am vndir your yerde
Ye han of vs as nowe / the governaunce
And therfor / wol y do yon obeysaunce
As fer as reson axeth / hardely
I woll telle a tale / which that I
Lerned at padowe / of a worthi Clerk
As preeveth bi his worthis / and his werk
He is now ded and nayled in his chest
I prray to god / so yeve his soule rest
Ffraunces patrark / the laureat poete
Hiht this clerk / whos retorik swete
Enlumened all ytalye / of poetrye
As lynyan dide / of philosophie
Or lawe othir / othir art particuler
But deth that wol nat suffre vs / dwelle her
But as it wer / a twynklyng of an eye
Hem both hath slayn / and all shull we deye
But forth to telle / of this worthi man
That tauht me this tale / as y began
I sey that first / he wyth hih style enditeth
Or he the body / of his tale wryteth
A ꝓprohemiye / in the whiche decerued he
Pemond and of saluces / the contre
And speketh of a peyn / the hille hih
That ben the bondes / of westlumbardye
And of mount / vesulus in special.
Wher as the poo / out of a well smal
Takyth his first spryngyng / and his sowris
That estwarde enir creseth ni his cowris
To emele warde / to ferar and venyse
The whiche a long thyng it wer to devyse
And trewly as to my Iugement
Me thynketh it a thing imꝑpertynent
Sauf that he wolde / conveye his mater
But this is the tale / which ye may her

Explicit prologus clerici Oxon
⁊ incipit fabula eiusdem
Ther is at the west side of ytaylye
Doon at the root / of vesulus the colde
A lusty pleyn habundaunt / of vitayle
Wher many a tour and ton thou maist beholde
That ffounded wer / in tyme of ffadris olde
And many a nothir / dilectable siht
And saluce / that noble contre hyht.
A marqwys whilom / lord was of that londe
As were his worthi eldres / heer to fore
And obeysaunt ay redy to his honde
Wer all his liges / both lasse and more
Thus in delit he lyued / and hath don yore
Beloued and drad / thoruh fauour of fortune
Both of his lordis / and his comvne
Therwith he was to speke as of lynage
The gentilest / iborn of lumbardye
A fair persone / and yong and strong of age
And ful of honour and of curtesye
Discreet inouh his contre for to guye
Sauf in som thingis / that he was to blame
And Walteer / was that yong lordis name
I blame him thus / that he considred nouht
In tyme comyng / What myht hum betyd
But on his lust / present was al his thouht
And for to hunt and hauke / on euy syde.
Well nye all othir cures / let he slyde
And eek he nolde / that was wost of all
Wedde no wyf / for auht that may befall
Only that poynt / his poeple bar so sor
That flotmell on a day / to him they went
And oon of hem / that wysest was of lor
Or ellis that the lorde wolde best to assent.
That he shulde telle him / what his poeple ment
Or ellis cowde he shewe / wel such mateer
He to the marquys seid / as ye shul her
O noble marquys / your humanyte
Assureth vs / and yevith vs hardynesse
As oft as tyme is / of necessitee
That we to yow may telle / our hevynesse
Accepteth now lorde of your gentylnesse
That we wyth pitous hert / to you pleyne
And lat youre erys / nat my voys disdeyne
Al haue I nat to done in this mater
Mor thanne a nothir man / hath in this place
Yet for asmuche / as ye my lorde so der
Han alwey shewed me / fauour and grace
I dar the bettir / aske of you a space
Of audience / to shewe our requeste
And ye my lorde / to don ryht as ye list
Ffor certis lorde / so well as lyketh you
And all your werkys / and evir hath don that wee
Ne cowde nat our self deuysen howe
We myhten lyve / in mor felycytee
Sauf oon thing lorde / if it your will be
That for to be a wedded man/ if you leste
Than wer your poeple / in souereyn hertis rest
Boweth your necke / vndir that blisful yok
Of soueraynte / and nat of seruyse
Whiche that men clepe / speusayle or wedlok
And thinketh lorde / among your thouhtys wyse
Howe that our days passe / in sondry wyse
Ffor thouh we slepe or wake / or rome or ryde
Ay fleeth the tyme / it wolle no man abide
And thouh your grene youth floure as yete
In creepeth age / alwey as still as stone
And deth manaceth / euery age and smyt
In eche estaat / for ther escapeth non
And also certeyn / as we knowen echoon
That we shull dey / as vncerteyn we alle
Ben of that day / that deth shall on vs falle
Accepteth thanne / of vs the trewe entent
That yit nevir refused / your heste
And we woll lorde / yf ye woll assent
Chese you a wyf / in short tyme at leste
Born of the gentiles / and of the meste
Of all this londe / so that it auht seeme
Honour to god / and yow as we kan deme
Delyver vs out / of all this besy drede
And take a wyf for hih geddis sake
Ffor if it so befall / as god forbede
That thoruh your deth / your lynage shulde slake
And that a straunge successour / shulde take
Your heritage o woo wer vs on lyve
Wherfor we pray you / hastely to wyve
Her meke prayer / and her pitous cher
Made the marquys hert / to han pite
Ye wolden qd he / myn owne poeple der
To that y never thouht / erst streyne me
I me reioysed of my liberte
That seelde tyme is founde in maryage
Ther y was ffree / y must be in ꝸseruage
But natheles / y se your trewe entente
And trust vpon your wyt / and haue don ay
Wherfor of my ffre wyll / y w[]w will assent
To wedde me / as sone as evyr y may
But ther as ye han ꝓprofered me to day
To chese me a wyf / y yow relese
That choys / and paray you of that ꝓprofer cese
Ffor god it wot that children often ben
Vnlyk her worthi eldres hem bifore
Bonte cometh al of god / nat of the stren
Of whiche they ben engendred and y bore
I trust in goddis bonte / and therfor
My maryage / and my estaat / and rest
I him betake / he may doon. as hym lyst
Lat me alone / in chesyng of my wyf
That charge vppon my bak / I wol endur
But y yow paray and charge / vpon your lyf
That / that wyf I me take / ye me ensure
To worship hir / whil that hir lyf may dur
In word ni werke / both heer and eurerywheer
As she an emꝑperoures douhter wer
And ferthirmor / this shul ye swer that ye
Ageyn my choys / shul nat grucche ne stryve
For sith y shall for go my liberte
At your request / as so evir mot y thryve
Ther as myn hert is set / ther wol y wyve
And but ye woll assent / in such maneer
I pray you speketh no mor of this mater
With herty wyll / they sworen and assenten
To all thing / and seyde no wiht nay.
Besekyng him of grace / er that they wenten
That he wolde graunten hem a certeyn day
Of his spousayle / as sone as evir he may
Ffor yit alwey / the poeple / somwhat dredde
Lest that this marquys / no wyf wolde wedde
He graunted hem a day suche as hym lest
On whiche he wolde he wolde be weddid sikyrly
And seid he did / as this / at her request
And they wyth humble entent / ful buxumly
Kneled vppon hir kneis / ful reuerently
Him thankyng all / and thus thei han an ende
Of her entent / and hom ageyn they wende
And her vppon / he to his officers
Comaundeth / for the fest to purvey
And to his pryvy knyhtes / and sqwyers
Suche charg yaf / as him lest on hem to ley
And they to his cōmmaundement / obey
And ech of hem / doth all his dylygence
To don on the fest / reverence
Nat fevr from thilke paleys honorable
Wher as the marquys / shoope his maryage
Ther stood a thorpe / of sihte dilectable
In whiche that por folk / of that village
Hadden her bestis / and her herbergage
And of her labour / took her sustinaunce
Aftir therthe / yaf hem habundaunce
Among thees por folke / ther dwelt a man
Whuhe that was holden / poorest of hem all
But hih god / som tyme sende kan
His grace / in to an oxis stalle
Ianicula / men of that thorp him calle
A douhter he hadde / fair y nouh to syht
And Grysildys / this yong maydyn hiht
But for to speke of vertuous beaute
Than was she oon / the fayrest vndir sonne
Fful poorely fostred / vp was she
No likorous lust / was in her hert ronne
Wol ofter of the welle / thanne of the tonne
She Dranke / and for she wolde vertu plese
She knewe wel labour but noon ydil ese
But thouh this mayden tendir was of age
Yit in the brest / of hir vyrgynyte
Ther was enclosed rype and sad corage
And in grete reuerence / and in charyte
Hir olde pore ffadir / fusteyued she
A ffewe sheepe / spynnyng on felde she kepte
She wolde nat ben ydil / til she slepte
And whan she homwarde cam she wolde bryng
Wortys or othir herbes / tymes ofte
The whiche she shrede / and seth for hir lyvyng
And made hir bed / ful harde / and nothing softe
So she kept her fadirs lyf a lofte
Wyth euery obeysaunce and diligence
That childe may doo / to the fadres Reuerence
Vpon Grisilde / that poor creature
Fful oft sithes / the marquys set his ye
As he on huntyng Roode paraventure
And whan it fell / that he myht hir espie
He nat wyth wanton looke of folye
His eye cast on hir / but in sad wyse
And on hir cheer / he wolde him oft avyse
Comendyng in his hert hir wommanhede
Ffor hir vertue / passyng any wyht
Of so yong age as weel in cheer as in deede
For thouh the poeple / han no gret insyht
In vertue he considreth ful ryht
Hir bonte and disposed that he wolde
Wedde hir wonly / yf evir he wedde sholde
The day of weddyng cam but no wiht can
Telle what womman / it sholde be
For /whiche mervayle / wondred many a man
And sei whan they wer in pryvyte
Wol nat our lorde / yit leue his vanytee
Wol he nat wedde / allas allas the while
Why wol he thus / him self and vs bigile
But natheles / this marquys hath don make
Of gemmys set in golde / and in asure
Brochis and rynges / for grysyldes sake
And of hir clothyng / toke he the mesure
Of a mayden / lyk to hir mesure
And eke of othir ornamentys alle
That vnto suche / a weddyng shulde falle
The tyme of vnderne / and of the same day
Approched that this weddyng shulde be
And all the paleys / put was in array
Bothe halle and chaumbres / ech in his degree
Houses of offyce / stuffed wyth plente
The maist thou see / deyntevous vytayle
That may be founde / as fer as lasteth ytayle
This royall marquys / rychely arrayde
Lordis and ladyes / in his companye
The whiche vnto fest / were prayde
And of his retynue / the chyvalrys
Wyth many a sound / of sondry melodye
Vnto the vyllage / of the whiche y tolde
In this array. / the ryht wey they holde
Grysylde of this / god wot ful Innocent
That for hir shape was / all this array.
To fecche watyr / at a well is went
And cometh hom / as sone as she may.
Ffor well she herde sey / that ille day
That marquys shulde wedde / and yf she myht
She wolde fayn / aseyn som of that siht
She thouht / y woll wyth othir maydens stond
That be my felaws / in our dore and see
The marqussesse / and therfor wol y fonde
To don at hom / as soone as it may be/
The labour the whiche / that longeth to me
And thanne y may / at leyser hir beholde
If she this wey / vnto the castell holde
And as she wolde / ouer hir throisshold goon
The marquys cam / and gan hir for to calle
And she set don hir watir pot a noon
Beside the throissholde / in an oxes stalle
And doon vppon hir kneis she gan falle
And with sadde contynaunce / kneelith stille
Till she hadde herde / what was the lordis wylle
This thohtfull marquys / spak vnto the mayde
Fful sobirly and said / in this maneer
Wher is your ffadir / Grysilde he saide
And she wyth Reuence / in huble cheere
Answerde lorde / he is al reedy heere
And in she goth / wythout lenger let
And to the marquys / she hir ffadir fet
He by the honde / than toke this olde man
And sey thus / whan he him hadde aside
Ianicale / y neithir may ne can
Lenger the plesaunce / of myn hert hide
If that thou vouchesaff what so betyde
Thi douhter wol y take / er that y weende
As for my wyf / in to my lyves eende
Thow lovest me / I wot it wel certeyn
Thou art my feithful / lyge man y bor
And all that lyketh me / I dar wel seyn
It liketh the / and specyally therfor
Telle me that poynt / as y haue seid bifor
Yf that thow wolt / vnto that purpos drawe
To take me as for thi sonne in lawe
The sodeyn caas / the man astoneth so
That red he wex abaisshed / and all quakyng
He stood / and vneth seid he wordes mo
But only thus / lord my[]my qd he my willyng
Is as we wol a yens youre lykyng/
Y wol nothing / ye be my lorde so dere
Riht as yow lyst / governe this mateer
Yet wol I qd this marquys sothly.
That in thi chaumbr / I and thou and she
Haue a collacion / and wostou why
For I woll axe / if it hir wyl be
To be my wyf / and rewled aftir me
And all this / shalle don / in thi presence
I wol nat speke / out of thyn audience
And in her chaumbr / whil they wer abowte
Her tretys / whiche as ye shall aftir her
The poeple cam / vnto the hous withoute
And wondred hem / in how honest maneer
And tentyfly / she kept hir fadir der
But vttirly Grisilde / wondir myht
Ffor nevir er ne sauh she / suche a sight
No wondir is / thouh she wer astoned
To see so gret a gest / comyn in that place
She nevir was / to suiche gestis woned
Ffor whiche she loked / wtith ful pale face
But shortly forth / this mater for to chace
Thes arn the wordis / that this marquys seyde
To this benygne / feithful verray maide
Grysylde he seyde / ye shul wel vndirstonde
It lyketh to your fadir and me
That y on wedde / and eek it may so stonde
As y suppose / ye wol that it so be
But these demandes / axe y furst qd he
That sith it shalbe don / in hasty wyse
Wol ye assent / or ellis you avyse.
I sey this be ye redy with good herte
To all my lust / and that y frely may
As me best thinketh / do doon you lawhe or smert
And ye nevir to grucche it / nyht ne day
And eek whan y sey ya / ne sey ye nat nay
Neythir by worde / ne frownyng contynaunce
Swer this / and heer I swer our alyaunce
Wondryng vppon this worde quakyng for drede
She sayd lord vndigne and vnworthy
Am y to that ylke honour / that ye me beede
But as ye wol your self / ryht so wol y
And heer y swere / that nevir wyllyngly
In werke ne thouht I nel yow disobeye
For to be ded / thouh me wer leth to deye
This is y nouh Grysylde myn qd he
And forth he goth wyth a sobre cheer
Out at the door / and aftir / than cam she
And to the poeple seid in this maneer
This is my wyf qd he / that standeth heere
Honoureth hir / and loveth hir I you pray
Who so me loveth / ther is no more to say
And for nothing / of hir olde gere
She shulde bryng in to his hous / he bad
That womme shulde dispoyle hir ryht ther
Of whiche thes ladyes / wer nothing glad
To handle hir clothis / wheryn she was lad
But natheles / this mayden bryht of hewe
Fro foot to hed / they clothid han newe
Hir herys han they kempt that lay vntrussed
Ful rudly / and with hir fyngres smale
A corowne on hir hed / they hane y dressed
And set hir ful nowches / gret and smale
Of hir array / what shulde y make a tale
Vnethe poeple hir knewe / for hir fairnesse
Whan she translumed was in swich richesse
This marquys hath hir spoused / wyth a ryng
Brouht for the same cause / and than hir sette
Vpon an hors snow whit / and wel anblyng
And to his paleys / or he lenger let
With ioyful poeple / that hir ledde and mette
Conveyed hir / and thus the day they spende
In revel til the sonne gan descende
And shortly forth / this tale for to chase
I sey that to this newe marquysesse
God hath such favour / her sent of his garace
That it me semeth / nat by lyknesse
That she was born / and fed in rudnesse
As in a cote / or in an oxes stalle
But norshed / in an Emꝑperoures halle
To euery wiht / she waxen is so deere
And worshipfull / that folke ther she was bor
And from hir birthe / knew hir yeer by yeer
Vneth trowed they / but han swor
That to Ianycle / of the whiche y spak of bifor
She douhtir was / for as bi coniectur
Him thouht she was / a nothir creatur
Ffor thouh that evir verteous was she
She was encresed in such excellence
Of thewys good / y sed in hih bounte
And so discret and fayr of eloquence
So benygne and digne of Reuerence
And cowde so the poeple hertis enbrace
That eche her loveth / that loketh in hir face
Nat only of Saluces / in the ton
Publisshed was / the beaute of hir name
But eek beside / in many a region
Yf oon seid wel / anothir seid the same
So spredeth of hir hih bounte the fame
That men and wommen / as wel yong as olde
Goon to saluce / hir to beholde
This Walteer lowhly nay but royally
Wedded with fortunat / honest
In goddis pes / lyveth ful esily
At hom and outwarde grace y nouh had he
And for he sauh / that vndir lowe degre
Was oft vertue hid / the poeple him hilde
A prudent man / and that is seyn ful selde
Nat oonly this Grysilde / thoruh hir wit
Kowde al the fet of homlynesse
But eek / whanne the caas required it
The comon profyt / kowde she redresse
Ther nas discorde / rancor ne heuynesse
In al that lande / that she ne cowde appese
And wisely bryng / hem all in hertys ese
Thouh that hir housbonde / absent wer anon
If gentil men / or othir / of hir contre
Wer wroth / she wolde bryng hem at on
So wyse and rype wordys / hadde she
And Iugementys / of so gret equyte
That she from hevene / y sent was as men wend
Poeple to saue / and euy thyng tamende
Nat long tyme aftir / this Grysylde
Was wedded / she a douhter hath y bor
Al hadde she levir / haue born a knave chylde
Glad was the marquys / and the folk therfor
Ffor thouh amayden childe / come bifor
She may vnto a knave childe atteyne
By lyklyhed / sith she is nat bareyne
Ther fell / as it befalleth tymes mo
Whan this childe / had souked but a throwe
This marquys / in his hert longeth so/
To tempte his wyf / hir sadnesse for to knowe
That he myht / out of his herte/throwe
This mervelows desir / his wyf to assaye
Nedeles god wot / he thouht hir taffraye
Nee hadde assayed hir / ynouh bifor
And fond hir evir good / what nedid it
Hir for to tempte / and alwey mor and mor
But as forme / y sey that evil it sit
Thouh som men preyse / that for a sotyl soll[]soll wit
To assay a wyf / whan it is no nede
And putt hir in anguyssh / and in drede
Ffor whiche this marquys wrouht in this maneer
He cam a nyht allone / ther she lay
Wyth stene face / and wtith drouble cheer
And said this / Grysilde qd he / that day
That y yon took/ out of your por array
And put you in estat / of hih noblesse
Ye han it nat for gete / as y gesse
I sey Grysylde / this present dignyte
In whiche y haue put you / as y trowe
Maketh you nat foryetefull for to be
That y you tookin poore estaat ful lowe
For any wele / ye mote yorurself knowe
Tak hed of eurery worde that []ysup you sey
Ther is no wigt / that herith but we twey
Ye wot your self / wel / how that ye com her
In to this castell / that is nat long ago
And thouh to me ye bith / both leve and der
Vnto my gentiles / ye be nothing so
Thei sey to hem / it is gret shame and wo
For to be soget / and ben in servage
To you that born arn / of a smal lynage
And manely sith thi dowhtir was y bore
These wordis han they spoke doutles
But y desire / as y haue don bifor
To lede my lyf / with hem in rest and pes
I may nat in this caas / be recheles
I mot do with the douhtir / for the best
Nat as y wolde / but as my gentiles lest
And god it wot / this is ful loth to me
But natheles / withouten your wytyng
I wol nat do / but this wol y qd he
That ye to me assent / as in this thing
Shewe now your pacience / in werkyng
That ye me hiht / and swor / in your vyllage
That day that maked / was our maryage
And whanne she herd this / she nas nat ameved
Neythir in worde / ne in contynaunce
For as it semeth / she was nat aggreved
She said lorde / al lyth/ in your plesaunce
My childe and y / wyth hertely obeysaunce
Be yours all / and ye mowe saue and spylle
Your owne thing / werketh aftir your wylle
Ther may nothyng / so god my soule save
Lykyng to you / that may dislese me /
Ne y desire nothing / for to haue
Ne drede for to lefe / sauf oonly ye
This wyl is in my hert / and ay shalbe
No lenght of tyme / or deth may this deface
Ne chaunge my corage / to anothir place
Glad was this marquys / for hir answeryng
But yit he feyneth / as he were nat so
Al dreery was his cheer / and his lokyng
Whanne that he shulde . out of the chaumbre goo
Sone aftir this / a forlong wey or twoo
He pryvyly hath tolde / al his entent
Vnto a man / and to his wyf him sent
A maneer sergeaunt / was this pryvy man
The whiche he feithfull / often founden hadde
In thinges gret / and eek such folke wel can
Soon execution / on thinges badde
The lorde knew well / that he him loved / and dradde
And whanne this sergeaunt / knew his lordis wylle
In to the chaumbir / he stalketh him ful stille
M adame he seid / ye mote foryeve it me
Thouh y do thing / to whiche y am constreyned
Ye ben so wys / that ful wel knowe ye
That lordis hestis / mou nat ben I feyned
They mow welbe / bewayled / and compleyned
