That impossible it wer / to replye
Ageyns his choys / that was his fantasie
His freendis sent he to / at his Instaunce
And prayd hem to do / to him that plesaunce
That hastely they wolde to him come
He wolde a bregge her labour and her some
It nedith no more for him to go / nor ryde
He was apoynted ther he wolde abide
Placebo cam al his freēmdys sone left
And altherfirst / he hadde hem al aboone
That noon of hem / noon argumentes make
Ageyne the purpos / that he that y take
Whiche purpos was plesaunt to god said he
And verray grounde of his prosperyte
He saide ther was a mayden in the tou
Whiche of beaute hadde grete renou
Al wer it so she wer of smal degre
Suffiseth him hir youthe and his beaute
Whiche mayde he said he wolde haue to his wyf
To leede in ese and holynesse his lyf
And thanked god / he myht haue hir al
That no wyht his blisse / part shal
And prayde hem al to laboure in this neede
And shapen that he fayle nat to spede
For thanne he saide his spirit was at ese
Ther is ꝙquod he / nothing that may me displese
Sauf oon thing prikketh on my conscience
The whiche y wol reherce in your presence
I haue ꝙquod he heer said yon yore ago
Ther may no man haue / parfit blisses too
This is to seyne in erthe / and eek in heuene
For thouh he kepe him / from the synnes sevene
And eek from euꝰery braunche of thilke tre
Yit is ther so parfit felicite
And so gret ese / and lust in mariage
That evir y am agast now in myn age
That y shal leed nowe / so mery a lyf
So delycat / wyth outen woo and stryf
That y shalhaue myn heuene / in erthe heer
For sith that verray hevene / is bouht so dere
Wyth tribulacou / and with gret penaunce
How shulde y thanne lyve / in suche plesaunce
As al wedded men / doon with her wyfys
Come to the blisse / ther crist eterne a lyve is
This is my dreede / and ye my brethirne tweye
Assoyleth me this questiou / y you praye
Iustinus / which that hateth his folye right
Answerde a noon as riht in his iaperye
And for / he wolde / his long tale abregge
He wolde noon auctorite legge
And seid sire / so ther be noon obstacle
Othir thanne this / god of his myracle
And of his mercy / may so for you werche
Er ye han your ryhtes of holy chirche
Ye may repente of weddid mannys lyf
In whiche ye seyn is neithir woo nor stryf
And ellis god forbed / but ye sent
A wedded man grace / him to repent
Wel oft rather / thanne a sengle man
And therfor sir / the best red y can
Dispeireth you nat / but haueth in memorye
Parauenture / she may / be / your purgatorye
She may be goddis mene / and goddis whippe
Than shal your soule / vnto heue skyppe
Swyfter thanne doth tharwe out of the bowe
I hope to god / heer aftir shul ye knowe
That ther is no grete / felicite
In mariage / ne nevir mor shalbe
That you shal let / of your sauaciou
So that ye vse / that skyl is / and resou
The lustis wyf of your wyf / attempirly
And if ye plese hir / to amerously
And that ye kepe you / eek from othir synne
My tale is doon / for my wit is but thynne
Beth nat agast heerof / my brothir der
But lat vs wade out / of this mateer
The wif of Bathe / if ye haue vndirstonde
Of mariage which we haue on honde
Declared hath / ful wel in litel space
Fareth nowe wel / god haue you in his grace
And with this worde Iustyn and his brothir
Han take her leve / eche of hem of othir
And whanne thei sauh it moost nedis be
Thei wrouht so / be sleiht and by trete
That she / this faire mayde / that Mayus hiht
As hastely as evir / that she myht
Shal wedded be / vnto this Ianuarye
I trowe it wer to long / you for to tarye
If y you telle / of euy scryt and bonde
Bi whiche she was / y feffid in his londe
Or for to rekene / of his freissh array
But fynally / I comen is the day
That to the chirch / both they be went
For to ressayve / both the holy sacrament
Forth cometh the prest / wtith stole about his nekke
And badde hir be lyk / Sara / and rebekke
As in wysdam / and trouth of mariage
And said his holy orisous / as is vsage
And crowcheth hem / and bad god shulde hem blesse
And made al siker y nouh / wyth holynesse
Thus ben they wedded / with solempnyte
And at the feste / sit he / and she
And othir worthi folke / vppon the deys
Al ful of Ioye and blisse / is this paleys
And ful of Instrumentis / and vitaile
The most deyntes / that werne in ytayle
Beforne hem stood / Instrumentes of such sown
That orpheus / ne of thebes amphiou
Made nevir in her lyf / such melodye
At euery cours / thanne cam lewd menstracye
That nevir trembed Ioab / for to her
Ne he Therdomas / half so cleer
At Thebes whanne the care was in dowte
Bachus the wyn / hem shentheth al a bowte
And venus lauheth / vpon euy wiht
For Ianuarye was become / hir knyht
And wolde both assaye / his corage
In liberte / and eek in mariage
And with hir fyrbrond / him hitte abowte
Daunseth bifor / the bryd / al abowte
And certaynly / I dar ryht wel sey this
Imeneus that god of wedding is
Sauh nevir his lif / so mery a wedded man
Holde thou thi pes / thou poete Marcian
That writest vs / that ilke weddyng merye
Of hir philogie / and of him mercury
And of the songes / that the muses song
To smal is thi penne / and eek thi tong
For to descryven / of this mariage
Whanne tendir youth / hadde wedded stoupyng age
Ther is such myrthe / that may nat be writen
Assaieth it your self / than may e wetyn
If that y lye or nat / in this mateer
Mayus that sit / with so benygne cheer
Hir to beholde / it semeth a fayre
Queen hester / loked nevir wtith such an ye
On assuer / so meek a look hath she
I may you nat devise / al hir beaute .
But thus moche of her beaute / tellen I may
That she lyke the bryht morwen of May .
Fulfilled with beaute / and with al plesaunce
This Ianuarye / is ravysshed / in a traunce
At euery tyme / he loketh in hir Face
But in his hert / he gan hir to manace
That he that nyht / in armys wolde hir streyne
Harder tha evir did / parys Eleyne
But natherles / yet hadde he gret pyte
That ilke nyht / offenden most he
And thouht allas / a tendir creature
Now wolde god / she myht wel endure
Al my corage / which is so sharpe and kene
I am agast / she shal it nat susteene
But god forbede / I dede al my myht
Nowe wolde god / it wer waxen nyht
And that the nyht / wolde lasten evir moo
I wolde al thes poeple / wer now ygo
And fynally / he doth al his labour
As he best myht / savyng his honour
To haste hem from the mete in subtil wyse
The tyme cam / that reson was to ryse
And aftir that men daunce / and drynke faste
And spices al aboute the house / they caste
And ful of Ioye and blisse / is euery man
Al but a Squyer / hiht damyan
Whiche carf be for the knyht / many a day
He was so ravisshed / on his lady may
That for verray peyne / he was nyh woode
Al most he sowned / ther as he stoode
So sore hath she / I hurt him wtith hir bronde
As that she bar it / dauncyng in hir honde
And to his bed he went him / hastely
No more at this tyme / of him speke I .
But ther y let him wepe y nouh and pleyne
Tyl freissh may / wol rewen on his peyne
O perlous fire / that in the bedstrawe bredith left
O famylyar foo / that his ꝸseruyse beedeth
O fals traytour / o fals homly hewe
Lyk to thadder / in bosom / sly and vntrue
God shilde vs alle / from your acquyetaunce
O Ianuarye / dronken in plesaunce
In mariage / see how thi Damyan
Thy squyer and thin owne sworne man
Entendith for to doon / the velanye
God graunt the / thyn enemy taspye
For in this worlde / is no wers pestilence
Than homly foo / al day in thi pꝰersence left
Parfourmed hath the sonne / his srk dyurne
No lenger may the bodye / of him soiourne
In the orisaunt / as in that latitude
Ryht with his mantel / that is derke and rude .
Gan to ovirspreed / themysperye aboute
For whiche deꝑperted is / the lusty rowte
For Ianuarie wyth thanke on euꝰery side
Hom to her houses / lusty they ryde
Wher as they doon her thynges as hem lest
And whanne they sawe her tyme / they go to rest
Soone aftir this / this hasty Ianuarye
Wol go to bedde / he wol no lenger tarye
He dryngeth ypocras / clarre and vernage
Of spices hoot / tencresen his corage
And many a letuarye / hath he wol fyne
Suche as the cursede monk / Dan constantyne
Hath wretyn in his book / de coetu
To ete hem al / he was no thing eschewe
And to his pryvy freendis / thus said he
For goddis love / as sone as it may be
Lat voide al this hous / in curteyse wyse
And they han doon ryht / as he wol devyse
Men dronke / and the tables drowen a noon
The bryde was brouht / a bedde as stille as stoon
And whan the bryde / was wtith the preest y blessid
Out of the chaumbr / hath euy wyht dressed
And Ianuarye / hath fast in armys take
Hir faire may / his paradys / his make
He lulleth hir he kysseth hir wo oft
With the boistrous bresteles / of his berd vnsoft
Lyk to the skynne of an houndfissh / sharpe as breere
For he was shaue al newe / in his maneer
He rubbith hir / abouten hir tendir face
And said thus / allas y must trespace
To you my spouse / and you gretly offende
Er tyme come / that y wil downe descende
But natherles / considreth this ꝙquodhe
Ther is no werkeman / what so evir he be
That may both / werke wel and hastely
This wol we doon / at leyser ꝑperfytly
It is no fors / how long that evir we pley
In trew wedlok / cowpled be we twey
And blissed be that yok that we bith Inne
For in thes actꝭes we mou doon no synne
A man may don so synne with his wyf
Ne hurt him self / with his knyf
For we haue leve / to pleye as be lawe
Thus laboured he / til the day gan dawe
And than he taketh a sop / in fyn clarre
And vpryht in his bed / than sit he
And aftir that / he song / wol lowd and cler
And kyst his wyf / and made wanton cheer
He was as coltyssh / ful of ragerye
And ful of Iargon / as a flecked pye
The slak fy skynne / about his nekke shaketh
Whil that the song / so chaungeth he and craketh
But god wot what may / thouht in hir hert
Whan she him sauh / vp syttyng in his shurt
In his nyht cappe / and with his nekke lene
She preyseth nat his pleyng worth a bene
Than he thus said / my reste wol y take
Now day is come / I may no lenger wake
A don he leyd his hed / and slept til pryme
And aftirwarde whanne he sauh his tyme
Vp riseth Ianuarye / but the freish may
Helde her chaumbre in til the ferthe day
As vsage is of wyves for the best
For euꝰery labour somtyme mot haue rest
Or ellis long / may he nat endur
This is to seyne / no lyvissh creatur
Be it of fyssh / or brid / beste or man
Now wol y speke / of woful damyan
That languysshet for love as ye shal her
Therfor y speke to him / on this maneer
I sey o sely Damyan allas right
Answer to my demaunde / as in this caas
How shalt thou thy freish may
Telle thy wo / she wol al wey sey nay
Eek if thou speke / she wol thi woo bewreye
God be thin helpe / I can not bettir sey
This syke Damyan / in Venus fir
So brennyth that he dyeth for desir
For whiche he put his lyf in aventure
No lenger myht he / in this worlde endure
But priuely a penner gan he borwe
And in a lre wrote he / al hir sorwe
In maner of a compleynt as he lay
Vnto his fayre / freish lady may
And on a purs of silke / heng on his cheerte
He hath it put / and leyd it at his herte
The mone that he was in / that Ilke day
That Ianuary / hath weddeth freish May
I too a Taur was in to a cankre glyden
So long hath in hir chaumbre abiden
As custom is / vnto this nobles al
A bryd shal nat eten in the halle
Tyl dayes foure / or thre at the leste
I passed be / than let hir go to feste
The first day / fro noon vnto noon
Whanne the hih messe / was I doon
I halle sit Ianuary / and may
As freissh / as is the somers day
And so be fel / that this good man
Remembred him vpon damyan
A seynt marys how may this be
That Damyan / attendith nat to me
Ys he ay syk / or howe may this betyde
Hir squyers / which that stoden ther beside
Excused him / bi cause / of his siknesse
Whiche lettith him / to don his besynesse
Noon othir cause / myht make him tarye
That me for thynketh / ꝙquod this Ianuarye
He is a gentyl squyer / bi my trouth
If that he deyde / it wer gret harm ⁊ routh
He is as wys discret and eek secre
As any man y wot / of his degre
And therto manly / and also seruysable
And for to be a trusty man / ryht able
But aftir mete / as sone as euir y may
I wol my selfe visite / and eek may
To don him / al the comfort that y can
And for that worde blissed him euꝰery man
That of his bounte / and of his gentylnesse
He wolde so comforte / in sekenesse
His squyer / for it was a gentyl deede
Dame ꝙquod this Ianuarye / taketh now good heede
That aftir mete / ye with your wommēm al
Whan ye haue ben in chaumbre out of this halle
That al ye go / to see this damyan
Do him disport / he is a gentil man
And tellith him / y wol him soone visite
Haue y nothing / but rested me alyte
And spede you fast / y wol ye nat abyde
Til that ye slepe / faste / by my side
And with that worde he gan to him calle
A squyer / that was Marchal of his halle
And tolde him certeyne thingꝭes / that he wolde
This freissh may hath streyht wey holde
With alle hir wommen vnto damyan
Dou bi his beddis side / sitte she than
Comfortyng him / as wel as euir she may
This damyan / whan he his tyme say
In secre wyse / his purs and eek his bylle
In whiche he writen / hadde al his wille
Hath put in to hir hand / withouten mor
Save that he siketh / wondir depe and sor
And sothly on to hir / thus said he
Mercy / and that ye nat diskyuer me
For y am ded / yf that this thing be kyd
This purs hath she / in hir bosom hid
And went hir way / ye get no mor of me
But vnto Ianuarye / y come is she
That on his beddis side / sit ful soft
And takith hir / and kisseth hir wol oft
And leyde him doon to sleep / and that a non
She feyned hir / as that she most goon
Ther as ye wot / that euꝰery wiht mot neede
And whanne she of this bille / hath taken heede
She rent it al to clowtys / at the last
And in the pryve ful lowe / she it cast
Who studieth nowe / but fair freissh may
A dou be olde Ianuary / she lay
That sleepe / til the couh / hath him a waked
A noon he preyde hir / to strippe hir al naked
He wolde of hir / he seyde / haue som plesaunce
He seid hir clothis / did him encombraunce
And she obeieth / be she leef or loth
But lest that precious folke / be to me wroth
Howe that she wrouht / y dar nat you telle
Or whethir it thouht hir / ꝑperadys or helle
But heer y let hem werken / in her wyse
Tyl evesong rang / and than they most ryse
Wher it be destenye / or aventure
Wer it bi enforsung / or bi nature
The hevene such tyme fortunat
Or bi constellaciou / in such estaat
For all thing hath tyme / as seyn thes clerkes
As fo to put / of venus werkes
To any man / for to gete hir love
I can nat sey / but grete god above
That knoweth wel / noon act is causeles
He deme of al / for y wol holde my pes
But soth is this / that this freish May
Hath take such empressiou / that day
Of pite / on this sike Damyan
That fro hir hert / she ne dryve can
The remembraunce / for to don him esse
Certeyn thouht she / whom this thing displese
I recke nat for her y him assure
To love him best of any creature
Thouh he no mor hadde / than his shert
Loo pyte / renneth sone / in gentil hert
Heer may ye seen / how exellent franchise
In womman is / whan thei ben narwe avise
Som wys tyraunt is / as ther ben many oon
That hath an hert / as sad as any stoon
Whiche wolde haue lete him sterve / in that place
Wel rather / than haue graunted him his garace
And him reioissen in hir cruel pride
And recketh nat / to ben an homycyde
This gentil may / fulfilled of pite
Ryht of hir hoonde / a lettir maade she
In whiche / she graunted him / hir verray garace
Ther lacketh nat but only day and place
Wher that she myht / vnto his lust suffise
For it shalbe / ryht as ye wol devise
And whan she sauh hir tyme / vpon a day
To visite seke damyan / goth May
And subtily this lreꝰer dou she threste
Vndir his pilwe / reede it if him list
She taketh him bi the hond / and harde twyste
So secretly / that no man of it wist
And bad him been al hool / and forth she went
To Ianuarye / whan he for hir sent
Vp riseth damyan / the next morwe
And passed was / his sekenesse and his sorwe
He kembith him / he proyneth him and pyketh
He doth al that his lady / lust and lyketh
And eek to Ianuarye / he goth as lowe
As evir dede a dogge / for the bowe
He is so plesaunt vn to euꝰery man
For craft is al / who so do it can
That euꝰery wiht / is fayn to speke him good
And fully in his ladys grace / he stood
Thus lat y damyan abowten his neede
And my tale / forth y wol procede
Som clerkes holden / that felicite
Stant in delyt / and therfor he
This noble Ianuarie with al his myht
In honest wise as longeth to a knyht
Shoop him for to lyve / delyciously
His housing his array / as honestly
To his degre / was make as a kynges
A monges othir / of his honest thinges
Ne made a gardyn / walled al wtith stoon
So fair agardyn / wot y nowher noon
For out of doute / I verraily suppose
That he that wrot the Romauce of the Rose
He cowde of it the beaute wel devise
Ne priapus ne myht nat suffise
Thouh he be god / of gardyns for to telle
The beaute of the gardyn / and of the welle
That stood alway / vndir a lawrer greene
Wol often tyme / he pluto / and his queene
Proserpyne / and al his fayre
Desporten hem / and maken melodye
Abouten that wel / and daunced / as men tolde
This nobil knyht / this Ianuarye tholde
Suche deynte hath he in it to walke and pleye
That he wolde suffre no wiht ber the keye
Sauf he him self / sauf of the smale wyket
He bar alway / of silver a cliket
With whiche whan he him lest to vnshette
And whanne he wolde paye / his wif hir dette
In somer seson thedir wolde he go
Ad may his wif and no wiht but hem too
And thing whiche wer nat for to do a bedde
He in the gardyn / ꝑperfourmed hem and spedde
And in this wyse / many a mery day
Lyveden this Ianuarye / and freissh may
And wordly Ioy / May nat al way dure
To Ianuarye / nor to ne creature
O sodeyn happe / o fortune vn stable
Lyk to the skorpyon / so desseyveable
That flaterest / wtiththin hed / whan thou wolt stynge
Thi tail is deth / with thin envenyminynge
O brotil Ioye / with such venym queynt
O monstre / that so sothlt sothly / canst peynt
Thy yftes / vndir hewe / of stedfastnesse
That thou disseyvest / both mor and lesse
Whi hast thou Ianuary / thus dissayved
That hadde him / for thi fulle frend ressayved
And now thou hast beraft him / both his eyn
For sorwe of whiche / desireth he to deyen
Allas this noble Ianuarye / so fre
Amyd his lust / and his ꝓprosꝑperite
Is woxen blynde / and that al sodeynly
He wepeth / and he weileth / pitously
And therwithal / the fir of Ielousye
Lest that his wif / sholde fal in som folye
So brende his hert / that he wolde fallen
That som man bothe him and hir had slayn
For neithir aftir his deth / ne aftir his lyf
Ne wolde he / that she wer neither love ne wyf
But evir lyve / as widewe / in clothis blake
Sooh as the turtil / that lost hathhis make
But at the last / aftir a moneth or tweye
His sorwe gan tasswage / soth to seye
For whanne he wist / it myht noon othir be
He paciently / took his aduersite
Sauf out of dout / he may not for goon
That he was Ielous / evirmor in oon
With Ielousie / he was so outrageous
That neithir in halle / ne in noon othir hous
Ne in othir place / nevir the mo
He nolde suffre hir / to ride nor go
But he hadde hond / vpon hir alwey
For whiche wol oft wepith freissh may
That loved Damyan / so fervently
That she mote / outher dye sodenly
Or ellis she mot haue him at hir lest
She waiteth / whan hir hert wolde brest
Vpon that othir side / eek damyan
Becomen is / the sorwefulest man
That evir was / for neithir nyht ne day
Miht he speke a worde / to freissh may
As to his purpos / of noon suche mateer
But if that Ianuarye / must it heer
That hadde oon hande / vpon hir evir mo
But nathirlesse / by wrytyng to and fro
And privy signes / wist she what he ment
And she knewe eek / the fyn of his entent
Lo Ianuarye what myht it the avayse
Thou thou myht se / as fer as shippes sayle
For as good is blnde to disseyued be
As be desseyved / whan a man may se
Loo Argus which that hadde / an hudred eyen left
For al that evir he coude / looken or pryen
Yit was he blent / and bi god so be mo
That wenyn wysly / that it be nat so
Passe ovir is an ese / y sey no mor
This freissh may / that y spake of so yor
In warm wex / hath preinted the cliket
That Ianuarye hadde of that smale wyket
By whiche in to his gardyn / oft he went
And Damyan / that knewe al hir entent
The cliket coūntirfeted / privily
Ther is no mor to seye / but hastily
Som wondir of this cliket / shal betyde
Whiche ye shul her / yf ye wol a byde
O noble ovid / wel seist thou God wot
What sleihte is it / thouh it be long and hoot
That he nyl fynden / it out in som maneere
Bi piriamus / and Thesbe / may men leere
Thouh they wer kept / streyte long oviral
They ben accorded / rownyng thoruh a wal
Ther no wiht cowde / haue foude out such a sleiht
But now to purpos / er than dayes eyhte
Wer passed / er the moneth of Iuly fille
That Ianuarye hath cauht so gret a wille
Thoruh . eggyng of his wyf / him to pley
In his gardyn / and no wiht but they twey
That on a morwe / vnto his May seith he
Rys vp my wif / my love / my lady free
The turtles vois is herde / my lady swete
The wynter is go / wyth the reyne wete
Comforth nowe / with thyn eyen columbyne
Ouh fairere ben thi brestis than my wyne
The gardyn is enclosed / alabowte
Comforth my swete spouse / out of dowte
Thou hast y wounded me / in myn hert / o wyf
No sport of the / ne knew y / al my lyf
Comforth / and lat vs taken / our disport
I ches the for my wyf / and for my comfort
Suche olde lewde wordes / vsed he
On damyane a signe / maad she
That he sholde go befor wtith his cliket
This Damyan / than opened the wyket
And in the he stert / and that in such maneer
That no wyht mꝰeryht it se / nen heer
And stille he sitt vndir a bussh a noon

Colours of rethoryk ben to me queynte

In armoryk that called is britayne
Ther was a knyht that loued and did his payne

And many a labour and many a gret emprise
He for his lady wrouhte er she wer wonn
For she was oon the fairest vndir sonne
And eek therto com of so hyh kynreed
That wel vnneths durst this knyht for drede
Telle hir his woo his peyne or his distresse
But at the last she for his worthynesse
And namely for his meke obeysaunce
Hath suche a pyte cauht for his penaunce
That pryvyly she fell of his accorde
To take him to hir housbonde and hir lorde
Of suche lordshipe as men̄ han of her wyves
And for to lede the more in blisse ther lyves

That nevir in all his lyf he ne day ne nyht
Ne sholde vppon̄ him take no mastrye
Ageyn̄ hir wylle ne kyth hir Ielousye
But hir obeye and folwe hir wyl in all
As any louer to his lady shall
Saue that the name of souereynte
That wolde he haue for shame of his degre
She thanked him and wyth ful gret humblesse
She seid sir sith of your gentlesse
Ye profre me to haue so large a rayne
Ne wolde nevir God bitwyxe vs tweyne
As in my gilt wer eythir werre or stryf
Sir y wol be yoʳ humble true wyf

For oon thing sires saufly dar y seye

Love is a thyng as any spyrit free
Wommen of kynde desiren̄ lyberte
And nat to be constreyned as a thral
And so do men yf I soth sey shal
Look who that is most is pacient in love
He is at his avauntage al above
Pacience is a hih v̉ertu certayn̄
For it venquyssheth all thes clerkes sayn̄
Thynges that rygour nevir shulde atteyne
For every worde men may nat chide or pleyne
Lerneth to love or ellis so mot y goon̄
Ye shul it lerne wher so ye wool or noon
For in this world certayn̄ no wyht ther is

Ire syknesse or constellacioıı̄un
Wyn wo or chaungyng of chaıı̄ungyng
Causeth ful oft to don amys or speken̄
On euery wrong a man may nat be wrekyn
Aftir the tyme most be temꝑperaunce
To eủery wyht that can of governaunce
And therfor hath this wyse worthy knyht
To lyve in ese suffraunce hir bihith
And she to him ful wysely gan to swer
That nevir shulde ther be defaute in her
Ther may men see an humble wyse accorde
Thus has she take hir servaunt and hir lorde
Servaunt in love and lorde in maryage
Thanne was he both in lordshipe and servage
Servage nay but in lordshipe above
Syth he hath his ladye and his love
His lady certys and his wyf also
To which that lawe of love accordyth to
And whan he was in this prosperyte
Hom with his wyf he goth to his contre
Nat fer fro Pedmarke ther his dwellyng was
Wher as he leveth in blisse and in solas
Who covde telle but he hadde wedded be
The yoy the ese and the prosperyte
That is bitwye an housbonde and his wyf
A yeer or mor lasteth this blisful lyf
Tyl that the knyht the whiche y spek of thus

In Inglonde that clepid was Brytayne

For all his lust he set in suche labour
And dwelle ther too yeer / the book seith thus
Now wol y stynte of this aruiragus
And speke y woll of Dorrigene his wyf
That loueth hir housbonde as hir hertys lyf
For his absence wepith she and siketh
As doon thes noble wyves whan hem lykyth
She morneth waketh / wayleth fasteth playneth

That al this wyde worlde / she set at nouht
Hir freendys / whiche that knewe / hir hevy thouht
Confortyn̄ hir / in all that evir they may

They prechin hir / they tellyn̄ hir nyht and day

Or ellis hadde this sorwe hir hert slayn̄

And prayde hir on hir kneis / for goddis sak

And fynally she graunted / that request

Now stood hir castel faste by the se

But whan̄ she seih / the grisly rokke blake

And pitously / in to the se beholde
And seid ryht thus / wyth sorweful sykes colde
Eterne god / that thoruh thy purviaunce
Ledist the world / by erterne governaunce
In ydel as men seyn̄ ye nothing make
But lorde this grisly / feendly rokkes blake

Look suche a suretye / is it to you all
That y am in your felaship / y falle
That may assoile you / both mor and lasse
Whan that the soule / shall from the body passe
I reede that our hoost / first of all begynne
For he is hihly / envolupid in synne
Cometh forth sir hoost / and offrith first anoon
And thou shalt kysse / the relykes euꝰerychoon
Ya for a grote / vnbocle a noon thi purs
Nay / nay / ꝙquod he / than haue y cristis curs
Lat be ꝙquod he / it shal nat be so theech
Thou woldist make me kysse / thin olde breech
And swer it wer / the relyk of a seynt
Thouh it wer / wtith thi foundement depeynt
But bi the cros / which that seynt helyn fond
I wolde y hadde / thi colions in myn hond
In sted of relykes / or of seynt warie
Lat kytte hem of / and y wyl than hem carye
They shul ben shryned / in a hoggis toord
This pardoneer / answerd nat ayeyn a word
So wroth he was / no word wolde he seye
Nowe ꝙquod our hoost / y will no lenger pleye
With the / ne with noon othir angry man
But ryht a noon / the worthy knyht began
Whanne that he sauh / that all the peple louh
No mor of this / for it is ryht y nouh
Sir pardoner be glad / and mery of cheer
And ye sir hoost / that ben to me so der
I paray you that ye kysse / the pardoneer
And pardoner y paray the / drauh the neer
And as we did to for / lat vs lauh and pleye
A noon they kysten / and riden forth ther wey
¶ Explicit fabula Questoris
A Marchaunt whilom dwelt at seynt denys
That ryche was / for which men hild him wys
A wyf he hadde / of excellent beaute
A compenable and revelous was she
Whiche is a thing that causeth mor dispense
And worth is all the cheer and reverence
That men hem Don at festes and at daunces
Such salutacions and contynaunces
Passen as doth a shadewe vpon a wal
But wo is him that payen mot for al
The sely housbond algate he mot paye
He mot vs cloth alway and arraye
Al for his owne worship rychelye
In which array we dawncyn Iolyly
And yf ye may nat parauentur
Or ellis lust nat such spence endur
But thenkith it is wasted and lost
Than mot a nothir pay for our cost
Or leene vs golde and that is perilous
This noble marchaunt heelde a worthy hous
For whiche he hadde al day such repayr
For his largisse and for his wyf was fayr
That wondir is but herkenyth to my tale
Among all the gestꝭes grete and smale
Ther was a monk / afair man and a bolde
I trowe a thirty wyntyr he was olde
That evir in oon was Drawyng to that place
This yong monke / that was so fair of face
Acqueynted was so with the good man
Sith that hir ferst / knolech began
That in his hous as famyliar was he
As it is possible any freede to be
And for asmoche as this goodman
And eek this monke / of which that y began
Wer both too / born in oon village
The monke him cleymeth as for cosynage
And be ageyn him seith nat onys nay
But was as glad therof as foul of day
For to his hert it was agret plesaunce
Thus ben they knyt wtith eterne Aliaunce
And eche of hem gan othir tassure
Of brothirhed wll that her lyf may dur
Fre was Dan Iohn and namely of dispence
As in that hous and ful of diligence
To to plesaunce and also gret costage
He nat forgat to yeve the lest page
In all that hous but aftir her degre
He yaf the lorde and sith all his meyne
Whanne that he com / som maneer honeste thing
For whiche they wer alle glad of his comyng
As foul is fayne whan the sonne vprisith
No mor of this as nowe for it suffisith
But so bifell this Marchaunt on a day
Shoope him to make redy / hit array
Towarde the Tou of burgeys for to fare
To byen ther a ꝓproporciou of war
For whiche he hath to parys sent a noon
A messageer and parayed hath Dan Iohn
That he shulde come to seynt denys and pleye
Wyth him and wtith his wyf a day or tweye
Or he to burges went in all wyse
This noble monk of whiche y you Devyse
Hath of his Abbot as him lust lycence
Be cause he was a man of hih prudence
And eek an officer out for to ryde
To seen her graunges and her berne wide
And vnto seynt Denys he cometh a noon
Who was so wolcome as my lord dan Iohn
Our deere cosyn / ful of curtesie
Whiche him he brouht a Iubbe of malmesye
And eek a nothir ful of fyn vernage
And volatilye as ay was his vsage
And thus y let hem eet / and drynke and pleye
This marchaunt / and this monke a day or twey
The thridde day / the marchaunt vp ariseth
And on his needis / sadly him aviseth
And vp onto his countir hous / goth he
To rekkene wtith him self wel may be
Of thilke yeer how that it wtith him stood
And howe that he dispendid hadde his good
And if that he encresed wed or noon
His bookys and his baggys many oon
He leith before him / on his countyng boord
Wol ryche was his tresour and his hoord
For whiche ful fast his countir door he shet
And eek he nolde that no man shulde him let
Of his accountes for the mene tyme
And thus he sit til it was passid payme
Dan Iohn was rysen in the morwe also
And in the gardyn walketh to and fro
And hath his thingꝭes seyd wol curteysly
This good wyf cam walkyng pryvyly
In to the gardyn ther she walked soft
And him salveth as she hath doon oft
A mayde childe cam in hir companye
Whiche as hir lust she may governe and guye
For yet vndir the yerde was the mayde
O deere cosyn my Dan Iohn she said
What eyleth you so rathe for taryse
Neece ꝙquod he it auhte y nouh suffise
Fyve hours to slepe vpon a nyht
But it wer for an olde appalled wyht
As ben thes wedded men / that lyu and dare
As in a fourme sit a wery hare
Wer all for strauht wtith houndes gret and smale
But deere Nece why be ye so pale
I trowe certis / that yorur good man /
Hath you laboured sith the nyht beganne
That you wer neede to restyn hastelye
And with that woorde he louh wol merely
And of his owne thouht / he wex al red
This faire wyf began to shake hir hed
And said thus / ya god wot al ꝙquod she
Nay cosyn myn it stant nat so wtith me
By that god that yaf me soule and lyf
In all the reame of Fraunce ther is no wyf
That lasse lust hath to that sory pleye
For y may synge allas and welaweye
That y was born / but to no wyht ꝙquod she
Dar y nat telle how it stant wtith me
Wherfor y thynke out of this londe to wende
Or ellis of my self to make an ende
So ful y am of dreede and eek of care
This monke began vppon this wyf to stare
And said allas my neece / god forbede
That ye for any sorwe / or any dreede
For doo your self but telle me yorur greef
Parauentur / y may you myscheef
Conseyle or helpe and therfor tellith me
Al your annoy . for it shal secre be
For on my portos heer y make an oth
That nevir in my lyf for leef ne loth
Ne shall y you / of no conseil be wreye
The same agayn / ꝙquod she / to you y seye
By god and by this portos her y swere
Thouh men me wolden / al on peces ter
Ne shall y nevir for to go to helle
Bewreye o woord / of thing that ye me telle
Nat for no cosynage nallyaunce
But verrayly for love and affyaunce
Thus ben they sworn and her vpon kyst
And eche of hem tolde othir / wham him list
Cosyn ꝙquod she / yf that y had a space
As y haue noon / and namely in this place
Than wolde y telle a legen>de of my lyf
What y haue suffred sith y was a wyf
Wyth myn housbonde al be he yorur cosyn
Nay ꝙquod this monke bi god and by seynt Martyn
He is no mor cosyn / vnto me
Than is this leff that hangeth on the tre
I clepe him so / by seynt Denys of Fraunce
To haue of him / the cause of acqueyntaunce
Of you / whiche haue loved specyally
Aboven al womnēm / sykyrly
This swer y you / on my professiou
Telle on your greef / lest ye come a dou
And hasteth you and goth awey a noon
My der love / o my dan Iohn
Wol leef it wer to me this conseil hide
But out yt mote / y may no mor byde
Myn housbonde is to me / the worst man
That evir was / sith the worlde began
But sith y am a wyf / it sit nat me
To telle no wiht / of your privite
Neithir a bedde / ne in othir place
God shilde y shulde telle it for his garace
A wyf shall nat seyn / of hir housbond
But all honour / as y can vndirstond
Save vnto you thus moche telle y shall
So helpe me god / he is nat worth catall
In no degre / the value of a flye
But yit me greuith most / his nygardye .
And wel ye wot / that wommēm naturallye
Desiren othir thynges / as wel as y
They wolden / that her housbondes shulde be
Hardy and wys and ryche / and fre
And buxum to his wyf / and freissh a bedde
And by that lord / that for vs bledde
For his honour / my selven tarraye
A sonday next y most nedis pay
An hundred Frankes / or ellis am y lorn
It wer me bettir / that y wer vnborn
Than me wer don / a sklaundr / or velanye
And of my housbonde / myht it eek espeye
I ner but lost / and therfor y you preye
Leene me this somme / or ellis mot y deye
Dan Iohn y sey / lene me this hudred frankes
Parde y wol nat faile you me thankes
If that ye lest to doon that y you pꝰerye
For at a certeyn day / y wol you paye
And doon to you / what plesaunce and seruyse
That y may do / Ryht as you list Devyse
And but y do / god take on me vengeaunce
As foul as evir hadde Genelou of Fraunce
This gentyl monke answerd in this maneer
Now truly / myn owne lady Deer
I haue of you / nowe so gret routh
That y you swer / and plyht you my trouth
Than whanne your housbonde is to flaundresifar
I wol delyver you / from all this car
For y wol bryng you / an hundred Frankes
And with that woord he cauht hir by the flankes
And hir embraced / and kyst hir ful oft
Goth now your wey ꝙquod she / al stille and soft
And lat vs Dyne as sone as that you may
For be my chelaundir it is tyme of Day
Goth nowe / and be as true as y shalbe
Now ellis goddis forbede ꝙquod she
And forth he goth / as Ioly as a pye
And bad the cookys that they shuld hem hyh
So that men myht dyne and that a noon
Vp to hir housbonde is this wyf igoon
And knocketh at his countir boldelye
Que laꝙquod he / Petir it am I
Qd she what be how long wol ye fast
How long tyme wol ye reckne and cast
Your Sommys and your bookys and yorur thingis
The Devel haue part on all such rekenynges
Ye haue y nougꝰer parde of goddis sonde
Com dou to day and lat our bagges stonde
Ne be nat a shamed that Dan Iohn
Shal fastyn all this day elyng goon
What lat vs her a masse and go we dyne
Wyf ꝙquod this man canst thou devyne
The curious besinesse that we haue
For of vs chapmen also god me saue
And by that lord that clepid is seynt Ive
Skarsly among twelve ten shul thryve
Contynual lastyng vn til our age
We may well make cheer / and good visage
And dryve forthe the world as it may be
And keep our estaat al in pryvyte
Tyl we be ded / or ellis that we pleye
On pilgrymage or goon out / of the weye
And therfor haue y / grete necessite
Vppon this queynt world avise me
For evirmo we mot stond and drede
Of happe and fortune in our chapmanhede
To Flaundirs wol y go / to morwe day
And come agayn as sone as evir y may
For whiche my der wyf I the beseeke
As be to euꝰery wiht buxum and meeke
And for to kepe our good / be curious
And honestly / governe wel our hous
Thouh hast y nouh in euꝰery maner wyse
That to thrifty housolde / may suffyse
Ther lacketh noon array / ne non vitaile
Of silver in thy purs shalt thou nat faile
And with that word his coutour dor he shet
And dou he goth no lenger wold he let
And hastely a masse / was ther said
And speedly the tables wer y laid
And to dyner / faste they hem spedde
And rychely this mōmk / the chapman fedde
And after dyneer / Dan Iohn sobirly
This chapman took a part / and pryvyly
And seid him thus / cosyn it stondeth so
That wel y se to Burgeys wol ye go
God and seynt Austyn Spede you and guyde
I paray you cosyn / wysly that ye ryde
Governeth you also of your dyete
Attempirly and namely / in this heete
Betwyx vs it nedith no straunge far
Farwel cosyn god shilde you from car
And if that any thing by day or be nyht
If it be in my power and my myht
That may ye wel cōmmaunde in any wyse
It shalbe do ryht as ye wol devyse
O thing or ye goo / if it may be
Y wolde paray you / for to lene me
An hundred Frankes / for a wyke or tweye
For certayn bestys / that y most beye
To store wtith a place that is ourys
God helpe me so wolde y hit wer youris
I shall nat fayle surely of my day
Nat for a thousand Frankes a myleway
But lat this thing be secre I you paray
For yit to nyht / thes bestys mot y beye
And far nowe wel myn owne cosyn der
Graunt mꝰercye of you cost and of your cher
This noble marchaunt / gentely a noon
Answerd and said / o cosyn myn Dan Iohn
Now sykyrly this is / a smal request
My golde is your / whan that evir you lest
And nat only my golde but my chaffar
Take what you lest god shilde that you spar
But othing is / y know it wel y nouh
Of chapmen / that her money is her plouh
We may creaunce / whil we han a name
But goodles for to me it is no game
Payeth it agayn whan it lyth in yorur ese
Aftir my wyt fayn wolde you plese
Thes hundred Frankes / he fet forth a noon
And privily he took hem / to Dan Iohn
No wiht in all this word / wost of this lone
Savyng this Marchaunt / and dan Iohn allone
They Drynke and speke / and roome awhile and pleye
Tyl Dan Iohn / rideth to his Abbey
The morwe cam / and forth this marchant rideth
To flaundirs warde / his preyntys wel him guydeth
Tyl he com in to Burges muryly
Now goth this marchaunt / fast and besely
Aboute his nede / and byeth and creaunseth
He neithir pleyeth at the dees / ne Daunceth
But as a marchaunt sothly for to telle
He ledith his lyf / and ther y let him twelle
The sonday next / that the marchaunt was a gon
To seynt Denys / I comen is Dan Iohn
With crowne and borde al freissh and new y shave
In all the hous ne was so litil a knave
Ne no wiht ellis / that he nas ful fayn
That my lord Dan Iohn / was comen agayn
And shortly to the poynt / for to goon
This wi fair wyf accordid to Dan Iohn
That for thes hundred Frankes / he shuld al niht
Haue hir in his armys / bolt vpryht /
And this accord / parfourmede was in dede
In myrthe all nyht a besy lyf they lede
Tyl it was day / that Dan Iohn went his way
And bad the mene / farwel and haue good day
For noon of hem / ne no wiht of the tou
Hath of Dan Iohn / ryht no suspecciou
And forth he rideth hoom / to his abbeye
Or wher him list / no mor of him y seye
This Marchaunt whan that ended was þe fair
To seynt Denys he gan ageyn repair
And wtith his wyf he maketh fest and cheer
And telleth hir / that chaffar is so deer
That nedis meste he make a chevisaunce
For he was bounde in a reconisaunce
To pay twenty thousand / sheeld a noon
For which this marchaunt is to pareys goon
To borwe of certayn frendys / that he hadde
A certayn Frankes and som wtith him he ladde
And whanne he was y comyn in to the tou
For grete cheerte / and affecciou
Vn to Dan Iohn him first he goth to pleye
Nat for to aske or borwe of him monye
But for to weefe / and seen of his welfar
And for to tellyn him of his chaffar
As Freendis doon whan they ben y fer
Dan Iohn him maketh fest and mery cheer
And he him tolde agayn ful specially
Howe he hadde wel y bouht and graciously
Thanked be god all hool his marchaundise
Save that he most in al maneer wyse
Make a chevisaunce / as for his best /
And than he shulde be in yoy and rest
Dan Iohn answerd certys y am fayn
That ye in hele as comen hoom agayn
And yf that I wer ryche / as haue y blisse
Of twenty thousande sheeldys shulde ye nat mysse
For ye so keendly / this othir day
Lent my golde and as y can or may
I thanke you by god / and by seynt Iame
But natherles I took vnto you Dame
Your wyf at hoom / the same gold agayn
Vpon your benche she wot it wel certayn
By certayn tokenys / that y can you telle
Nowe by your leve / y may no lenger dwelle
Our abbot / wol out of this tou anoon
And in his companye / mot y goon
Greteth wel our dame myn own nyce swete
And farwell dere cosyn / tyl we mete
This marchaunt / which þtat was was ⁊ wys
Creaunceth hath and payd in parys
To certayn lubardis / reedy in her hoond
The somme of gold and gat of hem his bond
And hom he goth as mery as a poyngay
For wel he knewe he stood in suche array
That needis most he wynne / in his vyage
A thousand Frankes / a boven all his costage
His wyf wol redy / met him at the gate
As she was wont / of olde vsage algate
And all that nyht / in mirth they besette
For he was ryche / and cleerly out of dette
Whan it was day this marchaunt gan tenbrace
His wyf all newe / and kyst hir on the face
And vp he goth / and maketh it ful touh
No mor ꝙquod she / by god ye haue y nouh /
And wantonsly / agay with she playd
Tyl at the last / this Marchaunt to hir seid
By god ꝙquod he / y am a litel wroth
Sith you my wyf / al thouh it be me loth
And wot ye why / bi god as that y gesse
That ye han made a maner of straunlgenesse
Betwyx me and my cosyn / Dan Iohn
Ye shulde hau harne me / er y had goon
That he you hadde an hundred Frankes payd
By redy tokene and held him evil apayd
For that y to him spak / of chevysaunce
Me semed so / as by his contynaunce
But natherlesse by god our hevene kyng
I thouh nat to aske of him no thyng
I paray the wyf / do thou no mor soo
Telle me alway / er that y from the go
If any dettur / hath in myn absence
I payd the lest throuh thi necgligence
I myht him aske a thing that he hath payd
This wyf nat a ferd ne affrayd
But boldely she said / and that a noon
Mary I diffye / the fals monke Dan Iohn
I keep nat of his tokenys / nevir adeel
He took me certayn golde thus wot y wel
What evil thedam on his monkes snowte
For god it wot I wend wtith owten dowte
That he had yove it me by cause of you
To do wythall / myn honour and my prowe
For cosynage and eek for bele cheer
That he hath had wol ofttyme her
But sith y se it stant in such dysyont
I wol answer you shortly to the poynt
Ye han mo slacker dettours than am I
For y wol pay you wele and redely
Fro day to day if it so be y fayle
I am your wyf scor it vpon my tayle
And y shall pay as sone asvir y may
For by my trouth / I haue on myn array
And nat on wast / bestowed euꝰery dell
And for y haue bestowed it so well
For your honour for goddis sake y seye
As be nat wroth but lat vs lauh and playe
Ye shal haue my Ioly body to wedde
By god y wilnat pay you but a bedde
For yeve it me / myn owne spouse deer
Turneth hiddirward and maketh bettir cher
This marchaunt sauh the was no remedye
And for to chide it ner but folye
Sith that the thyng may nat amendid be
Now wyf he seid / and y foryeve it the
And bi thi lyf be no more so large
Keept bet thi good this yf y the in charge
Thus endith her my tale / and god vs sen
Talkyng y nouh vnto our lyves ende
WEle seyd by corpus dūns / seyd our host
Now long mot thou sayle / by the coost
Syr shipmānn / gentyl mayster maryneer
God yeve the Monk / a thousand quade yeer
A ha felows bewar / of such a Iape
The Monk put in / the mannys hood an ape
And in his wyves eek / by seynt Austyn
Drawe no monkes / no more to your In
But now passe ovyr / and lat vs seek abowte
Who shall now telle / fyrst of all thys rowte
A nothir tale / and with word he sayde
As curtesly / as he hadde ben a mayde
My lady pryoresse / by your leve
So that I wyst / I sholde you nat greve
I wolde deme / that ye tellyn sholde
A tale next / yf hit so were ye wolde
Now wol ye vouchesafe / my lady dere
Gladly qd she / and sayde as ye shal here
O lord our lord / thy name how mꝰerueylous
Is in this large world / spred qd she
For not oonly thy name loud so precious
ꝐPerfourmed is / by men of dignyte
But by the mouth / of children thi boute
ꝐPerfourmed is for in the brest sowkyng
Somtyme shewyn thei / thyn heryeng
Wherfore in laude / as I best can and may
Off the and of the white lylie flour
Which that the bare and is a mayde alway
To telle a story / I wol doo my labour
Nat that I may encresyn hyr honour
For she hir silf / is honour and the roote
Of boute next hir sonne / and sowlys boote
O moodyr mayde / o mayde mooder fre
O bussh vnbrent / brennyng in Moyses syght
That ravisshst dou / from the deite
Therough thyn hūnblesse / the goste that alyght
Of whos vertu / whan he in the alyght
Conceyvid was / the fadrys sapience
Help me to tell hit in thy reuerence
Lady thi boute / thi magnificence
Thi vertu / and thi grete humylite
Ther may no tonge / expresse in no science
For somtyme lady / er men pray to the
Thou gost beforn / of thi benygnyte
And getist vs the lyght / of thi prayeere
To getyn vs / to thy sonne so deere
My konnyng is so weyk / o blysfull queene
For to declare / thi grete worthynesse
That I may nat / the with no wight susteene
But as a childe of twelue moneth or lesse
That kanne vnethe / any word expresse
Ryght so fare I / and therfore I the praye
Gydith my song that I shal of you seye

l.hi:
Explicit tabulaꝒPrologus Priorisse . Et
incipit fabula euildiūn de Alma Redemptoriꝭes

div.l: Ther was in Asye / in a grete Cite
Amonges Crystene folk / a Iewerye
Susteyned by a lord / of that Contre
For vsurye and lucre of velanye
Hatefull to Cryst / and to his companye
And thorough the strete / men myght ryde ⁊ wende
For hit was fayre and open atte either ende
A lytel scole of crysten folk ther stood
Doun atte the ferther ende / in which ther were
Children an hepe / come of cristen blood
That lerneden in that scole / as men vsyd there yere by yere
Such maner doctryne / as men vsyd there
This is to seyn / to syngen and to rede
As smale children doon / in her chyld heede
Among thes chyldren / was a wydwes sonne
A lytel clerke / sevyn yere of age
That day by day / to scole he was wonne
And eke also / where he saugh an ymage
Of crystes moodir / he hadde in vsage
As hym was taught / to knele a doun ⁊ saye
His Aue marye / as he goith by the waye
Thus hath this wydewe / hir lytel sonne I taught
Our blysfull lady / crystes mooder deere
To worshipe ay / and he forgat hit naught
For seely childe / wol alway sone leere
But ay whan I remembre on that mateere
Seynt Nicholas / stant evir in my presence
For he so yong / did cryst suche reuerence
This litel childe / this lytel book lernyng
As he sat in scole / atte his prymeer
He Alma Redemptoris / herd syng
As children lerned / her Antiphoneer
And as he durst / he drow hym neer ⁊ neere
And herkeneth ay / the woordis and the noote
Tyl the firste verse / covde al be roote
Nought wist he / what this latun was to saye
For he so yong was / and of tendir age
But on a day / his felawe gan he praye
Texpowne hym / this song in his langage
Or telle hym why / this song was in vsage
This prayde he hym / to construe and declare
Wel ofte tymes / vpon his knees bare .
His felawe / whiche that eldere was than he
Answerde hym thus / this song I haue herd seye
Was maade of our blisful lady fre
Hir for to salute / and eeke for to pray
To ben oure helpe and socour / whan we deye
I canne nomore expoune / in this mateer
I lerne song I kanne but litel grameer
And is this song / maad in Reuerence
Off crystes mooder / seyd this Innocent
Now certis / I wol do my diligence
To lerne hit al / er Crystenmasse be went
Though that I / for my prymeer sholde be shent
And sholde be bete / thryes in an hour
I wol hit konne / our lady to honour
His felawe taught hym homward pryuely
Fro day to day / tyl he cowde hit by roote
And then he song hit wel and boldely
Fro word to word / accordyng with the noote
Twyes aday / hit passid thorough his throote
To scole ward / and homward / whan he went
On crystis mooder / sette was alle his entent
As I have seyde / thorugh the Iewerye
That litel childe / as he cam to and fro
Wel meryly / wolde he syng and crye
O Alma Redemptoris mater / evir mo
The swetnesse / of his hert perced so
Of crystes mooder . that to hir to praye
He can not stynt / of syngyng by the waye
Owr first foo / the serpent sathanas
That hath in Iewys hert / his waspys nest
Vpswal and seyde / o hebrayk people o allas
Is this a thyng / that is to you honest
That such a boy / shal walken as hym lest
In your despyte and syng suche sentence
Which is ayens your lawe and Reuerence
Fro thens forth the Iewys han conspired
This Innocent owt of this world to chace
An homycide / therto han thei hired
That in an Aley / hadde a pryvy place
With swykil hert / and with cursed face
This cursed Iewe hym hente and held hym faste
And kitte his throte / and in A pytte hym caste
I sey that in a Wardrope / thei hym drewe
Where as thes Iewes / purgen her entrayle
O cursed folk of herodis al newe
What may your evil entent / you avayle
Morthre wol owt / certeyn hit wol not fayle
And namely there / as the honour of god shal spreede
The blood owt cryeth on your cursed dede
O martir sone lyke to virgynyte
Now maist thou syng / foloyng evir in oone
The white lamb celestial qd she
Of which the grete ewangelist seynt Iohn
In patmos wrote which seyth that thei that goon
Bifore this lomb / and syng a song al newe
That thei fleisshly wommen knewe
This pore wydewe wayteth al that nyght
After hir litel childe / but he cometh nought
For which as soone / as hit was dayes lyght
With face pale / for drede and bisy thought
She at scole / and ellis wher hym sought
Tyl fynally / she gan so ferr aspye
That he last seye was in the Iewerye
With moodris pyte / in hir hert enclosid
She goth as she were / half owt of hir mynde
To every place / where she hath supposid
By lykliheed / hir litel childe to fynde
And evir on cristes moodir / meke and kynde
She cryide / and at the laste thus she wrought
Among the cursed Iewes / she hym sought
She frayneth / and euꝰery Iewe pitously
She axith that dwellith in that place
To telle yf hir childe went forth by
They seyden nay / but Ihūn of his grace
Yafe in hir thought / wtith in a litel space
That in that place aftir hym so she cryde
Where he was cast / in a pitte beside
O grete god that ꝑperfourmest thi laude
By mouth of Innocentes / loo here thy myght
This gemme of chastite / this emeraude
And eke of martirdom / the rubye bryght
Ther he with throte / lay corven vpryght
He Alma Redemptoris / gan to syng
So lowde / that alle the place gan to Ryng
The crysten folk / that thorough the strete wenten
In cōmme forto woundern vpon this thyng
And hastely / thei for the provost senten
He cōmme Anon / withoute taryeng
And prayeth cryst that is hevyn kyng
And his mooder eeke / that is honourꝰer of mankynde
And aftyr that / the Ieweys left lete / be bynde
This chylde with pitous / lamentacoūn
Vptaken was / syngyng his song alway
And with honour / and grete processioūn
They carye hym / in to the next Abbay
His mooder swonyng / by his beere lay
Vneth myght the people / that was there
The newe Rachel / bryng from his bere
With turment and with shameful deth echoon
This provyst doth thes Iewes forto sterve
That of this wyst / and that right anoon
He wolde no suche cursednesse / observe
Evil shal haue / that evil wol deserve
Therfore with wilde hors / he dede hem drawe
And after that he heeng hem by the lawe
Vpon this beere ay lay this Innocent
Bifore thawtere / whil the masse laste
And aftir thabbot / with his hool covent
Haue sped hem hym to beryen wol faste
And whan the haly watyr / on hym was cast
Yit spak this childe whan sproung was halywatir
And song . O alma Redemptoris mater
This Abbot / which that was an hooly man
As monkes be / or ellis aught to be
The yong childe to coniure he began
And seyde / o deere childe I halsen the
In vertu of the hooly trynyte
Telle me / what is thi cause forto syng
Sith thi throte is kyt at my seemyng
My throte is kit / vnto my necke bon
Sayde this childe and as by wey of kynde
I sholde han deyed ya ful longe agon
But Ihūn criste / as ye in bookes fynde
Wol that his glorie laste and be in mynde
And for the worshepe of his moder deere
Yit may I syng / O Alma lowde and cleere
This welle of mercy / cristis mooder deere
I lovide alwaye / as aftir my konnyng
Whan I my lyfe / sholde leet as heere
To me she cam / and bad me forto syng
This Anthme verrily in my deyeng
As ye han herd / and whan that I hadde songe
Me thought she layde a grayne vpon my tonge
Wherfore I syng and syng mot certeyn
In honour of the blysfull mayde free
Til of my tonge taken is the greyne
And aftir that / seyde she to me
My litel childe nowe I fecche the
Whan the greyne / is from thi tonge take
Be not agast / I wol not the forsake
This hooly monk / this Abbot hym meene I
His tonge out caughte / and took away the greyne
And he yaf vp the gost / wel softely
And whan that this wounder / was I seyne
His salt terys / trilled a doun as reyne
And doun he fil / al plat vpon the grounde
And stille he lay as though he had be bounde
The Covent eeke lay vpon the pavement
Weepyng and praying crystis mooder deere
And aftirward thei ryse / and forth thei went
And tooken away the martyr from his beere
And in a tombe / of marbil stonys cleere
Enclosen thei / this hooly body swete
Ther he is nowe / god lene vs forto meete
O yong huhe of lincolne slayn also
With cursed Iewes / as hit is notable
For hit is but a litel while ago
Pray eeke for vs / synful folk vnstable
That of his mercy / god so merciable
On h vs his greete mercy multiplye
For Reuerence of his mooder marye Amen

l.hi:
Et incipit
Prologus Chaūnceer de Dūno Thopas

div.l: Whan seid was this miracle / every man
As sobre was / that wondir was to se
Til that our host / iapen then began
And then at erst / he looked vpon me
And seide thus / what art thou qd he
Thou lookist / as thou woldist fynde an hare
For evir vpon the ground / I see the stare
Approche neere / and looke vp merily
Nowe war you syrres / and lat this man haue place
He in the wast / is shape as wel as I
This were a pepet / in Armes to enbrace
For any womman / fayr and smal of face
He seemeth elvissh / by his contynauce
For vnto no wyght / doth he no daliance
Nay somwhat nowe / syn othir folk haue saide
Telle vs a tale of myrth and that Anone
Host qd I / ne beth nat evil appayde
For othir tale certys kan I none
But of a ryme / I lernyd long agone
Ye that is good qd he / now shul we heere
Som deynte thyng me thynketh by thy cheere
Lysteneth lordyges in good entent
And I wol telle verrayment
Off myrth and solas
Of a knyght was fayr and gent
In batayle and in turnement
His name was syr Thopas
Born he was in ferr contre
In flaundres al beyond the se
At poperynge in the place
His fadir was a man ful free
And lord he was of that contre
As hit was goddis grace
Syr Thopas was a doughty swayn
Whyte was his face as paynne mayn
His lyppes rede as Rose
His roode was lyke scarlet in grey
And I you telle in good certeyn
He hadde a seemely nose
His heer his berd is lyke saffroıı̄un
That to his gerdel raught adoıı̄un
His shoon of Cordewane
Off Bruges wer his hosen broıı̄un
His Robe was of Sulatoıı̄un
That cost many a Iane
He cowde hunte at the wilde deer
And ryde and hawke by the Ryuer
With gray goshawke on hond
And therto he was a good Archere
Off wrastlyng was ther noon his peer
Ther any man shold stonde
Full many a mayde bryght in bowre
Thei moorne for his ꝑparamoure
Whan hem wer bet to sleepe
But he was chast and no lechoure
And swoote as is the brembil floure
That berith the rede heepe
And so befell vpon a day
Forsothe as I you telle may
Sir Thopas wold out Ride
He worth vpon his steede gray
And in his hond a laūnce gay
A long swerd bi his syde
He pryketh thorugh a fayr forest
Ther in is many a wilde beest
Ya both bukke and hare
And as he pryked North and es
I telle you hym hadde almest
Betyd a sory care
Ther spryngen herbis both grete and smale
The lycorys and the Cetuale
And many a Clowe gelofre
And a notmuge to putten in ale
Whethir hit be moist or stale
Othir for to leyn in cofre
The bryddis syngen hit is no nay
The sparhawke and the popingay
That Ioye hit was to here
The throstil cok made eeke his lay
The wode dove vpon the spray
She song ful loude and clere
Syr Thopas fel in love longyng
Alwey he herd the throstil syng
And priked as he wer woode
His fayr steede in his prikyng
So swette that men myght hym wryng
His sydes wer all bloode
Syr Thopas eeke so sory was
For prykyng on the soft gras
So fers was his corage
That doıı̄un he layd hym in that place
To maken his steede som solace
And yaff hym good forage
O seynte Marye benedicite
What eileth this love at me
To bynde me so sore
Me dremyd al this nyght parde
An elue queene shal myn lēmman be
And slepe vndir my gor
An Elue queene wol I loue I wys
For in this world no woman is
Worthy to be my make
in towne
Alle othir women I forsake
And to an Elue queene I me take
By dale and eeke by downe
In to his sadil he clamb anoon
And prikith ouer style and stoon
An Elue queene forto aspye
Til he so long riden hath and gone
That he fond in a pryve wone
The contre of Fayrie
So wilde
For in that contre was ther noon
Nouthir wife ner childe
Til that ther cam a grete geaıı̄unt
His name was clepid sir Olifaıı̄unt
A pereilous man of deede
He seide childe by Termagaıı̄unt
But yf thou prike out of myn haunt
Anoon I sle thi steede
With mace
Heere is the queen of fayrie
With harpe and pipe and symphonye
Dwellyng in this place
The child seide also mot I the
To morwe wil I meeten with the
Whan I haue myn Armour
And yit I hope parmafay
That thou shalt with this laıı̄uncegay
Abeyen hit ful sour
Thi mawe
Shal pershe yif that I may
Or hit be prime of the day
For heere thou shalt be slaw
Sir Thopas drauth a bak ful faste
This Geaıı̄unt at hym stonys caste
Out of a fel staf slynge
But fayr escapid childe Thopas
And al hit was bi goddis gras
And thorugh his fayr beryng
Yit lestenyth lordynges to my tale
Meryer than the nyghtyngale
For nowe I wil you rowne
How syr Thopas with sydes smale
Pryking ouer hill and dale
Is comen ageyn to towne
His mery men comaıı̄undid he
To make hym both game and gle
For needis most he fight
With a geaıı̄unt with heedis thre
For paramours and Iolite
Of oon that shone ful bryght
Do com he saide my menstralles
And gestours forto telle tales
Anoon in myn Armyng
Of Romaıı̄unces that be Roiales
Of Popis and of Cardinales
And eek of loue lykyng
Thei sette hym first the swete wyne
And mede eeke in a maselyne
Off Roial spicerye
Off gyngerbred that was ful fyne
And lycoris and eeke comyne
Wᵗith sugre that is trye
He dide next his white leere
Off cloth of lake fyne and cleer
A brech and eeke a shert
And next his sherte and aketoıı̄un
And ouer that an habirioıı̄un
For persyng of his hert
And ouer that a fyne hauberke
Was al wrought in Iewes werke
Ful strong hit was of plate
And ouer that / his cote armour
As white as is the lilly flour
In which he wil debate
His sheeld was of gold so rede
And therin was a boris hede
And a Charboucle beside
And ther he swoor in Ale and brede
That the geaıı̄unt shal be dede
Betide what be tide
His Iambes wer of quire bon
His swerdis sheth was of yuery bryght
His sadil was of Rowel bon
His bridil as the sonne shon
Othir as the moon lyght
His spere was of fyne Cypresse
That tokenyth werre and nothyng pese
The hede ful sharp I ground
His steede was al dapil gray
Hit goth an amble by the way
Ful softely and roıı̄unde
In londe
Loo lordynges heer is a fytt
Yif ye wil here any more of hit
To telle hit wil I fonde
Nowe hold your mouth for charyte
Both knyght and lady free
And herkenyth to my spell
Of batail and of chyualrye
And of ladies love drurye
Anon I wil you telle
Men speken of Romaıı̄uncies of pryce
Off horn childe and of ypotice
Off Beve and sir Guy
Off sir libeus and pleyndamour
But Sir Thopas berith the flour
Off Roial chyualry
His good steede he al be strod
And forth vpon his way he rod
As sparke out of the bronde
Vpon his Creste he bare a toure
And ther in stiked a lilly floure
God sheld his Corps fro shonde
And for he was knyght Auenturous
He nolde slepyn in non hous
But slepyn in his hood
His bryght helm / was his wonger
And by hym baited his destrer
Off herbis fyne and good
Hym silf drank watyr of the welle
As did the knyght Sir ꝐPercyvelle
So worthy vndir weede
Tyl on a day
NO more of this / for goddis dignyte
Quod our host for thou makest be
So wery / of the verray lewdnesse
That also wysly / god my soule blysse
Myn erys akyn of thy dresty speche
Now suche a Ryme / the devil I beteche
This may be wel / ryme dogerel qd he
Why so qd I . whi wolt thou lette me
More of my tale / than anothir man
Sith it is the best ryme / I can
By god qd he / for playnly atte o wor
Thy dresty Rymyng / is not worth a tord
Thou dost not ell / but dispendist tyme
Sir at o word / thou shalt no lenger ryme
Lat see yf thou canst / ought tellen in geste
Or telle in prose / somwhat and at the leste
In which ther be / som merth or som doctryne
Gladly qd I . bi goddis swete pyne
I wol you telle / a litel thyng in prose
That aught to lyke you / I suppose
Or ell certys / ye be to daūngerous
It is a moral tale / vertuous
Al be hit told / somtyme in sondry wyse
Off sondry folk / as I shal you devyse
As thus ye wot / that euꝰery euangelist
That tellith vs the peyn of Ihūn crist
Ne seith nat al thyng / as his felawe doth
But nathirles / her sentence is al soth
And all accorden / as in her sentence
Al be ther in her tellyng difference
For som of hem / seith more and som lesse
Whan thei his pitous passiou expresse
I meene of Mark / Mathew / luke / and Iohn
But doutles her sentence / is al oon
Therfore lordynges / alle I you beseche
Yif ye thinke I war varye as in my speche
As thus / though that I telle somwhat more
Of proverbes / than ye han herd before
Comprehended in this litel tretys heere
Tenforce with / theffect of my mateere
And though I nat / the same wordes seye
As ye han herd / yit to you alle I preye
me me nat / for as in my sentence
l ye nouhere / fynde difference
Fro this sentence / of this tretys lyte
After the which / this mery tale I write
And therfore herkenyth / what that I shal seye
And lete me telle / al my tale I preye

div.ab:
A yong man called Mellibeus myghty and ryche
he begat vpon his wife / that callid was prudence
a doughtir / which that clepid was Sophye /

Vpon a day hit befel that for his disport is went in to
the feeldys hym to pleye /

his wife and eeke his doughtir
hath he left with inne the hous / of which the dorys wer
faste I shet /

Thre of his olde foos han hit aspied / and
setten ladderys to the walles of his hous / and by wyndowes
ben entred /

and beetyn his wyfe and woūndid his doughtir
with fyve mortal woundes in fyve sondry places /

this is
to seye in hir feet / in hir hoondes / in hir erys / in hir nose
and in hir mouth / and leftyn hir for dede / and wentyn
her way /

Whan Mellibeus retourned was in to his hous /
and seeth al this myscheeff / he like a mad man reendyng
his clothis gan to wepe and crye /

Prudence his wife / as
ferre forth as she durste / besought hym of his weepyng
for to stynte /

But nat for thi he gan to crye and wepe evir
lengere the more /

This noble wife prudence Remembred
hir vpon the sentence of Ovide / in his book that is I
clepid the Remedye of love / wher as he seith

he is a fool
that distrobleth the moodir to weepe the deth of hir
childe til she hath weepid al hir fille as for a certayn tyme

and than shal man doon his diligence wtith amyable wordis
hir to recomforte /

For which resou this noble wife prudence
suffred hir housbonde forto weepe and crye / as for a certayn
space

And whan she saugh hir tyme she seide hym in
this wise / Allas my lord qd she why make ye your self
for to be lyke a fool /

Forsothe hit apperteneth nat to a wiseman
to make such sorwe

your doughtir with the grace of god
shall warysshen and escapen /

And all wer hit so that she
rightnowe wer dede / ye ne aught nat as for hir deth yorur
silf to distroye .

Senek seith a wise man shal nat take
to greet discomforte for the deth of his children

but certys
he sholde suffren it in pacience as wel as he abideth the
deth of his owne ꝑpersone /

Mellibeus seide what man qd
he shoold of his weepyng stynte that hath so grete a cause
forto weepe /

Ihūn cryst our lord hym sylf / wept for the deth
of lazar his freend //

Prudence answerde Ceertys wele I
wot a tempre wepyng is no thyng dyffendid to hym that
sorweful is / amonges folk in sorwe / but hit is rather grauted
hym to weepe /

The Apostil poule vnto the Romayns
writeth Man shal reioissh wtith hym that makith ioye and
weepe wtith such folk as weepe /

But though tempre wepyng
be grauted / outrageous weepyng / certys is diffendid /

Mesure
of weepyng sholde be considred aftir the lore that techith
vs Senek /

whan that thi freend is dede qd he / lat thyn eyen
be nat to moyste of terys / ne to moche drye /

yif that ye
gouerne you bi sapience / putteth away sorwe out of your
hert
Ihc̄etc Sirak seith / sorwe in hert sleth many a man

OF thes forseide thynges / answerde Mellibeus to his wife
prudence / Alle thes wordes qd he ben soth and therto
profytable / But trewly myn hert is troubled with this
sorwe so grevously / that I not what to doon /

Lat calle qd
prudence thi trewe freendes alle / and thi lynage which þtat
ben wise / and telleth hem your caas / and herkenyth what
thei seye in comen seying / and you gouerneth aftir her
sentence /

Salamon / seith / werk all thi thynges by couseyl
and thou shalt nevir repent /

Than bi the cousail of his
wife Prudence / This Mellibeus leet callen a grete congre-
gacou of folk //

as Surgens phisiciens / olde folk and yonge /
And som of his olde enemys reconsiled / as bi her semblaut /
to his love / and in to his grace /

And therwithalle / ther
come some of his neyhbourys that dede hym Reuerence
more for drede than for love as hit happeth oft /

Ther com
also many sotyl flatererys and wise aduocatys in the lawe /

And whan thes folk to gidre assembled weren . This Mel-
libeus in sorweful wise shewid hem his cas /

And bi the ma-
neer of his speche hit seemed that in herte he bare a crvel
Ire / redy to do vengeauce vpon his foos / And sodenly desi-
red that the werre sholde begynne /

But nathirles yit askid
he her coūnseyl vpon this mateer .

A surgen bi lycence and
assent of such as wer wise Vp roos / and to Mellibe seyde
as ye may heere //

Sir qd he as to vs surgiens apparteneth
that we doon every wight the best that we can wher
as we witholde / and to our pacientes / that we doo no da-
mage /

wherfore hit happeth many tyme and oft / that whan
too men han everiche wounded othir / o same surgyen hee-
lith hem both

wherfore vn to our arte hit is nat ꝑpertynent
to norissh werre / ne partyes supporte /

But also certys as
to the warysshyng of your doighter / al be hit so / that she
perlously be woudid / we shul do so entendyff bisynesse /
fro day to nyght / that with the garace of god / she shal ben
hool and soūnde / as soone as is possible //

Almost right in þe
same wise / the phisiciens answerd / save that thei seyden
a fewe wordis more

That right as maladies ben curyd
by her contararijs / right so shal man warisshe werre bi ven-
geauce /

his nyghbours ful of envye / his freendis feyned
that seemed reconsiled / his flatereris

maaden semblaut
of weepyng / and empeyred and engendred mochil of his
mateer / In preisyng gretly Mellibe of myght of power
of richesse and of freendis / dispreisyng the poweer of
his aduersaries /

and seide vttirly that he anoon shold wreke
hym on his foos and begyn werre

Up roos than / an aduocat that was wys / bi leve
⁊ bi cousayl of othir that were wise and seyde /

lordynges the neede for which we ben assembled in this
place is wol hevy thyng / and an high mateer

bi cause of
wrong and of wrechidnesse that hath be doon and eek by
resou of the grete damages that in tyme comyng ben
possible to fallen / for the same cause

and eek bi resou of
grete riches and power of the partyes bothe

For the which
resoun hit were wol grete pereyl erryn in this mateer /

wherfore Mellibeus this is our sentence we consaylen you
aboven alle thyng that right anoon / thou doo thi diligence
in keepyng of thi propir persone in such a wise / that thou
ne wante noon espye ne watssh thi body for to save

And
aftir that / we consayl the / that in thi hous thou sette suf-
ficiant garrisou So that thou may as wel thi bodi as thin
hous diffende

But certis for to meve werre no sodeynly
for to doo vengeauce / we may not deeme in so litel tyme /
that hit were profytable
