how she fond his aduersaries repentaūnt /

knowlechyng wol
lowly her synnes and trespaces / and thei weer reedy to suffren
al peyne /
requiryng and prayeng hym of mercye and pite

Thanne seide Mellibe / he is wel worthy to haue pardou
and foryeuenesse of his synne / that excusith nat his
synne

but knowlechith his synne and repentith hym / as-
kyng indulgence /

For Senek seith ther is remyssiou and for-
yeuenesse where as confessiou is /

for confessiou is neihborur
to Innocence /

And therfore I assent and conf me to
haue pees

But it is good that we doon it vn to as-
sent and will of our freendis /

than was Prudence right glad
and ioyeful and seide /

Certys ꝸser qd she ye han wel and
dly answerde

For riht as bi the couseil and assent and help
of your freendis ye han be sterid to venge you and
werre

right so withouten coūnseil of hem ye shal nat accorde
you ne haue pees with your aduersaries /

For the lawe seith
Ther is no thyng so good bi weye of kynde as a thyng to ben
onboude bi hym / that it was boūnde /

And thanne Dame
Prudence withoute delay or taryeng / sent anoon hir messa-
ges for hir kyn / and for hir olde freendis / which that wer
trewe and wise /

and tolde hem bi ordre in the presence of
Mellibe / al this mateer as it is aboue expressid and declarid /

and prayd hem that thei wolde yeuen her avis / what wer
best to doon in this neede /

And whan Mellibeus freendis
hadde taken her avis and delibaciou / of the forseide mateer
and hadde examyned it / by gret bisinesse and gret diligence
thei yaf ful couseil to haue pees and reste /

and that Mel-
libe sholde receyue with good hert his aduersaries to foryeue-
nesse and mercy /

And whan Dame Prudence had herd
thassent of hir lord Mellibe / and the couseil of his freendꝭes
accorden with hir wille and hir entenciou /

she was won-
dirly glad in hir herte and seide /

Ther is an old proverbe
qd she that seith that the goodnesse that thou myhtist doo
this day / doo it
and abide nat til to morwe /

And therfore
I couseil that ye send your messages such as ben discrete
and wise
on to your aduꝰersaries / tellyng hem on your half /
that yif thei wol trete of pees / and accord /

that thei wol
shapen hem to comen to vs withouten delay or taryeng / þe
which thyng ꝑperfourmed was in deed /

And whan thes tres-
passours and repentyng folk of their folies / that is to seye /
thaduersaries of Mellibe /

hadden herd / what the messangers
seiden to them /

thei wer right glad and ioyful and answerden
wol meekly and benyngly /

yeldyng graces and thankynges to
her lord Mellibe and to his companye /

and shoopen hem with-
oute delay / to gon with the messangers / and obeye to the cōm-
maūndmentis of her lord Mellibe /

And right anoon thei taken
her way to the court of Mellibe

and token with hem som
of her trewe freendis to make feith for hem / and for to be
her borwes /

And whan thei wer I come to the presence of
Mellibe / he seide hem thes wordes /

It stant thus qd Mellibe
and sooth it is that ye

causeles and withoutēm skyl and re-
sou

han doon gret Iniurijs and wronges to me / and to my
wif / and to my douhtir also /

for ye haue entred in to my
hous with violence /

and han doon such outrage that alle
men knowen wel that ye han deserued the deth

And ther-
fore will I knowe and wite of you

whethir ye wol putte
the punsshyng and the chastisyng and the vengeaūnce in þe
wille of me and of my wif Dame Prudence or wol ye
nat / for fayne wold I knowe .

Thanne the wisest of hem thre Answerd for them alle /
and seid /

sire qd he / ye knowen wel that we be on-
worthy to come to the court of so gret a lord / and so worthy
as ye ben /

For we han so gretly mystaken vs / and han offen-
did and gilt in such a wise ageyn your hih lordship /

that
trewly we han disseruyd deth /

But yit for so gret good-
nesse and debonairte / that alle the world witnessith on your
ꝑpersone

we submytten vs to thexcellence and benygnyte of
your gracious lordship /

and ben reedy to obeye to all your
cōmmaundementꝭes /

besekyng you that of your merciable pite /
ye wolde considre our gret repentaūnce / and lowe submissiou

and graūnte vs remyssiou of our gret outrageous trespas ⁊
offence /

For wel we knowen / that your liberal grace and mꝰercy
strechen hem ferther in to goodnesse / than doon our outrage
gyltes and trespassis in to wickednesse /

al be it that cursidly
and dampnably / we han agylt ageyn your high lordship /

Thanne Mellibe took hem vppe from the groude wol benyg-
nely /

and receyvid her obligacious and her bondis bi her othis
vpon her pleggis and borwes /

and assigned hem a certeyn day
to retourne on to his court /

for taccepte and receyve the sen-
tence and Iugement that Mellibe wold cōmmaunde to be doon
vpon hem bi causes affore seide /

which thynges ordeyned
euery man retourned on to his owne hous /

And whan þtat
Dame Prudence sauh hir tyme / she freyned and asked hir
lord Mellibe /

what vengeaūnce he thouhte to take on his
Aduersaries /

to which Mellibe answerde and seide / Cer-
tys qd he I thynk and purpose me fully

to disheriten
hem of alle that evir thei han / and for to put hem in exil
for evir /

Certis qd Dame Prudence / this wer a crwel
sentence / and mochel ageyn resoūn /

For ye ben riche I
nowh and haue noon need of othir mennys good /

And ye
myght lightly in this wise / geten you a coueytous name /

Which is a vicious thyng / and ouhte to ben eschewed of euꝰery
good man /

For aftir the sawe of the worde of thapostle /
Coueytise is the root of alle harmes /

And therfore it wer
bettir for you to leese moche good of your owne / than for
to take of her good in this maner //

For bettir it is to leese
good with worship / than it is to wynne good with vile-
nye and shame /

And euꝰery man ouhte to don his diligence
and his besynesse to getyn hym a good name /

And he shal
oonly besy hym in keepyng of his good name /

but he shal
so enforcen hym alwey to don som thynges / by which he
may renovestre his good name /

For it is I writen / that the olde
good loos or good name of a man is soon goon and passed whan
it is nat newed ne renovelid /

And as touchyng þtat ye wol ex-
ile your aduersaries

that thynketh me moch ageyn resou
and out of mesur /

considred the power that thei han youen
you / vpon hem self /

And it is wryten / that he is worthi
to leese his preuylege / that mysvsith the myht and the
power / that is youen hym /

And I seette caas ye myht en-
ioyne hem that peyne bi riht and bi lawe

which I trow
ye may nat doo /

I sey ye myht nat put it to execuciou
ꝑperauentur

and thanne wer it likly to retourne to the werr /
as it was beforn /

And therfore yif ye wol that men do
you obeisaūnce / ye moste deem mor curteisly /

This is to seyn /
ye moste yeue more esy sentencis and Iugementis /

For it is
writen / that he that most curteisly comaudith / to hym most
men obeieth /

And therfore I pray you in this necessite and
in this neede / ye cast you to ouercome your herte /

For Sene-
ca seith / that ourecometh his herte / ouercometh twies /

And
Tullius seith / Ther is no thyng so commendable in a gret
lord /

as whanne he is debonair and meek and appesith hym
lightly /

And I pray you that ye wol forbere you nowe for
to doon vengeaūnce

in such maner / that your good name may
ben kept and conserued /

and that men mon han cause and
mateer to preise you of pite and of mꝰercye /

and that ye haue
no cause to repent you of thyng / that ye don /

For Senek seith
he ouercōmmeth in an euyl tyme and maneer that repenteth
hym of his victorie //

Wherfore I paraye you lat mꝰercye be in your
herte

to theffect and thentent / that god almyghty haue mercye
in his laste Iugement

for seynt Iame seith in his Epistil / Iuge-
ment withowten mꝰercye shal be doon to hym that hath no
mercye of a nothir wiht /

Whanne Mellibe had herd the gret skiles and resous of
Dame Prudence / and hir wise informacoūns ⁊ techynges /

his herte gan tenclyne to the wille of his wif consideryng
hir entent /

enforced hym anoon / and assentid fully to werken
after hir couseil /

and thankid god of whom procedeth al vertu
and alle goodnesse / that hym sent a wif of so gret discreciou

And whan the day cam / the aduersaries shold apper in his
presence /
he spak to hem wol goodly / and seid in this wise /

Alle be it so / that of your pride and presumpciou and hih
folie / and of your negligence and onkonnyng

ye han mysbo-
rne you and trespassed on to me /

yet for as mochil as I see
and beholde your gret humylite /

and that ye be sory and re-
pentaute of your giltis

it constreyneth me to do you grace
and mercy /
wherfore I receyve you to my grace /

and foryeue
vttirlech alle theffencis Iniurijs and wronges / that ye han
do to me and myne /

to this effect / and to this eende / that god
of his eendles mꝰercye

wol at the tyme of our deyeng foryeve
vs our giltes / that we han trespaced to hym in this wrechid
world /

For doutles yif we be sory and repentaut of the syn-
nes and gyltes which we haue trespassed in the siht of our
lord god /
he is so fre and so merciable

that he wol foryeven
vs our giltes / and bryng vs to that blysse / that nevir shal haue
ende / AMEN .

div.l: Whanne eendid was / this tale of Mellibe
And of hir prudence / and benygnyte
Our hoost seide / as I am feithful man
And bi that precious body / Madryan
I had levir / than a barel of ale
That god lefe my wif / hadde herd this tale
She nys nothyng of such pacience
As was this Mellibeis wif prudence
By goddys bonys / whan I bete my knavis
She bryngeth me the gret clobbed stavis
And crieth sle the doggis euerichone
And breke bothe her bakkis and her bone
And yif that any neihbour of myne
Wol nat in chirche / on to my wife inclyne
Or be so hardy to her to trespace
Whan she cometh she raupeth in my face
And crieth fals cowerd wreke thi wiff
Bi corpus bonys / I wil haue thy knyff
And thou shalt haue my dystaf and go spynne
Fro day to nyht / right þus she wol begynne
Allas she seith that evir I was I shape
To wedde a mylk sop / or a coward ape
That wol ben ouerlad / of euery wight
Thou darst nat stonden / by thy wyues ryht
This is my lyf but if that I wol fight
And out at the dore / anoon I mot me dight
Or els I nam but lost / but if that I
But like a wilde lyon / fool hardy
I wot wel / she wol do me sle som day
Som neighbour / and thanne go my way
For I am pereilous / with a knyff in hoonde
Al be it / that I dar nat hir withstonde
For she is bygg / in Armys bi my feith
Yif that she fynde / that hir mysdoth or seith
But lat vs passe now / from this mateer
My lord the monk qd he / be mery of cheer
For ye shul telle / a tale trwly
Loo Rouchestre stant heer fast by
Ryde foorth myn owne lord / breke nat our game
But by my trouth / I can nat telle your name
Whethir shal I calle you / my lord Daune Iohn
Or Daune Thomas / or ellis Daune Alboūn
Of what hous be ye / by your fadir kynne
I vowe to god / thou hast a ful fayr skynne
It is a gentil pastour / ther thou gost
Thou art nat lik a penaut / or a goost
Vpon my feith / thou art som officeer
Som worthy sexteyn / or som Celereer
For by my soule as seemeth to my doom
Thou art a maister / whan thou art at hoom
No pouꝰer cloisterer / ne no novys
But a gouernour wyly and wys
And therwithal / of brau and eek of bonys
A wel faryng ꝑpersone / for the nonys
I pray to god / yeve hym confusiou
That the brouht first / in religiou
Thou woldist haue be / a credfoul wight
Haddist thou as gret leve / as thou hast mygh
To ꝑperfourme al thi lust / in engendrure
Thou haddist begotyn many a creature
Allas why werist thou / so wide a cope
God yeve me sorwe / but and I were a pope
Nat oonly thou / but euery myghty man
Thou he were shore / wol hih vpon his panne
Sholde haue a wif / for alle the world is lorne
Religiou hath take vp / alle the corne
Off credyng and we borel men be shrympis
Off feble treesth ther cometh wreched ympis
This maketh that our heires be so sklendre
And feble / that thei may nat wel engendre
This maketh that our wyues wolen assaye
Religious folk for ye may bettir paye
Of venus paymentis / than may we
God wot no lushbournes pay ye
But be nat wroth / lord thouh that I pleie
Wol oft in game / a soth I haue herd seie
This worthi monk / took al in pacience
And seide / I wol doon al my diligence
As ferre as sowneth / in to honeste
To telle you a tale / or too or thre
And if ye list to herken hidirward
I wol you seyn / the lyf of seynt Edward
Or ellis Tragedies / wol I telle
Of which I haue / an hundred in my celle
Tragedie is to seyn / a certeyn storye
As old bookis / maken vs memorye
Off hym that stood / in gret prosꝑperite
And is I fallyn out of hih degre
In to myserie / and eendith wrechedly
And thei ben versified / comouly
Off sex feet / which men clepyn exameron
In prose eeke / ben ditid many oon
And eeke in metre / many a sondry wise
Lo this declaryng ouht I nouh suffise
Now herkenyth yif you lyketh for to heere
But first I you beseke / in this mateere
Thouh I bordre / telle nat this thynges
Be it of popis / Emꝑperours or kynges
Aftir her Agis / as men writen fynde
But telle som before / and som behynde
As it now cometh / in to my remembrauce
Haueth me excused / of myn igorauce

l.hi: Et incipit narracio euildem de eodem .

div.l: I wol bewreie / in maner of Tragedie
The harm of hem / that stood in hih degre
And fillen so / that ther nas remedie
To bryng hem out / of her aduersite
For certeyn / whanne that fortune lest to flee
Ther may no man / the cours of hir witholde
Lat no man triste / on blynde prosꝑperite
Be ware of thes / ensauples / trewe and olde
At lucifer / thouh he Angil were
And a man / at hym I wol begynne
For thouh fortune / may noon Angil dere
Fro hih degre / yit fille he for synne
Dou in to helle / wher that he is Inne
O lucifer bryhtest / of Angelis alle
Nowe art thou Sathanas / thou maist nat twynne
Of myserie / in which thou art I falle
Lo Adam / in the feeld of Damassene
Which bi goddis owne fynger / wrouht was he
And nat begoten / of mannes sperme vnclene
And welth of paradise / sauyng oon tree
Had nevir erthly man / so high degree
As Adam til he for mysgouernaunce
Was dryven out / of his ꝓprosperite
To labour / and to tele / and to myschaunce
Lo Sampson / which that was Anūnciat
Bi the Angil / long er his natyuyte
And was to god almyhty / consecrat
⁊ stood in noblesse / whil he myht see
Was neuyr such anothir / as was he
To speke of strenghte / and therwith hardynesse
But to his wyfes / told he his secree
Thorugh whiche / he slough hym silf for wrecchidnesse
Sampson this myhty / and noble champion
Withowten wepyn / sauf his hondes tweye
He slouh and al to rent / the leon
Toward his weddyng / walkyng bi the weye
His fals wif / cowde hym so plese and preye
Til she his cownsel knewe / and she vntrewe
Vnto his foes / his couseil gan bewreye
And hym forsook / and took anothir newe
Thre hundird foxes / took Sampson for Ire
And al her tayles / he to gidre bond
And sette tho foxes tayles / alle on fyre
For he / ouꝰery tayl / had knyt a brond
And thei brent / alle the cornes in that lond
And alle ther Olyves / and vynes eeke
A thousend men / he slowh eeke with his hond
And hadde no wepyn / but an Asses Cheeke
Whan thei were sleyne / so thurstid hym / that he
Was wol ner lorn / for which he gan to pray
That god wold of his peyne / haue som pite
And sende hym drynk / or ellis must he deye
And of this Asses cheeke / that was drye
Out of a wang toth / anoon ther sprang a welle
Of whiche he drank Inowh / shortly to seye
Thus halp hym god / as Iudicu can telle
By verray force / at Gasan on a nyht
Maugre the philistiens / of that Cite
The gatis of the towne / he hath vp pliht
And on his back / I caried hem hath he
Hih on an hill / wher as men myht hem see
O noble / o myghty sampson leef and dere
Haddest thou nat tolde / to women thi secree
In alle this world / hadde noon be thi peere
This Sampson nevir cider drank nor wyn
Ne on his hede / cam rasour n ne sheere
By precept of the messanger dyvyn
For alle his strenghtis in his heris werre
And fully .xx.ti wynter yere bi yeere
He hadde of Israel / the gouernauce
But soone shal he wreye many a teere
For wōmmen shal hym bryng / to myschauce
Vnto his lemman Dalyda he tolde
That in his heere alle his strenght laye
And falsly to his fomen she hym solde
And sleepyng in hir harme / vpon a daye
She maad to clippe or sheere / his heere awaye
And made his fomen / alle his craft espyen
And whan thei hym fond / in this arraye
Thei bouden hym fast / and putten out his eyen
But er his heere / wer I clippid or I shave
Ther was no bond / with whiche men myht hym bynde
But nowe is he in prisoūn / in a cave
Wher as thei made hym / at querne grynde
O noble Sampson / strengest of mankynde
O whilom Iugge / in glorie and in richesse
Nowe maist thou weepe / with thyn eyen blynde
Sith thou from wele / art falle in to wrechidnesse
The eende of this caityff / was I shalle seye
His fomen maden / a feste vpon a day
And made hym as her fool / to forn them pleye
And this was a temple of gret array
But at last / he made a foul affray
For he too pileers shook / and made hem falle
That dou fell temple and al / and ther it lay
And slouh hym silf / and eeke his fomen alle
This is to seyn the pirinces euerichoūn
And eeke / thre thousand es wer there slayn
With fallyng of the gret temple / of stoūn
Of Sampson now / wol I nomore seyn
Beware bi this exapls / eke and pleyn
That no man telle coūnseil / to his wiff
Of which thyng / he wolde haue secre feyn
Yf that it tuch / her lymes / or her lyff
Of hercules the souerayn conquerour
Syngen his werkes / laude and hih renou
For in his tyme of strengh he was the flour
He slowh and refte / the skyn / of the leoūn
He of Centouris / leid the boste a dou
He slouh Arpis / the cruel briddis felle
The golden Aples / reft of the dragou
He drouh out Cerberus / the hound of helle
He slouh the cruel tyraut / Busirus
And maad his hors / to frete hym flessh and bon
He slouh the fers serpent / venymous
Off Achilles too hornys / he brak oon
And he slouh Cacus / in a Cave of stoon
He slouh a giaut / Antheus the stronge
He slouh the grisly boore / and that anoon
And bare the hevene / on his neck longe
Was nevir wiht / sith the worlde began
That slouhe so many / monstris as did he
Thoruh out this wide world / his name ran
What for his strengh / and his hih boute
And euery rewme / went hym for to see
He was so strong / that noman myht hym lette
At bothe thes worldis eendis / seith Trophe
In stede of boundis / he a piler sette
A lemman hadde / this noble champiou
That hiht Deanra / as fressh as any may
And thes Clerkes / maken menciou
She hath hym sent a shert fressh and gay
Allas this shert / allas and welaway
Envenymed it was / so subtily with alle
That er he hadde / I werid it half a day
Hit made his flessh alle from his bonys falle
But nathelus / clerkes hir excusen
Bi oon that hihte Neseus / that it maked
Be as be may / I wille hir nat accusen
But on his back this shert he werid alle naked
Till that his flessh was for the venym blaked
And whan he sauh / noon othir remedie
In hoot Coolis / he hath hym silf raked
For with venym / deyned hym to dye
Thus starf / this worthi myhty hercules
Loo what man trustith on fortune any throwe
For hym that folwed alle this world of prees
Er he be war / is ofte leide ful lowe
Wol wis is he / that kanne hym silf knowe
Of euery happe / in text and eeke in glose
Be ware for whanne / that fortune lest to throwe
By such a way as he wol lest suppose
The myhty throne / the precious tresour
The glorious Septre / and roial maieste
That hadde the kyng / Nabugodonosor
With tong vneth may descryved be
He twies wan Ierusalem the Cite
The vessel of the temple he with hym ladde
At Babilonye was his souereyn see
In which his glorie / and his delit he hadde
The fayrest children / off the blood roiall
Off Israel / he lette do gelde anoon
And maked ech of hem / to ben his thrall
Amonges othir / Danyel was oon
That was the wisest / childe of euerichoon
For he the dremys / of the kyng expowned
Wher as Caldei clerk / ne was ther noon
That wist to what fyn / his dremys sowned
This proude kyng / leet make a statue of gold
Cubitis long / and sevene in breede
To which ymage / he both yong and old
Comauded to loute / and haue in dreede
Or in a furneys / fulle of flawme reede
He sholde be brent / that wolde nat obeye
But nevir wolde assent / to that deede
Danyel ne his yonge felawis tweye
This kyng of kyngis proude was and elat
He wende god / that sittith in maieste
Ne myht nat hym bereve of his estate
But sodenly / he leste his dygnyte
And like a beste / hym seemed for to be
And eet hey as an oxe / and lay theroute
In reyne with wilde beestis walked he
Til certeyn tyme / was comen aboute
And lik an Eglys fetherys / wex his heeris
His nailes lik a briddes clawis were
Til god relesid hym / at certeyn yeris
And yaf hym wit / and thanne with many a teere
He thanked god and evir his lif in feere
Was he to doon amys or more trespace
And til that tyme he leide was on his beere
He knewe that god was fulle of myht and grace
This sone which / that hiht Balthasar
That held the Regne / aftir his fadris day
He bi his fadir cowde nat be war
For prowde he was of herte and of array
And eeke an ydolatre / was he ay
His estat assured hym in pride
But fortune cast hym dou / and ther he lay
And sodenly his Regne gan devide
A feste he made to his lordis alle
Vpon a tyme / and made hem blithe be
And thanne his Officers / gan he calle
Gooth bryngeth foorth / the vesselis qd he
Which that my fadir / in his prosꝑperite
Out of the temple of Ierusalem beraft
And to our hih goddis / thank we
Off honour / that our eldris with vs laft
His wiff his lordis / and his Concubynes
Ay dronken whil her appetites laste
Out of thes noble vesselis / sondry wynes
And on a wal this kyng his eyne caste
And sauh an hond armeles that wrot wol faste
For feere of which he quook and sighed sore
This hand that Balthasar / made so sore agaste
Wrote Mane / Techel Phares and no more
In alle that lond / magicien was ther noon
That cowde expowne / what this lettir mente
But Danyel expowned hit anoon
And seide kyng god to thy fadir lente
Gold honour / regne / tresour and rente
And therfor wreche / god vpon hym sente
And he was proud / and nothyng god ne dradde
And hym berafte / the Regne that he hadde
H outcast off mannys companye
assis was his habitaciou
And eet hey as a beeste / in weete and drye
il that he knewe / bi grace and bi resou
That god of heven / hath domynaciou
ir euery Regne / and euery creature
And thanne hadde god / of hym compassiou
And hym restorid his Regne and his figure
eke thou that art his sone / art proud also
d knowist alle thes thynges verraily
And art rebel to god / and art his fo
Thou drank eeke of his vessil boldely
Thi wiff eeke / and thy wenchis synfully
Dronke of the same vesselis / sondry wynes
And heriest fals goddis / cursidly
Therfore gret peyne / to the shapen is
The hand was sent fro god / that on the walle
Wroot Mane Techel Phares truste me
Thi Regne is dou / thou weyist nat al atalle
Devided is thi Regne / and it shal be
To Meedis and perses qd he
And thilke same nyht / the kyng was slawe
And Darynes occupieth his degre
Thouh he therto / hadde neithir riht ne lawe
Lordynges herby / exauple may ye take
Howe that in lordshipe / is no sikernesse
For whan fortune will a man forsake
He berith away his regne and his richesse
And his frendis / both more and lesse
For who that hath / freendis thoruh fortune
Myshap will make hem / enemyes as I gesse
This proverble is wol sooth / and wol comune
CEnobia off palmerie qweene
As writeth parcens / of hir noblesse
So worthy was in Armys / and so keene
That no wiht passed hir / in hardynesse
Ne in lynage / ne in othir gentilnesse
Off kynges blood / off Perce is she descendid
I sey nat that / she hadde most fayrnesse
But of hir shap / she myght nat ben amendid
From hir childhood I fynde that she fledde
Office of wōmmen and to wodde she wente
And many a wilde hertis blood she shedde
With Arwes brode / that she to hem sente
She was so swift that she anoon hem hente
And whan that she / was eldere she wolde kille
Leous liberdis and beris all to rente
And in hir Armys welden hem at hir wille
She durst wilde beestis dennys seeke
And Rennyn in the mouteyns / alle the nyht
And slepyn vndir the busshe / and she cowde eeke
Wrastle bi verrai fors and verray myht
With any yong man wer he nevir so wiht
Ther myht no thyng / in hir Armys stonde
She kept hir maydenhed / from euery wiht
To no man deyned she / to be bonde
But atte laste / hir freendis han hir maried
To Ovedake / a prynce off that contre
Alle wer it so / that she hym longe taried
And ye shul vndirstonde / how that he
Hadde such fantasies / as hadde she
But nathirles / whanne thei were knyt in feere
Thei lyued in ioye and in felicite
For eche of hem hadde othir leeff and deere
S thyng that she wolde nevir assente
By no weye that he sholde bi hir lye
ut onys for hit was hir pleyn entente
haue a childe the world to multiplye
And also soone as she myht hit aspye
at she was nat with childe with that deede
Thanne wolde she suffre hym doon his fantasye
onys and nat but onys out off dreede
And yif she were / with childe that ilke cast
Ne more sholde he pleye that ilke game
fully fourty dayes / wer I past
Than wolde she suffre hym / oonys doon the same
Alle were this Ovedake wilde or tame
He gat of hir no more / for thus she saide
Hit was to wyues lechery and shame
In othir caas yf men with hem plaide
Too sonys bi this Ovedake hadde she
The which she kept in vertu and lettrure
But nowe vnto our tale / turne we
I seye so worshipful a creature
And wys therwith / and large with mesure
So penyble in the werre / and curteys eeke
Ne more labour / myht in werre endure
Was noon / thouh alle this world men sholde seeke
Hir riche array / myht nat ben I told
As wele in vessel / as in hir clothyng
She was al clad / in perre and in gold
And eeke she left nat / for noon huntyng
To haue of sondry tonges / ful knowyng
Whanne that she hadde leiser / and for tentende
To lerne bookis was alle hir lykyng
How she in vertu / myht hir lyff dispende
And shortly of this story / forto trete
So doughty was hir hosbonde and eeke she
That thei conquerid many Regnes grete
In thorient with many a fair Cite
Aꝑpertynaut / to the maieste
Of Rome / and with strong hond heeld hem faste
Ne nevir hir fomen doon hem flee
Ay whil that Ovedakes / dayes laste
Her batailes who list hem for to reede
Ageyn Sapor the kyng and othir mo
And how that alle this processe felle in deede
Whi she conquerid / and what title therto
Aftir of hir myscheffe / and hir woo
How that she was beseegid / and I take
Lat hym to his maister Petrak go
That writh Inouh / of this I vndirtake
Whanne Ovedake was dede she myhtily
The regnes heeld / and with hir propir hond
Ageyns hir foos / she fouht so cruelly
That ther nas kyng / ne prynce in al that lond
That he nas glad / of hir that grace fond
That she ne wold / vpon his lond werrey
With hir thei maden / alliauce with bond
To ben I pees and lat hir ryde and pleye
Themꝑperour of Rome Claudius
Ne hym beforn the Romayn Galien
Ne durst nevir / be so coragious
Ne noon Ermen / ne noon Egipcien
Ne Surrien / ne noon Arabien
Withinne the feeldis / ne durst with her fight
Lest that she wolde hem / with hir hond slen
Or with hir meyne / putten hem to flight
I habit / went hir sonnys too
As heiris of her fadris regne alle
And heremanus / and eek Thymalo
Her namys wer / as Parciens hem calle
But ay fortune hath in hir hony galle
This myhty queene / may no while endure
Fortune hir made / out of Regne falle
To wrechidnesse / and mysaventure
Avrelian whan that the gouernauce
Off Rome cam / in to his hondis tweye
He shoop vpon this queen / to do vengeauce
And with his legions / he took his weye
Toward Cenobie / and shortly forto seye
He made hir flee / and atte laste hir hente
And wanne the lond / and home to Rome went
And feterid hir / and eeke hir children tweye
Amonges othir thynges / that he wan
Hir chare that was / with gold wrouht and perre
This gret Romayn / this Aurelian
Hath with hym lad / for that men shold it see
Bifore his tryvmphe / walketh she
With gylt cheyne / on hir necke hangyng
Crowned was she / as aftir hir degre
And fulle of perre / chargid hir clothyng
Allas fortune / she that whilom was
Dreedful to kynges / and to Emꝑperours
Now gavreth al the poeple / on hir allas
And she that helmed was / in stark shours
And wanne bi force / townys strong and towrs
Shal on her hed / were a vitryte
And she that bar / the sceptre fulle of flours
Shal bere a dystaff / his cost for to quyte
Althouh Nero that was so vicious
As any feend / that lith lowe a dou
Yit as tellith Svetonious
This wide world / he hadde in subiecciou
Bothe Est and west North and Septentriou
Of Rubies Saphirs / and of perlis white
Were alle his clothis / brawdyd vp and dou
For he in Gemmys / gretly gan delyte
More delycat more pompous of array
More proude was nevir Emꝑperour than he
That ilke cloth that he hadde werid a day
Aftyr that tyme / he wolde it nevir see
Nettis of gold threde / hadde he gret plente
To fysshe in Tibre / whan hym list pleye
His lustis wer al lawe / in his decre
For fortune as his freende / hym wolde obeye
He Rome brent for his delicacie
The Senatours he slouh vpon a day
To heere how men wolde weepe and crie
And slouh his brothir / and bi his sustir lay
His moodir he made / in pitous array
For hir wombe / he slitte to beholde
Wher he conceyved was / so weleaway
That he so litel / of his moodir tolde
No teere out of his eien / for that sight
Ne cam / but seide a fair womma was she
Gret woundir hit is / how that he cowde or myght
Be domys man / of hir dede beavte
The wyne to bryngen / anoon comaudid he
And drank anoon / noon othir wo he maade
Whan myht is ioyned / onto cruelte
Allas to deepe / wol the venym wade
aister / hadde this Emꝑperour
lettirure / and curtesie
moralite / he was the flour
his tyme but the bookis lie
whil this maister / hadde of hym maistrie
de hym so lovyng / and so sovple
ong tyme to was / er tyrannye
Or any vice durste in hym on covple
This Seneca of which I devise
By cause that Nero hadde of hym such dreede
he from vices / wolde hym ay chastyse
Discreetly as bi woord / and nat bi deede
Sire wold he seyn / an Emꝑperour mot neede
Be ertuous and hate tyrannye
For which in a bath / made hym to bleede
On both his Armys / til he moste deie
This Nero hadde eeke of custumauce
In youth ageyns his maister to arise
Which aftirward hym thouhte a gret grevauce
Therfore he made hym deyen / in this wise
But natheles / this Seneca this wise
Ches in a bath to deie in this maneere
Rather thanne han anothir turmentrise
And thus hath Nero slayn his maister deere
Now fil it so / that fortune list no lengere
The hid pride of Nero to cherice
For thouh that he was strong / yit was she strengere
She thouht thus / be god I am to nyce
To sette a man / that is fulfilled with vice
In hih degre / and hym an Emꝑperour calle
Bi god out of his see / I wol hym trice
Whan he leste wenyth / sonnest shal he falle
The poeple arros / vpon hym on a nyht
For his defawte / and whan he it aspide
Out of his doris / anoon he hath hym diht
Allone and ther he wende ha ben allied
He knokkid faste / and ay the more he cried
The faster shette the dorys alle
For dreede of this / hym thouht that he died
And went his way / no lenger durst he calle
The poeple cried and rombled vp and dou
That with his eris / herd he how thei seide
Wher is this false tyraūnt this Nerou
For feere almost / out of his witte he breide
And to his goddis / pitously he praiede
For socour / but it myght nat bynde
For dreede of this / hym thought þtat he deiede
And ran in to a gardyn / hym to hide
And in this gardyn / fonde the cherlis tweye
That setyn be a fier / gret and rede
And to this cherlis / fast he gan to preye
To slen hym / and to gerdyn of his hede
That to his body / whan that he were dede
Wer no despyt I do / for his diffame
Hym silf he slouh / he cowde no bettir rede
Of which / fortune louh and hadde game
WAs nevir Capitan vndir a kyng
That regneth / more put in subiecciou
Ne strengere was / in feeld off alle thyng
As in his tyme / no greeter of renou
Ne more pompous / in hih presumpciou
Than holoferne which fortune ay kiste
So likerously / and lad hym vp and dou
Til that his hede was off / er that he wiste
Nat oonly that this worlde hadde hym in Awe
For leesyng of richesse or liberte
But made euery man / to reneie his lawe
Nabugodonosor was god seid he
Noon othir god sholde honoured be
Ageyns his heste durst no man trespace
Sauff in Bethulia a strong Cite
Wher Eliachym / a preest was of that place
Butte take kepe / of the deth of holoferne
Amyd his hoost / he dronke lay al a nyht
Withinne his tente large as a berne
And yit for alle his pompe and alle his myht
Iudith a womma / as he lay vpriht
Slepyng his hede of smot and from his tente
Wol privily she stal from euery wiht
And with his hed onto her tou she wente
What needith it off kyng Antiochus
To telle his heie roial maieste
His heie pride his werkis venymous
For such anothir was ther noon as he
Reede which he was in Machabe
And reede the proude woordis that he seide
And why he felle from his hih prosꝑperite
And in a hil / howe wrecchidly he deide
Fortune hym hadde / enhauced so in pride
That verraily he wende / he myght attayne
Vnto the sterris vpon euery side
And in balaūnce weyen ech montayne
And alle the floodis of the see restrayne
And goddis poeple / hadde he most in hate
Hem wolde he slen in turment and in peyne
Wenyng that god ne myght his pride abate
And for that Nichanor and Thymothe
With Iewes were / venquysshed myhtilye
Onto the Iewes / such an hate had he
That he bad greith his char wol hastilye
And swore and seid / wol dispitously
Onto Ierusalem he wolde eft sone
To wreken his Ire on it wol cruelly
But of his purpose / he was let ful soone
God for his manace / hym so sore smote
With invisible woudes ay incurable
That in his guttis / karf it so and bote
That his peynes wer importable
And certeynly / the wreche was resoūnable
For many a mannys guttis dede he peyne
But fro his purpos / cursid and dampnable
For alle his smert wolde he nat restreyne
But bad anoon / apparailen his hoost
And sodenly er he was of hym war
God dampned his pride and alle his boost
For he so sore / felle out of his char
That his lemys and his skyn to tar
So that he myht go ne ride
But in a char men about hym bar
Alle forbrused / bothe back and side
The wrech of god / hym smoot so cruelly
That thoruh his body / wicked wormes crept
And therwithal / he stank so horribly
That noon of al his mene / that hym kept
Whethir so he wook or ellis slept
Ne myht nat / the stench of hym endure
In this myscheeff / he wailed and eeke wept
And knew god / lord of euery creature
To alle his hoost and to hym also
Wol lothsom / was the stynk careyne
No man mygh bere hym to ne fro
And in this stynk and this horrible peyne
He starff wol wrechedly / in a moutayne
Thus hath this rabbour and this homycide
That many a man to weepe and pleyne
Such guerdou as belongeth onto pride
The storye of Alisaudre is so comune
That euery wiht that hath discreciou
Hath herd somwhat or al of his fortune
This wide worlde as in conclusiou
He wanne bi strenghe or for his hih renou
Thei were glad / for pees to hym sende
The pride of man and beest / he leide adou
Wherso he cam / in to the worldis eende
Comparison myht nevir yit be maked
Betueyon hym and anothir conquerour
For alle this world / for drede of hym hath quaked
He of knyghthood / and of fredam the flour
Fortune hym maade the heir off hir honour
Sauff wyne and woman / nothyng myht aswage
His hih entente / in Armys and labour
So was he fulle / of leonyn corage
What price wer it to hym / thouh I you tolde
Of Daryus / and of an hundrid thousend mo
Of kynges prynces / Dukes Erles bolde
Which he conquerid / and brouht hem in to wo
I seye as ferre / as men myht ride or go
The worlde was his / what shold I more devise
For thouh I wrote / and told you evir mo
Off his knyhthood / it myht nat suffise
Twelfe yere he regned as seide Machabe
Philippes sone of Macedonye he was /
That first was kyng of greece the contre
O worthy gentil Alisaudre / allas
That evir sholdist falle / in such a cas
Enpoisownd of thyn owne folk thou were
Thi Sys fortune hath torned in to aas
And for that she / ne wept neviradele
Who shal yeue me teris to compleyne
The deth of gentilnesse and of frauchise
That al this world wildid in his demeyne
And yit hym thouhte it myht nat suffise
So fulle was his corage / of hih emprise
Allas who shal me help tendite
Fals fortune / and poisou to despise
The which too of al this woo I wite
By wisdam manhood / and also gret labour
From humylhede / to hih mageste
Vp roos he Iulius the conquerour
That wan thoccident / bi lond and se
Bi strengh of hond or ellis bi trete
And onto Rome / mad hym tributarie
And sith of Rome Emꝑperour was he
Til that fortune / wex his aduersarie
O myhty Cesar that in Thessalie
Ageyns Pompeious / fadir thyn in lawe
That of thorient / had al his chevalrie
As ferr as that the day / begynneth dawe
Thou thoruh thi knyhthood hast hem take and slawe
Sauf fewe folk that with pompeious fledde
Thoruh which thou puttist al thorient in Awe
Thank fortune that so wel the spedde
B now a litel whil / I wol bewaile
This mpeious / this noble gouernour
Of e which that fley at this batail
I sey oon of his men a fals traitour
His hed of smot to wynnen his fauour
Of Iulius / and hym the hed he brouhte
Allas Pompeie of thorient conquerour
t fortune onto such a fyne the brouht
o Rome ageyn repaireth Iulius
With his tryumphe lavreat wol hie
But on a tyme Brutus Cassius
That evir hadde of his hihe stat envie
Wol pryvily hath maade conspiracie
Agayns this Iulius in subtil wise
And caste the place / in which he sholde die
With boidekynes as I shal you devise
This Iulius to the Capitolie wente
Vpon a day as he was wont to goon
And in the Capitolie anoon hym hente
This fals Brutus and his othir foon
And stiked hym with boidekenys anoon
With many a woude and thus thei lete hym lie
But nevir gronte he at no strok but oon
Or ellis at too but if storye lie
So manly was this Iulius of hert
And so wel lovid estaatly honeste
That thouh his dedly woudes so sore smert
His mantyl ovir his hepys cast he
For no man sholde see his pryvitee
And as he lay deieng in a trauce
And wist verraily / that dede was he
Off honeste / yit hadde remembrauce
Lucan to the / this story I comende
And to sweton / and to valerius also
That of the story / wryten word and ende
How that these gret conquerours too
Fortune was first freend / and sithen a foo
No man truste vpon hir fauour longe
But haue hit in a wayte / for evir moo
Witnesse on alle conquerours stronge
This Ryche Creesus / whilom kyng of lide
Of which Cresus Cirus sore hym dradde
Yit was he cauht amyddis al his pride
And to be brent men to the fier hym ladde
But such areyn dou from the walkyn shadde
That slouh the fier and made hym tescape
But to be war no grace yit he ne hadde
Til fortune on the galwes made hym gape
Whan he escapid was he cowde nat stynte
For to begynne a newe werre ageyne
He wend wel / for that fortune hym sente
Such hap / that he escapid thoruh the reyne
That of his foos / he myht nat be sleyne
And eeke a sweven vpon a nyht he mette
Of which he was proud and eeke so fayne
That in vengeauce / he alle his herte sette
Vpon a tre he was as hym thouht
Ther Iubiter hym wesshe / bothe bak and side
And phebus also a fair towail hym brouht
To drie hym with and therwith wext his pride
And to his douhtir / that stood hym beside
Which that he knew in hih sentence haboude
He bad hir telle / what it signifiede
And she his dremes gan thus and expoude
The tre qd she Galwes is to meene
And Iubitꝰer betokenyth snow and reyne
And phebus with his towail so cleene
Tho ben the sonne bemys forto seyne
Thou shalt I honged be / fadir certeyne
Reyne shal the wysshe and sonne shal the drie
Thus she warned hym / al plat and pleyne
His douhtir which / that called was Phanye
And hanged was Cresus this proude kyng
His roial throne myht hym nat availe
Tragedie no othir maner thyng
Ne can in syngyng crie ne bewaile
But that fortune alway wol assaile
With onware stroke the regnes that ben proude
For whan men truste in hir / than wol she faile
And kevir hir briht face / with a cloude
O Noble o worthy Petre / glorie of Spayne
Whom fortune helde / so hih in mageste
Wel ouhten men thi pitous deth complayne
And aftir at a seege be subtilite
Thi brodir made the to fle
Thou were betraied and lad onto his tente
Wher as he with his owne hond slouh the
Succedyng in thi regne / and in thy rente
The feeld of snow with Egle and blak withinne
Cauht with the lymrod / coloured as the gleede
He brewe this cursidnesse / and al this synne
The wicked nest / was werker of this neede
Nat Charlys Olyuer that took ay heede
Of trouth and honour / but of Armorike
Geneleun / Olyuer corrupt for neede
Brouht this worthy kyng / in such a brike
O worthy Petre / kyng of Cipre also
That Alisaudre wan / bi hih maistrie
Wol many an hethen man / wrouhtist thou wo
Of which thyn owne lieges / hadden envie
And for nothyng / but for thi chevalrie
Thei in thi bed / han sleyn the bi the morwe
Thhus kanne fortune / hir wheele gouerne and guye
And out of ioye bryng men to sorwe
OF Melan gret Barnabo viscounte
God of delite and scorge of lombardie
Whi shold I nat thyn Infortune accoute
Sith in estat / thou clombe were so hihie
Thi brothir sone / that was thi double alie
For he thi nevew was and sone in lawe
Withinne his prisou / made the to die
But why ne how / wot I that thou wer slawe
OF Erl hughelyn of Pise the langour
Ther may no tonge / tellyn for pite
But litel out of Pise / stant a tour
In which tour in prison put was he
And with hym be / his litel children thre
Theldest scarsly / fyve yere was of age
Allas fortune it was gret cruelte
Such yong briddis / to put in such a cage
Dampned was he / to die in that prisou
For Roger which that bisshop was of Pise
Had on hym made / a fals suggestiou
Thoruh which the poeple vpon hym gan rise
And put hym to prisou / in such a wise
As ye han herd / and mete and drynk he hadde
So smal / that onethe it may suffise
And therwithalle it was ful poore and badde
And on a day befel / that in that hour
Whan that his mete wont was to be brouht
The Ieailer shette the dore of the tour
He herd it wele / but he spak riht nouht
And in his herte anoon ther fil a thouht
That thei for hungir / wolde doon hym dien
Allas qd he / allas that I was wrouht
Therwith the teris / fillen from his eien
His yong sone / that thre yere was of age
Vnto hym seide / fadir whi do ye weepe
Whan wol the Gailer / bryng your potage
Is ther no morsel bred / that ye doon keepe
I am so hongry / that I may nat sleepe
Now wold god I myht slepe for evir
Than sholde nat hongyr / in my wombe creepe
Ther is no thyng but brede / that me wer levir
Thus day bi day / this child gan to crie
Til in his fadris Armys dou it lay
And saide farwel fadir I mot die
And kist his fadir / and deied the same day
And whan the woful fadir / ded it say
For wo his Armys too / he gan to bite
And seid allas fortune / and wele a way
Thi fals wheel / my wo al may I wite
His childryn wenden that for hungyr it was
That he his Armys gnewe / and nat for wo
And seiden fadir do nat so allas
But rather eete the flessh vpon vs too
Our flessh thou yaff / take our flessh vs fro
And eete Inovh / riht to hym thei seide
And aftir that withinne a day or too
Thei leiden hem in his lappe adou and deied
Hym silf dispeired / eeke for hunger starff
Thus eendid this myhty erl of Pise
From hih estat fortune away hym carff
Of this Tragedie / it n ouhte Inouh suffise
Who so wol it heer in lenger wise
Reedith the gret poete of ytaile
That hihte Daunt for he can it devise
Fro poynt to poynt nat o worde wol he faile
HO qd our hoost / sire nomore of this
That ye han seid / is riht Inouh I wis
And mochil more / for litel hevynesse
Is riht ynouh to moche folk I gesse
Your talis don vs I sey for me / hit is a gret disese
Wher as men haue ben in gret welth and ese
To here of her sodeyn falle allas
And the contrarye is Ioye and gret solas
And whan a man hath be / in poor estat
And clymbeth vp / and waxeth fortunat
And ther abidith in prosꝑperite
Such thyng is gladsom as thynketh me
And of such thyng / were goodly for to telle
Ya qd our hoost / bi seynt poules belle
Ye sey soth / this monk hath clappid lowd
He spak how fortune / couꝰered was with a clowd
I nat nere what / and also tragedie
Riht now ye herde / and parde no remedie
s forto be wailyng and compleyne
Nor that that is don / and also it is a peyne
As ye han seid to heer of hevynesse
Sir monk nomore of this so god you blesse
r tale anoyeth / alle this companye
Such thyng is nat worth a bottirflye
ur talys don vs ne disport ne game
Wherfore sire monk / Adam Peers bi your name
I pray you hertily / telle vs somwhat ellis
For sikerly / ner clykyng of your bellis
That on your bridil / hang on euery side
Bi heven kyng that for vs alle deiede
I sholde er this / falle a dou for sleepe
All thouh the sloouh / hadde nevir be so deepe
Than hadde your tale / al be tolde in veyne
For certeynly as that thes clerkis seyne
Wher as a man may haue no audience
Nouht helpith it / to tellyn his sentence
And wel I wot / the substance is in me
Yif any thyng / shall wel reportid be
Sire sey somwhat / of huntyng I you praie
Nay qd this monk / I haue no lust to plaie
Now lat anothir telle as I haue tolde
Than spak our hoost / with reud speche and bolde
And seide onto Nonnys preest anoon
Com neer thou preest / com hidir thou sire Iohn
Telle vs such thyng / as may our hertis glade
Be blithe / thouh thou ride vpon a iade
What thouh thyn hors / be foul and leene
Yif he wol serue / ne rekke the nat a bene
Look that thyn herte be mery evirmo
Yis sir qd he / yis sir / so mot I go
But I be merie / I wis I wol be blamed
And riht anoon his tale he hath attamed
And thus he seide / vnto vs everichoon
This swete preest / this goodly man sire Iohn

l.hi: Incipit narracio eiusdem de Chaūntecler ⁊ ꝐPertelotte ~

div.l: A poore Widdwe somdel stopen in age
Was whilom dwellyng / in a naruh cotage
Beside a grove / stondyng in a dale
This widdwe of which / I telle you my tale
Sith thilke day / that she was last a wiff
In pacience she ledde / a symple lyff
For litel was hir catel / and hir rente
Bi housbondrie / which as god hir sente
She fond hir silf / and hir douhtren too
She fond Thre large sowes / had she and no moo
Thre keen / and eeke a sheep that hiht malle
Wol sooty was hir bour / and eeke hir halle
In which she eete / wol many a sondry mele
Of poynaut saus / hir neded nevir a dele
No deynte morsel / passid thoruh hir throte
Hir diete was accordaut to hir cote
Replecious made hir nevir seeke
A tempre diete / was al hir phisike
And excersise / and hertis suffisauce
The gowte / let hir nevir forto dauce
Ne peplexi / shente nat hir hed
Wyne ne drank she neithir white ne red
Hir boord was servid / most with white and blak
Milk and brou bred / in which she fond no lak
Somtyme bacoūn / and somtyme an egh or tweie
For she was thanne / as a maner deie
A yerd she hadde enclosid al aboute
With drye stikkis / and a dich withoute
In which she hadde / a cok hihte Chautecleer
In al the lond / of crowyng ne was his peer
His vois was merier / than the mery orgon
On masse dayes / that in the chirch goon
Wel sikerere / was his crowyng in his logge
Than any Clok in Abbay / or Orlogge
Bi nature he knew / ech ascensiou
Off the Equinoccial / in that tou
For whan degrees / fyfteen wer ascendid
Than krew he so / it myht nat ben amendid
His comb was redder / than the fyn coral
And batailed / as it wer a Castel wal
His bil was blak / and as get it shoon
Lyk Asure / were his leggis and his toon
Hs nayles whitter / than the lilie flour
And lyk the bourned gold / was his colour
This gentil Cok / had in his gouꝰernauce
Seven hennys / to doon al his plesauce
Which were his sustres / and his ꝑperamours
And wondir lyk to hym / as of colours
Of which the fairest hewid / on hir throte
Was hoote fayr damysele ꝑpertelote
Curtays she was discrete and debonair
And compynable and bar hir silf so fair
Sith thilke day / that she was seven yere olde
That trewly she hath the herte in holde
Off Chautecleere / loke in euery liht
He lovith hir so / that wel was hym therwith
But such a Ioye / ther was to heere hym synge
Whanne that the briht sonne / began to sprynge
In swete accord my lefe is faren in londe
For thilke tyme / as I vndirstonde
Beestis and briddes cowde speke and syng
And so befel / that in a dawenyng
As Chautecleer / among his wives alle
Sat on his perche / that was in the halle
And next hym sat / this fair Pertilote
This Chautecleer gan groven in his throte
As man that in A dreme / is drechid soor
She was agast / and seid herte deer
And whan that Pertilote / thus herd hym roor
What ayleth you to grone in this maneer
Ye been a verrey sleeper / fy for shame
And he Answerde / and seide thus madame
I pray you that ye take it nat to greff
By god I mette I was / in such myscheff
Nowe right that myn herte is sore affriht
Now god qd he / my sweven reche ariht
And keepe my body / out of foul prisou
Me mette that me romed vp and dou
Withinne our yerd / wher that I sauh a beest
Was lyk an houd and wolde haue maad a reest
Vpon my body / and wolde haue maad me ded
His colour was betwix yelwe and red
And tippid was his tail / and bothe his eerys
His snowte was smal / with glowyng eyen tweie
With blak onlik / the remanaut of his heris
Yit for his look / for feer almost I deie
This caused me / my gronyng doutlesse
A voy qd she / fy on you hertelesse
Allas qd she / for bi that god above
Nowe haue ye lost myn herte / and al my love
I can not love a coward bi my feyth
For certys / what so any woman seith
We alle desyren / yf hit myht be
To han housbondis / hardy wys and fre
And secre / and no nygard ne no fool
Ne hym that is agast of euery tool
Ne noon avautour / bi that god above
How durst ye seyn / for shame vnto your love
That any thyng / myht make you afferd
Haue ye no manys hert / and han a berd
Allas and konne ye ben agast of swevenys
Nothyng god wot / but vanyte in sweven is
Swevenys regendren of replecious
And ofte of fvme / of complexious
Whan humours been / to habundaut in a wiht
Certis this drem / which ye han met to nyht
Cōmmeth of the gret suꝑperfluite
Off your colour / parde
Which cawsith folk / to dreeden in her dremys
Of Arwis and of fyre / with rede bemys
Off rede beestis / that thei wol hem byte
Of contek / and of whelpis gret and lyte
Riht as the humour / of malencolye
Causeth wel many a man / in slep to crye
For feer of grete beris / and boolis blake
Or ellis blake develis / that wold hem take
Of othir humours / cowde I telle also
That werkith many a man in slepe much woo
But I wol passe / as lyghtly as I can
Loo caton / that was holde so wys a man
Seyde he nat thus / ne do no fors of dremys
Now sire qd she / whan we flee from the bemys
For goddys love / as take som laxatyff
Vp pereil of my soule / and of my lyff
I couseyl you the best / I wil nat lye
That both of Colre / and malencolie
Ye purge you / and for ye shul nat tarye
Thouh in this town / be noon Apotekarye
I shal my silf / too herbis teche yowe
That shal be for your hele / and for your prowe
And in your yerd / too herbis shal I fynde
The which han of here ꝓpropirte bi kynde
To purgen you / beneth and eke above
Forget nat this / for goddis owne love
Ye ben ful Colerik of complexiou
Ware the sonne in his Ascensiou
Ne fynde you nat / replet of humours hoot
For yiff hit do I dar weel legge a grote
That ye shal han a fevir tercian
Or an Agu / and that myht be your ban
A day or too / ye shal haue digestyves
Off wormys / er ye take your laxatyves
Off laureoll / Centaure / and fumitere
Or ellis of Elibre / that growith there
Off Catapuce / or of Gaterys beries
Off herb yve / that growith in your yerd that mery is
Pyke hem as thei growe / and ete hem Inne
Be mery housbonde / for your fadir kynne
Dredith no dreme / I can sey no more
Madame qd he / graut mercy of your lore
But nathirles / as touchyng Daune Catou
That hath of wisdom such a gret renou
Thouh that he bad / no dremys for to drede
By god men may / in olde bookꝭes rede
Off many a man / more of Auctoryte
Than evir Catou was / so mot I the
That al the revers seyn / of his sentence
And han wel fouden / bi exꝑperience
That dremys ben / significacyous
As wel of ioye / as of tribulacious
That folk enduren / in this lyf present
The needith make / of this non argument
The verray preeff / shewith hit in deede
Oone off the grettist Auctours / that men reede
Seith thus / that too felawes wente
On pylgrymage / in wol good entente
And happid so / thei comyn in A tou
Wher as ther was / such congregaciou
Off poeple / and eeke so streiht of herbergage
That thei ne foūnd / so much as oo cotage
In which thei bothe / myht logged be
Wherfore thei mosten / off necessite
As for that nyht / departe companye
And ech of hem goth to his hostelerye
And took his loggyng / as hit wold falle
That oon of hem / was loggid in a stalle
Ferre in a yerd / with oxen in a plouh
That othir man was loggid wel I nouh
As was his aventur / or his fortune
That vs governyth / alle as in comune
And so bifel long / er hit wer day
This man met in his bed / ther as he lay
How that his felawe / gan vpon hym calle
And seid allas / for in an oxen stalle
This nyht I shal be morthred ther I lye
Now helpe me deere broothir er I dye
In all haste / come to me he seyde
This man out of his slepe / for fere abrayde
But whan that he / was waked of his slepe
He turned hym / and took of this no keepe
Hym thouht this dreme / was but vanyte
Thus twyes in his slepe / dremyd he
And atte thridde tyme his felawe
Cam as hym thouht / and seide I am now slawe
Behold my bloody woudes / deep and wide
Arys vp erly / in the morowe tide
And atte west gate of the tou qd he
A cartfull of dong / ther shalt thou se
In which my body / is hyd pryvely
Doo thilk carte areste / boldely
My gold caused my mordre sooth to seyn
And told hym every poynt / how he was sleyn
With a full pitous face / pale of hewe
And trust wel his dreme / he fonde trewe
For on the morwe / as soone as hit was day
To his felawis Inne / he goth his way
And whan that he cam / to this Oxe stalle
Afftir his felawe / he began to calle
Thostler / hym answerde anoon
And seid sire / your felawe is a gon
As soon as day / he went out of the tou
This man gan falle / in suspeciou
Remembryng of his dremys / that he mette
And foorth he goth no lenger wolde he lette
Vnto the westgate / of the toun and fond
A donge carte wente / as hit were to donge lond
That was arrayed / in the same wyse
As ye han herd / the dede man devyse
And with an hardy herte / he gan to crye
Vengeauce and Iustice / of this felonye
My felawe mordred is / I this same nyht
And in this Carte / he lith gapyng vpriht
I crye out / on the mynystres qd he
That sholde the lawe keep in this Cite
Harrow allas / here lith my felawe sleyn
What sholde I more / vnto this tale seyn
The people out sterte / and caste the carte to groude
And in the myddis of the donge thei foude
The dede man / that moordred was all newe
A blisful god / that art so iuste and trewe
Loo how that thou / bewreiest moordre alway
Moordre wol out / that see we day bi day
Moordre is lothsom / and abhomynable
To god that is so iust / and resonable
That he ne wol suffren it / helid to be
Thouh hit abide / a yere or too or thre
Moordre wol out / this is my conclusiou
And riht anoon / the mynystres of the tou
Han hent the cartere / and so soore I peyned
And eeke the hosteleer / so soore engyned
That thei beknew / ther wikkednys anoone
And weer I honged / bi the nekke boone
Heere ye may see / that dremys be to dreede
And certis / in the same book I reede
Riht in the nexte chapityr / aftir this
I gable nat / so haue I Ioye or blys
Two men / that wolde han passid ovir the see
For certeyn causis / in to a ferre contre
Yiff that the wynde / ne hadde be contrarye
That made hem in A Cite / for to Tarie
That stood ful meryly / vpon an haven side
But on a day / vpon an evyn tyde
The wynde gan chauge / and blowe riht as hym lest
Ioly and glad / thei wentyn vnto rest
And casten hem / fully / ful erly for to saile
But to that oo man / fille a gret mervaile
That on of hem sleepyng / as he lay
He mette a woundir dreme / ageyn the day
Hym thouht a man stood / bi his beddis side
And hym cōmmandid / that he sholde abide
And seide hym thus / yiff thou to morwe wende
Thou shalt be dreynt / my tale is atte an eende
He wook and tolde his felawe / what he mette
And praied hym his viage / for to lette
As for that day / he praide hym for to abide
His felawe that lay / bi his beddis side
Gan for to lauhen / and scornen hym wol fast
No dreme qd he / may so myn hert agast
That I wol lette / for to doo my thynges
I sette nat a strauh / by thi dremynges
For swevenes bene / but vanyteis and Iapis
Men dremyn allday / of owlys and off Apis
And many anothir mase / therwithalle
Men dreme of thyng / that nevir was ne shalle
But sith I see / that thou wolt heer abide
And thus forslouth wilfully / thy tide
God wot it rewith me / and haue good day
And thus he took his leve / and went his way
But er that he / hadde half his cours I sayled
I noot why / ne what myschauce it eylid
But casuelly / the shippes botme rente
And ship and man / vndir the watir wente
In siht of othir shippes / ther beside
That with hym seiled / atte same tyde
And therfore faire Pertilote so deere
Bi Olde examples / myht thou wel leere
That no man sholde / be to rechelesse
Off dreemys / for I sey the doutelesse
That many a dreeme / wol soore is for to dreede
Loo in the lyfe of seynt kenelm I reede
That was kenulphus sone / the noble kyng
Off Mercorik how kenelm mette a thyng
A litel er he was mordrede / on A daye
His moordre in his avisiou he seye
His norice hit hym expowned everydeel
His swevene / and bad hym keep hym weel
Fro tresou / but he was but seven yere olde
And therfore litel tale / therof he tolde
Off Any dreeme / so hooly was his herte
Begod I hadde levir / than my sherte
That ye hadde red / his legende as have I
Dame Pertilote / I sey yow trewly
Macrobius that writith this avisiou
In Auffrik off the worthy sapiou
Affermyth dreemys / and seith that thei been
Warnyng of thynges / that men aftir seen
And Ferthirmore / I pray you looketh weel
In tholde testament / of Danyel
Yiff he heeld dremys / any vanyte
Reede eeke of Ioseph / and ther shul ye see
Wher dremys be somtyme / I sey nat alle
Warnyng of thynges / that shul aftir falle
Loo of Egipt / the kyng Daun pharao
His baker and his boteler / also
Whethir thei felt / noon effect in dremys
Who so wol seekyn / actys of sondry regmys
May rede of dremys / many a woūndir thyng
Loo Cresus / which that was of lide kyng
Mette he nat / that he was vpon a tree
Which signyfied / he sholde an honged be
Loo heere Andromatha / Ector his wiff
That day that Ector / his wiff sholde leese his lyff
She dreemyd in the same nyht beforne
How that the lyff of Ector sholde be lorne
Yff thilke day he wente / vnto bataile
She warnyd hym / but hit myht nat availe
He wente for to fiht natheles
And was I slayn anoon of Achilles
But thilke tale / is al to long to telle
And eeke it is nyh day / I may nat dwelle
Shortly I sey / as for conclusiou
That I shal haue of this avisiou
Aduersyte / and I sey ferthirmore
That I ne telle of laxatyves no store
For thei be venymous I wot riht wele
I hem diffye / I love hem nevir a dele
Now lat vs speke of merth and stynte of this
Madame Pertilote / so haue I blys
Off o thyng god hath sent me large grace
For whan I see / the bewte of your face
Ye been so skarlet rede / abowten your eyen
Hit maketh all my drede / for to deyen
For also siker / as In principio
Mulier est hominis confusio
Madame I the sentence of this latyn is
Wōmman is manys Ioye / and his blys
For whan I feele a nyht your softe side
Al be hit / that I may nat on you ride
For that our perche / is maade so narwe allas
I am so fulle of ioye and of solace
And I diffie both swevene and dreme
And with that woorde / he fley dou fro the beeme
For it was day / and eeke his hennys alle
And with a chuk he gan hem for to calle
For he hadde foude a corn / that lay in the yerde
Roiall he was / and was nomore afferde
He fethirhid Pertilote / twenty tyme
Ad trad as ofte / er than hit was pryme
He looked as hit were / a grym leou
And on his toys / he romyth vp and dou
Hym dayneth nat / to sette his foote on groude
He chukked whan he hadde a corne I founde
And to hym thanne / ronne his wyves alle
Thus roial as a prynce / in his halle
Leve I thys Chautecleer / in his pasture
And aftir wol I tellyn his aventure
Whan that the moneth / in which the worlde began
That hiht march / whan god first made man
Was complete / and passid were also
Sith March began / thritty dayes and too
Befel that Chautecleer / in all his pride
His seven wyves / walkyng bi his side
Caste vp his eyen / to the briht sonne
That in the signe of Taurus hadde I ronne
Twenty degreys / and oone and somwhat more
And knew bi kynde / and bi noon othir lore
That hit was tyme / and crewe with blysful steven
The sonne he seyd is clombyn vp in heven
Fourty degrees and oon / and more I wis
Madame Pertilote / my wordis blys
Herkyn thes blysful foules / how thei syng
And for the fressh flowrys / how thei spryng
Ful is myn herte of ioye / and of solas
But sodenly befil / a sorwful caas
For evir the latter eende / of ioye is woo
God wot that wordely ioye / is soone a goo
And yif a reeder coude faire endite
He in a cronycle / savely myht it write
As for a sovereyn notabilite
Nowe every man herkyn vnto me
This story is as trewe / I vndirtake
As is the book / of laucelot de lake
That womēm holde / in gret reverence
Nowe wol I torne ageyn / tomy sentence
A Cole Fox ful of sligh iniquite
That in the grove / hath wōmnyd yeris thre
Bi his ymaginacou forn I caste
The same /nyht thoruhout the heggeis braste
In to the yerde / ther Chautecleere the faire
Was wont and eeke his hennys to repayre
And in a bedde of wortis / stille he lay
Tille it was passid vndern of the day
Waityng his tyme / on Chautecleere to falle
As gladly doon / thes homycides alle
That in a waite ligge / to moordre men
O fals moordrere / lurkyng in thy den
O newe scaryot / o Gvenelou
O fals dissimilour / o greek synou
That brouhtist troye / alle vttirly to sorwe
O Chautecleer / I cursed be that morwe
That thou in that yerd / fley from the bemys
Thou were ful wele I warned / bi thi dremys
That ilke day / was pereilous to the
But what that god forwot / mot needis be
Aftir thopynyou / off certeyn clerkis
Witnesse of hym / that any ꝑperfite clerk is
That in scole / is altercaciou
In this mater / and gret disputaciou
And hath been of an hundred thousend men
But I ne kan / ne bulte hit to the bren
As can the hooly doctour Austyn
Or boece / or the bisshop Bradwardyn
Whethir that goddis for wetyng
Streyneth me needly / for to doon a thyng
Needly cleep I / symple necessite
Or ellis yif fre chois / be grauted to me
To doo that same thyng / or do hit nouht
Thouh god forewot it / er it was I wrouht
Or yif his wetyng / streyneth neviradele
But bi necessite / condicionele
I wol nat haue to doo of such mateer
My tale is of a Cok / as ye may heer
That tooke his couseil / of his wiff with sorwe
To walken in the yerd / vpon the morwe
That he hadde mette / the dreme that I you tolde
Womēmnys couseil / been ful often colde
Womānnys couseyle / brouht vs ferst to woo
And Adam maad / fro paradys to go
Ther as he was wol mery / and wele atte ese
But for I ne wot / whom I myght displese
Yiff I coūnseil of wommēm / wolde blame
Passe ovir / for I seide it in my game
Reede Auctours / wher thei trete of such mateer
What thei seyn off wommen / ye may heer
These been the Cokkis woordes and nat myn
I can noon harm / in no woman dyvyne
Fayre in the sond / to bathe hem merily
Lyith Pertilote / and hir sustres hir by
Ageyn the sonne / and Chantecleer so free
Sang meriere then the Marmaiden in the see
For Phisiologus / seith sikerly
How that thei syngen / wel and merily
And so bifel as he caste his eye
Among the wortis / on a botirflie
He was ware of this fox / that lay wol lowe
Nothyng lest hym then / for to crowe
But cried anoon / and vp soon he sterte
As man amasid / and fraid was in his herte
For naturally / a foul desireth to flee
His contrarye / yiff it may be
For nevir erst / he hadde seie with his eye
This Chautecleere / whan he gan hym aspie
He wolde han fled / but the fox anoon
Seid gentil sire / allas where wol ye goon
Be ye affraid off me / that am your freend
Nowe certis I were wers / than any feend
Yiff I to you wolde harm / or velanye
I am nat come / your coūnseil to aspye
But trewly the cause off my commyng
Was forto herken / oonly how ye syng
My lord your fadir / god his sowle blysse
And eeke your moder / off hir gentilnysse
Han in myn hous I been / to my grete eese
And certis therfore / fayn wolde I you pleese
But men wol speeke of syngyng I wol seie
So mot I browken / wel / myn eyen tweie
Save ye I ne herde nevir / man so syng
As dede your fadir in the morwnyng
Certis it was off herte / alle that he song
And to make his vois / the more strong
He wolde so peynen hym / with bothen his eyen
He most wynken / so lowde wolde he crien
And stonden on his typton / therwith alle
And strecche foorth his necke / long and smalle
And eeke he was / of such discreciou
That ther was no man / in no Regiou
That to hym song / or in wisdam myht passe
I haue wele rad / in Daun Burnel the Asse
Among his vers / that ther was a Cock
For A preestis sone / yaff hym a knock
Vpon his leg / whil he was yong and nyce
He maad hym for to leesyn his benefyce
But certeyn ther is no comparisou
Betwex the wisdam / and discreciou
Off your fadir / and his subtilite
Now syngeth sire / for seynt charite
Lat see / can ye your fadir coutirfete
This Chautecleer / his weenges gan to bete
As man that cowde his tresou nat aspie
So was he ravysshed / with his flaterie
Allas ye lordis / many a fals flaterour
Is in your court / and many a loseniour
That plesen you / wele more bi my feith
Than he that soothfastnesse / vnto you seith
Reedith Ecclesiaste / of flaterie
But war ye lordis / off their trecherie
This Chautecleere / stood vpon his toes
Strechyng his necke / and helde his eyen clos
And gan to crowe / lowde for the nonys
And daun Russel the Fox / stert vp attonys
And bi the garget / hente Chautecleere
And on his back / toward the woodde hym beere
For yit ther was man / that hym seewid
Allas that Chantecleer / fley from the bemys
Allas his wiff / rouht nat off his dremys
And on a fryday / felle alle this myschauce
O Venus that art goddes / of plesauce
More for delyte / than the world to multeplie
Why woldist thou suffre hym / on thy day to dye
O Gavfrid deere / maister soverayne
That whan thy worthi Richard was I slayne
With shot / compleyndist his deth so sore
Why ne hadde I nowe thi sentence and thi lore
The friday forto chide / as dede ye
For a Fryday / soothly slayn was he
Than wolde I shewe you / how I cowde pleyne
For Chautecleeris dreede / and eeke his peyne
Certis such crye / ne lamentaciou
Was nevir maade / off ladies whan Iliou
Was wonne / and Pirrus with his streiht swerd
Whan he hadde hent / kyng pryam bi the berd
And sleyn hym / as seith Enydos
As maden / all the hennys in the cloos
Whan thei hadden seyn / off Chautecleere the sihte
But soveraynly / Dame Pertilote shrihte
Wele lowder thanne dede hasc hastrubalis wiffe
Whan hir housbonde / hadde I loste his lyffe
And that the Romayns / hadde I brent Cartage
She was so full / off turment and off rage
That wilfully in to the fiere she sterte
And brend hir silf / with a stedefast herte
O wofull hennys / riht so cryden ye
As whan Nero / brend the Cite
Off Roome / cryden senatouris wyves
For that her housbondes / losten alle her lyves
Withouten gilt / this nero hath hem sleyne
Now will I torne / to my tale egayne
The sely widwe / and hir douhtren too
Herden the hennys / cryen and make woo
And out atte dooris / stirte thei anoon
And sauh the Fox / to the grove goon
And bare vpon his bak / the Cok away
And thei cryed out / harrow and welaway
Ha ha the Fox / and aftir hym thei ran
And eeke with stonys / many anothir man
Ran Colle our dogge / talbot and garlond
And malkyn with a dystaff / in hir hond
Ran Cove and Calves / and eeke the verray hogges
So ferde were / for berkyng off the dogges
And showtyng off the men / and women eeke
Thei ronne so / hem thouht her hertys breeke
Thei yelliden / as feendis doon in helle
The dokkes yelleden / as men wolden hem quelle
The geese for feer / flowen ovir the trees
Out off heuen / cam the swarme off bees
So hidouse was the noise / A benedicite
Certis Iakke strawe / and his meyne
Ne maaden nevir / shrowtyng half so shrill
Whan thei wolden / any flemmyng kyll
As thilke tyme / was maade vpon the fox
Off bras the brosten bemys and of box
Off horn off bonys in which thei blewe and powpid
And therwith all / thei shryked and thei howpid
It seemyd tho / as heuen shold haue falle
Nowe good men / I pray you herkenyth alle
Loo how fortune / turneth sodenly
The hope the pride / eeke off her enmy
This Cokk that lay / vpon this Foxis bak
In alle his drede / vnto the Fox he spak
And seide sire / and I were as ye
Yit wolde I seyn / as wisly god help me
Turneth ageyn / ye prowde cherlis alle
Verray pestilence / vpon your bodies falle
Nowe Am I /come vnto the wooddis side
Mavgre your hede / the Cok shall here abide
I wol hym ete / in feith and that anone
The Fox answerd / in feyth hit shall be doone
And as he spak that woord all sodenly
The Cok brak from his mouth delyverly
And hih vpon a tre / he fleih anoon
And whan the Fox sauh / that he was goon
Allas qd he / O Chaūntecleere Allas
I haue to you qd he / doon trespas
In-as moch as I maad you afferd
Whan I you hente / and browth onto this yerd
But sire I dede it / in no wicked intente
Com dou and I shall telle you what I mente
I shall seyn sooth to you / god help me so
Nay thanne qd he / I shrewe vs both too
And first I shrew my silf / both blood and bonyes
Yif thou begile me / oftener thenne oonys
Thou shalt nomore / thorwh thi flaterye
Doo me syng / and wynk with myn eye
For he that wynketh / whan he sholde see
I pray to god / lat him nevir the
Nay qd the Fox / but yeve hym myschance
That is so vndiscreet / off governauce
That Iangelith / whan he sholde hold his pees
Loo such it is / forto be recheles
And necligent / and trusteth on flatterie
And ye that holde / this tale but folie
As off a Fox / off cok / or off an henne
Taketh the moralite theroff / goodmene
For seynt Paule seith / alle that writen is
To our doctryn / hit is I wryten I wis
Taketh the frute / and lateth the chaffe be stille
Nowe good god / iff that hit be thi wille
As seith my lord / so maake vs alle good men
And bryng vs to his hihe blys Amen
SIr Nvnnys preest / our host seide anoon
I blessid be thi breche / and every stoon
This was a mery tale / of Chautecleer
But bi my trouth / yiff thou were seculer
Thou woldist ben / a trede foule a riht
For yff thou coragge / as thou hast myht
The were neede / of hennys as I weene
Ya. mo than vij tymes / seventene
See suche brawne / hath this gentil preest
So grete a neck / and such a large breest
He lookith as a sparhawk / wtith his eyen
Hym needith nat / his colour for to dyen
Wtith brasill ne wtith greyn / off portyngal
Now sire fair falle you / for your tale
And aftir that / he wtith full mery cheer
Seid vnto the Nūnne / as ye may heer
Madame and I durst I wolde you pray
To telle a tale in fortheryng of ourꝰer way
Than myht ye do vn to vs gret eese
Gladly sire qd she so that I myht pleese
You and this worthi company
And began hir tale riht thus fulle sobirly
